author: {'steamid': '76561198018941438', 'num_games_owned': 544, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 848, 'last_played': 1710663667}
review:
This game uniquely blends Japanese character learning with RPG elements, creating an engaging, albeit imperfect, experience. While it might not excel as a language learning tool or stand out as an RPG, it offers an enjoyable approach to mastering Japanese characters and would highly recommend it to anyone trying to learn katakana.

The gameplay involves defeating Katakana enemies by selecting the correct sounds, a concept that's both innovative and fun for those willing to overlook its RPG flaws. The journey to completion takes approximately 10 hours, accessible even to casual gamers.

However, the game's design would benefit from some refinement. Navigating through all 71 characters is cumbersome; a simpler character stepper for the constants and vowels would of enhanced the learning experience. 

Only the basic attack is linked to character recognition, limiting the potential for deeper engagement with Japanese. Incorporating mini-games for spells or status effects could enrich the gameplay and learning experience.

Moreover, the game underutilizes reverse recognition exercises, where players identify Katakana from sounds, an equally crucial skill. Additionly the final boss introduces an interesting concept—forming words with monsters—that could have been effectively integrated throughout the game for vocabulary building but which was not.

The Enemy variety is another area where the game falls short, with repetitive encounters that detract from the learning experience. Introducing varied enemy types based on phonetic features could make memorization more intuitive and enjoyable (like a sounds being fire type/s sounds being fast/dakuten being unaffected by physical attacks).

The story is... there. I'm sure whoever wrote the game knows the quality of the story they wrote.

Despite these critiques, I enjoyed myself enough to finish it (and learn all the katakana). With some improvements, it has the potential to make learning Japanese characters as entertaining as it is educational.

review:
This sequel is much more polished than the original hiragana game. The use of plugins really enhances things and the art and design are both better as well. As a teaching tool it is engaging and the combination of hearing the sound and having the strokes appear when you attack is really effective.

I am so impressed by the improvement in game making skill between the first and second one and am generally inspired by this series. It combines two of my favorite things. RPG Maker and learning Japanese. I would definitely recommend this one!

author: {'steamid': '76561199010042150', 'num_games_owned': 3874, 'num_reviews': 2454, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1705776024}
review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999629349', 'num_games_owned': 2195, 'num_reviews': 277, 'playtime_forever': 303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1701894698}
review:
[h1]Kiba Snowpaw's Epic Journey Through "Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War"[/h1]

[b]Reviewer:[/b] Kiba Snowpaw, a 36-year-old seasoned Furry Ice Wolf gamer from the frost-laden world of HowlStrom, mastering the art of ice magic.

[h2]Introduction: A HowlStrom Warrior's New Challenge[/h2]

In the heart of the icy tundra of HowlStrom, where the snow whispers secrets of ancient magic, I, Kiba Snowpaw, found myself enthralled by an adventure not just in gaming but in language learning. "Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War" is more than a game; it's a portal to a new world, a new language, and a new challenge for an Ice Wolf warrior like me.

[h3]Gameplay: Merging Battle with Learning[/h3]

[i]The core of the game[/i] is a unique blend of RPG elements and educational content. As I embarked on this journey, each Katakana character transformed from a mere symbol to a formidable adversary, challenging both my strategic skills and my newfound linguistic abilities. Battling these Katakana creatures felt like facing the fierce blizzards of HowlStrom, where each victory was a step closer to mastering this exotic language.

[u]Educational Value: A Furry's Perspective[/u]

Diving into the depths of Katakana, the game provided me, Kiba Snowpaw, with a comprehensive guide to mastering this aspect of the Japanese language. Each character was introduced with visual animations and audio examples, reminiscent of the ancient runes and chants of HowlStrom shamans. This educational journey was not just about memorizing characters; it was about understanding a culture, a language, and integrating it with my furry identity.

[strike]Storyline and Adventure: An Ice Wolf's Tale[/strike]

The storyline of the game is an epic tale, resonating with the adventures and legends of HowlStrom. As I ventured through this digital Japan, I encountered various characters, each unfolding a new chapter of the story and deepening my connection to the language. These characters became my allies, my pack, as we fought together against the shape-shifting monsters of Katakana.

[h2]Conclusion: A Howling Success[/h2]

"Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War" is a rare gem in the gaming world, offering both entertainment and education in a single experience. As Kiba Snowpaw, I found this game not only as a means to expand my linguistic skills but also as a way to connect deeper with my furry persona and the mystical elements of my homeland, HowlStrom. It is a must-play for any furry gamer looking to embark on an adventure of learning and discovery.

[hr][/hr]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/323190/]Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War on Steam[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561197998512328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1700019085}
review:
A series of games to help you learn Japanese.

This is the second game in the series (the game teaches you hiragana), and has vast improvements.
There is voice acting now, and you can win affection over your comrades like a dating sim, granting them extra abilities in battle. The story is a bit generic, but more effort was at least put in than the first game, and you even get your own snazzy apartment with its own theme song.

No more random encounters! you can just walk around enemies if you don't want to fight.
The menu is much better, you can now see all of the vowels (a,i,u,e,o) arranged all mostly in one big square screen, making it easy to select characters (even with the mouse, and you can now select enemy targets with the mouse too).


There's an interesting mechanic (that was present in the first game as well) that switches it up so you need to input the katakana radical instead of the romaji - I like this as it reinforces your learning even more.

The soundtrack is J-Pop and traditional Japanese Music inspired, and is way more catchy and fitting than the last game, The boss battle theme rocks way harder than it should. Sounds like something straight out of a modern anime. If you are a fan of JRPGs like Chrono Trigger, you will feel right at home. 

You could probably learn this stuff faster though a textbook or online, but lets be honest: playing a video game is way more fun and engaging. And the coolest thing is that you will actually be able to use the stuff you learn in this game in real life, so it's like you level up in real life.

author: {'steamid': '76561199163369506', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 2178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2178, 'last_played': 1697219760}
review:
Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana War is an educational RPG developed by Sleepy Duck and released in January 2017 1. The game is designed to teach players how to read and write Katakana, one of the three writing systems used in the Japanese language 1. The game is set up like a classic 16-bit RPG, where you play as the protagonist who is learning Japanese from a teacher. The game has three chapters, and each chapter introduces a new set of characters to learn 1.

The game has several pros. It teaches Katakana in bite-sized pieces, making it easy to learn and memorize. The game also has vocab lessons and basic grammar lessons that are helpful for beginners 1. The game’s use of repetition to help players remember Katakana is also commendable 1. The game’s price point is also affordable, making it accessible to many people 1.

However, there are some downsides to the game. The music can be repetitive, and the storyline is not very interesting 2. The characters are not well-developed, which can make it difficult for players to become invested in them or the game 2. The game’s use of calligraphy-style Katakana can also be confusing at times, as it doesn’t always match the font used in battle 2.

Overall, Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana War is a great game for early or casual Japanese learners. It has its flaws but is still worth playing if you’re interested in learning Katakana.

Some other people have reviewed:

https://howlongtobeat.com/game/43077/reviews/latest/1

author: {'steamid': '76561198092501220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 805, 'last_played': 1699118836}

author: {'steamid': '76561198105590811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 653, 'last_played': 1695328636}
review:
Better than Hiragana Battle. Here it's actually possible to play without cheating or grind. Combat is more forgiving, more quality of life features and better economy (because you're not forced to spend all you can on revives and healing). Voice acting and story is rather "undercooked" though.

Good way to recap what you already know and fill in the blanks, not so much to start learning from scratch, because the game does not provide associations (for example - カ (ka) - KAtana cutting paper, ア (a) - Axe) which does not make learning katakana easier. However, next game about kanji does provide associations.

If you like RPGs and want to learn Japanese - try it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198360810197', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1595049241}

author: {'steamid': '76561197980593659', 'num_games_owned': 1493, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 1563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1560, 'last_played': 1694717912}
review:
I'm going to judge this three ways: as a sequel, as a game, and as a learning tool.

As a sequel: It fixes many of the mistakes of its predecessor, but adds a few of its own. For one it takes place exclusively in Japan now which is a deeply, deeply strange decision for a game about living katakana symbols who can only be hurt by making the correct noise at them. It's not clear why all of the random Japanese people you meet aren't just out there reading the characters instead of relying on six foreigners who are having to learn them as they go.

As a game: It's pretty bad. They tried to make the RPG battling a bit more interesting this time around which really just gets in the way of what you're here for: matching shapes. The story and characters are pretty bad, and the gameplay (while better than the previous entry) is bland.

As a learning tool: I think a person would struggle quite a bit to use this alone as a way to learn katakana. It's mostly a convoluted wrapper on the concept of flash cards, so if you're looking for an excuse to do flash cards, this could work.

review:
As I said in my review of Learn Japanese to Survive! Hiragana Battle, I also utilized this game to practice Katakana. When it comes to originality, the sequel is an improvement in most ways, such as original character art, nice voice acting, stories and affection system, but I personally feel indifferent about these and focus on the educational offerings instead. Some other minor problems include the world being less immersive and there being no random encounters, which means less practicing overall. Nevertheless, it should serve as another fun and a good source for learning and practicing Katakana.

Rating: B

author: {'steamid': '76561197998280696', 'num_games_owned': 3109, 'num_reviews': 606, 'playtime_forever': 948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 948, 'last_played': 1618534766}
review:
In the enchanting realm of educational gaming, behold a game that shines like a star in the night sky, a beacon of how to seamlessly meld the worlds of learning and entertainment into an enthralling tapestry. This exceptional language-learning RPG effortlessly weds the domains of education and amusement, delivering an odyssey that's as intellectually invigorating as it is uproariously enjoyable.

At its very heart lies the brilliance, an opus of comprehensive lessons designed to conquer the enigmatic Katakana characters. This isn't a game that hurls these characters at you haphazardly; no, it offers a symphony of guidance, replete with engrossing animations and real-life speech examples. Learning Katakana morphs from a mundane chore into an exhilarating quest, a treasure hunt in the realm of a new language.

However, this experience goes beyond linguistic conquest. It's an RPG adventure that captivates your interest from the very beginning to the end. While journeying through this fantastical realm, facing formidable creatures becomes intricately linked with improving your language skills. It's a clever blend of gaming and education that keeps you engaged and highly motivated to elevate your linguistic proficiency.

Amidst your grand expedition, a troupe of endearing characters crosses your path, each bearing their own unique personalities and idiosyncrasies. They transform the often solitary act of linguistic study into a social and delightful experience. You'll discover yourself genuinely engrossed in their tales, forming bonds that transcend the boundaries of the game itself.

The in-game quizzes serve as delightful confections, adding a dash of fun challenge to assess your burgeoning knowledge. These quizzes do more than merely cement what you've absorbed; they bestow a sense of triumph as you conquer them. It's the perfect blend of gaming exhilaration and educational reinforcement.

Whether you are a linguistic aspirant, on a quest for linguistic mastery, or a dedicated gamer in search of a captivating adventure, Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War is an absolute riot. It unfurls the scroll of wisdom that education need not be a dull affair and that gaming can be a formidable catalyst for learning. Prepare for an odyssey that will leave you spellbound by your newfound linguistic prowess and thoroughly enchanted by the universe of Katakana War. It's a grand journey that promises both enlightenment and elation, rendering it an imperative addition to the repertoire of anyone yearning for a unique fusion of gaming and learning experiences.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046336608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 618, 'last_played': 1684610015}
review:
Sebbene la maggior parte dei giochi in rpg maker su steam non siano il massimo, questo si distingue dalla massa non per la storia o il gameplay, nella media se confrontati ad altri giochi simili come prezzo e composizione, ma per il fatto che ogni singolo nemico è una sillaba del sillabario katakana, e va battuto scegliendo l'attacco della sillaba che esso rappresenta.
All'inizio può sembrare macchinoso, però le sillabe vengono imparate a gruppi di 5 o 3 e si presenteranno come nemici nel livello successivo, in modo da poterle memorizzare con calma. 
Inoltre durante le varie lezioni vengono spiegate regole grammaticali, la fonetica dei vari simboli e la loro scrittura, nonché esempi con parole in inglese e giapponese, scritte sia in rōmaji(il nostro alfabeto) che in katakana.
Consiglio infine di munirvi di un taccuino per scrivere le sillabe imparate, può essere utile quando si ha bisogno di una consultazione rapida dei katakana(sebbene le lezioni possano essere sempre riviste dal menù)

Tiranndo le somme finali, è un gioco carino se si vuole imparare qualcosa di nuovo o se si ha del tempo per provare un gioco semplice e rilassante. Il prezzo è anche nella norma, sebbene consiglio di aspettare i saldi Steam per comprarlo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198204270512', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1684340433}

author: {'steamid': '76561197963583718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 308, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1683994611}
review:
Part two in the Learn Japanese to Survive! language practice trilogy. This is an RPGmaker series designed to help beginner level Japanese student learn and practice very basic Japanese writing. You get a bit of vocabulary and a couple of useful phrases as well.  If you have not studied Japanese before, I would recommend you do the games in order (despite the first game being a bit annoying in some areas gameplay-wise).

The good:
There are quite a few improvements over the the first game (hiragana). 
From a learning perspective, you now get to hear the sounds of the characters while you battle. You also get to see stroke-order demonstrated when you learn.
Sidequests provide bonus vocabulary and sometimes unique weapons and consumables.
It's now easier to navigate the answer selection grid during combat.
The turn-based combat itself has been streamlined so that you will never end up targeting an opponent one of your other characters has already dispatched.
The character designs are modern and appealing.

The meh:
It's an RPGmaker game. Don't expect Elden Ring.
The Danganrompa style voice acting is obnoxiously cheerful and cringey. Luckily you can FFW easily enough.
The affection systems between characters are kind of half-baked. I did get some bonuses by spending some more time chatting with a couple of my party, but it mostly seemed like a distraction.  In fact, I would have preferred fewer characters but more depth back-storywise.
It's an educational game, so don't expect a meaningful story or overly challenging puzzles apart from the memorization necessary.

The verdict:
As a language instructor and JSL learner I would say this is a good supplement for Japanese students who also have a soft spot for vintage 8-bit and 16-bit RPGs. Despite having learned Japanese for years, I still have brain-farts where I mix-up "sa" and "se" or have no idea what "wo" means. If you're interested in learning Japanese for the first time, just pick up the whole trilogy, especially if it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138588616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1684038290}
review: This game series has been a wonderful and fun way of adding some variety to my studies. I doubt I play the first two more than once (Hiragana and Katakana), but it's still been great having these to help move me along for learning the most basic and fundamental parts of Japanese. I definitely wish I had these games the first time I set out to learn Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060936212', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 338, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1680536606}
review:
6/10

Прежде, чем задумываться о покупке данной игры, стоит обратить внимание на первую часть - Hiragana Battle. Как катакана учится по канону после хираганы, так и эта игра проходится после. Их даже связали хронологически.

Удивительное.
Поэтому и акцент я буду делать, скорее, на различиях, позитивных и негативных. Нападения противников теперь не происходят внезапно - их видно на карте, в том числе примерный уровень сложности, можно даже побегать от них. Больше не нужно вздрагивать при каждой встрече. Партийцы теперь обладают более живыми характерами, которые, впрочем, состоят из клише и какой-то одной ключевой черты. Каждый представляет какую-то страну, и Россия тоже есть. За нее девушка по имени... Миша. Или это парень в платье и сережках, я так и не понял. Японцы и не такое могут придумать. Еще ввели ачивки в единственной игре этой серии. Но достижения - это сомнительное достижение, как видно ниже. И наконец из грустного - пропали битвы на словах, теперь только слоговая азбука. Одно слово будет - в финальной фазе финального босса, но это очень слабое развитие идеи. В первой части было гораздо веселее и продуктивнее.

Плюсы.
- По-прежнему можно неплохо подучить или повторить катакану. Как основной источник знаний, я бы эту игру не рекомендовал, но как дополнение - почему бы и нет. В этом ее ключевая ценность.
- Большой плюс в сравнении с предыдущей частью - теперь атаки делаются не просто текстом, его сопровождает начертание и озвучивание.

Минусы.
- Игра проходится за счет хорошего знания катаканы и базовой прокачки - просто докупайте снаряжение и бутылки лечения. Почему минус? Магия не нужна вообще, всякие прочие зелья, временные усилители и прочий микроменеджмент - лишь пустая трата времени. Погружения не организуют, процесс обучения смажут.
- Еще одна сравнительно бесполезная механика - развитие отношений. Да, она качает показатели, но не сильно. Но нужно прокликивать много графоманской болтовни, и авторы решили завязать на эту механику адовую ачивку. Помимо вашей основной партии придется качнуть прочих потенциальных участников, а для этого нанести вместе в боях по 500 ударов на партию. Да, очки получают все сразу, но лишних партийцев четверо, а свободных мест в партии 3, так что придется кликать 1000 раз.
- И подарком за вот этот безумный гринд будут дикие тормоза в финальной сцене привязанности для каждого партийца. Как они умудрились так положить графику в игре на RPGMaker, я до сих пор не понимаю.
- По-прежнему никаких ассоциаций, мнемоники, только зубрежка и гринд.

В общем, как JRPG игра слишком быстрая, простая и блеклая. Как тренажер, пойдет в комплекте с какими-то другими техниками, учитывающими ассоциативное запоминание.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201246082', 'num_games_owned': 3232, 'num_reviews': 1500, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1656182594}
review:
Hayatta Kalmak İçin Japonca Öğrenin! Katakana War, Sleepy Duck tarafından geliştirilen ve RIVER CROW STUDIO tarafından yayınlanan bir eğitim oyunudur. Oyun, Katakana yazı sistemine odaklanarak oyunculara Japon dilinin temellerini öğretmek için tasarlanmıştır.

Oyun PC ve Mac ile uyumludur ve hem eğlenceli hem de eğitici interaktif bir rol yapma deneyimi sunar. Oyuncular, Japonya'yı şekil değiştiren canavarların istilasından kurtarmaları gereken hikaye tabanlı bir maceranın içine girerler. Yol boyunca, Japonca kelimelerin nasıl telaffuz edileceği ve oluşturulacağına dair ayrıntılı talimatlarla birlikte her bir Katakana karakterini nasıl okuyacaklarını ve yazacaklarını öğrenecekler.

Oyunda her bir karakterin nasıl yazılacağını gösteren görsel animasyonlar ve her bir karakterin nasıl telaffuz edileceğini gösteren sesli konuşma örnekleri bulunmaktadır. Oyuncular Katakana şeklini almış düşmanlarla savaşa girerler ve hasar vermek için onları doğru şekilde çevirmeleri gerekir. Oyuncuların bilgilerini test etmek için oyun içi sınavlar da mevcuttur.

Oyuncular karakterlerle yeni arkadaşlıklar kurabilir ve hikaye sekanslarının kilidini açabilir, deneyim puanları kazanabilir ve karakterlerinin seviyesini yükseltebilirler. Oyun ayrıca oyuncuların bilgilerini tazelemek için tamamlanmış dersleri gözden geçirmelerine olanak tanır.

Genel olarak, Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana Savaşı, Japon dilinin temellerini öğrenmek için ilgi çekici ve etkili bir araçtır. Eğitim ve eğlenceyi bir araya getiren oyun, Japonca öğrenmek isteyenler için ideal bir başlangıç kursu.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996605343', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1679552750}
review: Really cool game. I'm very happy to see that games like this are being created. I wish I had these types of games when I was younger. I'd be pro by now in something that is useful. As for the game itself, it's very straight forward and a lot of fun to play. If you purchase this game, make sure you have a sketch book to practice drawing the symbols as you learn. Progression through this game would probably be impossible if you don't. If you take a break from playing, you will need the drawings as a reference to refresh your memory and help you progress through the game. It makes you feel even better to draw them and see yourself writing in Japanese, and you only have to do it once, trust me. Sketch book and a sharpie. The game feels like final fantasy with the battle system and the map is fun to explore and figure out. I lived in Japan for a while and never learned very much Japanese, so if I get the chance to visit again someday, I will have some knowledge to take with me. I am happy I purchased this game. We need more educational games than people just killing each other over and over again. <3

Pretty fun, a good improvement over the first game.
The last boss was a good fight, though magic, besides healing, felt pretty weak.
I felt like Daisuke was the main character at some point, with high STR and INT.
Still a bit salty about my strength being so low even with a good 7 strength potions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057344186', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 608, 'last_played': 1678209568}
review:
Game is a slight improvement to the Hiragana one. Neat introduction to Japanese. Learn some basic vocabulary and phrases (~100), as well as the Katakana characters of course.

There is very little overlap with the Vocab here and in the Hiragana game. It makes sense to play that one first, as it is intended.

If you have no knowledge of the Japanese language, these games are a nice starting point.

One downside was raising the affection of each character, the outings were especially annoying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190565041', 'num_games_owned': 450, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 850, 'last_played': 1677346097}

author: {'steamid': '76561198326097650', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1019, 'last_played': 1676394423}
review:
Assuming you've already played at the first game of the trilogy Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana War.
I'll just point out the differences 

It's pretty much the same thing with more vocabulary and more side quests.
There's also voice over and the characters feel way more alive.

The main thing is the combat system which is way better.
You actually get to see the katana warriors on the map and when you go near them you get into combat mode (you can avoid them if you want). Basically the same thing as Paper Mario, no more random combats at every single step.

You play your characters one by one and not all of them at once like in the first game and you can also see in which orders you and the ennemies play.

You actually get to hear the pronunciation everytime you pick the corresponding hiragana character in combat, which is quite a nice extra feature to help you memorize them.

Overrall a straight upgrade but the core of the game, the progression and lessons remain pretty much the same thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561199021331373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1697990608}
review: I would play hiragana first (which I did) but this is by far the best way to learn a language. The story can feel a little campy in spots but thumbs up over all.

author: {'steamid': '76561199044038536', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2282, 'last_played': 1680999568}
review:
After playing Hiragana battle, from the same developers,
I can say it's a huge improvement! 

Here the pro's: 
Before playing this game I had zero knowledge of Katakana,
and this game nailed it! I totally can write/understand the Katakana now.

Side quest are also very helpful for extending your learning curve.

Nice story about the Obake, or better said Katakana letters that taking over Japan. 

Later on in the game you unlock a place where you can always go to, where you can train/challenge your memory on all the Katakana letters you have learned.
They call it shape-shifting monsters that are in that place, but are actually Romajii letters, where you have  to combat with the right Katakana letter, and the other time in a battle it's Katakana, and you have to choose between the right Romajii letter that fits that Katakana.  
It's a nice place where you can challenge yourself in what you have learned.

Improvement with this game is the turn base.
In the previous game(Hiragana war) you have to select the right answer in a row for your whole party,
if one of the Hiragana characters where killed and your last party member gonna take a blow, then it's automatically the wrong character, because he give his attack to the undefeated hiragana, and so it is the wrong hiragana, because his attack was meant for the defeated hiragana.
In this game you have turn base, and attack with one character at a time, instead of all your party members at once.
if this is vague, you gonna understand, or understand already that it is a huge improvement with this game Katakana war! 

Also selecting the Katakana characters is a huge improvement, if have to relate it with the previous game Hiragana battle. 

So, lot of improvements!

Now the cons..

First of all, 'and it ruined my experience in the story'
the voice acting is horrible, and if I am honest it  would have been better without voice acting.
Also the repetitive sounds by the characters, makes the experience frustrating. 

Also the static images that represent the characters, were also a disappointment.. 

Further if you are for the learning and are 100% committed to ignore most of the cons, then this game is for you! 

I completed it 100%, so my review is very honest. 
But be prepared, the voice acting is horrifying/cringe,

but to learn Katakana this game is a ULTIMATE GEM!!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198110722133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 749, 'last_played': 1685615183}
review:
I have struggled to learn Katakana for years now due to some symbols looking so similar. 
After buying this game it has become so much easier and I am feeling MUCH more confident in my ability to both read and write in Katakana. BUT, if you truly want to have it down pat, make sure to grab some paper and a pen/pencil and write out the new letters once you get a new lesson. I write it out for about 3 lines in a Notebook. Then continue and play the game. Take breaks, randomly quiz yourself. All of these plus this game put together and you'll have it memorized in no time ^_^
The story line for me is 'meh' but I enjoy the game play and it's helped in my goal. 
If you have struggled like me with Katakana just go ahead and buy it, I struggled thinking whether or not it'd be worth the money for only one of the kanas instead of all of them. It's worth it ^.^

author: {'steamid': '76561198032452361', 'num_games_owned': 672, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1845, 'last_played': 1675517372}
review:
A fun way to learn Katakana through a video game c:

Pretty much an upgrade from part 1 (Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle)

This game will teach you the ''international'' (foreign) Japanese alphabet Katakana, as it says it the name.
There are some Hiragana words in the game, but it's all translated into English/Romanji, 
so you don't necessarily need to know Hiragana, but i would highly recommend that you play part 1 nontheless,
this is a sequel afterall, it will teach you Hiragana, some basic grammar, and they don't cost that much.

They even added voice acting, it's not really ''Troy Baker'' quality, but it does it's job ^^
They improved the UI and the Answer window, it's easier to navigate and find your answers.
They added Steam Achievments, which is always a plus.

As i said, it's pretty much an upgrade from Part 1, the Hiragana Battle c:

author: {'steamid': '76561198138305945', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1697962861}
review: Great game for learning Japanese. I highly recommend to buy the bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974998697', 'num_games_owned': 575, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1674328622}
review:
[u]Katakana Warriors was easily the best game in the series. Why? Because it made learning Katakana easy and fun![/u]

[b]DISCLAIMER:[/b] I played this entire game on my phone using JoiPlay so my hours don't match: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=cyou.joiplay.joiplay&hl=en_US&gl=US

Katakana is such a great game that I was able to learn Katakana fluently in 1 month in real time, 24 hours in game time. Comparatively, it took me from 2021 October to 2022 May to beat Hiragana Battle with the same amount of in-game time, 24 hours. Why such a long difference? Because Hiragana Battle was not engaging, it was clunky, and it felt really outdated just 5 years after release.

Here are the five things that make Katakana Warriors a great game:

1. [b]Hiragana Heartburn[/b]
Virtually all of the issues I detailed in my Hiragana review are fixed. It's easier to select Katakana characters, the characters play the sound when they attack, etc. https://steamcommunity.com/id/patpeter/recommended/438270?snr=1_5_9__402

2. [b]The characters Were Great[/b]
Each character is truly individual, changing class as you level each one up, unlike Hiragana Warriors where each individual character did not have their own personalities really. You actually become invested in each character. Kyoko is like Rei Ayanami, you can't help but root for her to come out of her shell. The characters spurred me on to complete the game.

3. [b]Voice Acting is Good[/b]
I can't remember cringing at any of the voice actors, so I'm giving this game an A for voice acting. The only thing I do remember is that there are parts where it will be voice-acted, the next few lines aren't voice acted, and then it goes back to voice acting. That took me out of the immersion of the game, but did not happen often as I recall.

4. [b]Combat: Fighting and Turn Order[/b]
The combat is much better in this game than Hiragana Warriors, as mentioned. Fights actually feel real, like the enemies are dynamic and their attacks are dynamic. All of the stats for your characters make sense. The game shows the turn order for each character/obake in the top right of combat. In Kanji Combat, it doesn't show turn order and the stats make no sense because each kanji is an instant-kill.

5. [b]Quests are Very Educational and Logged[/b]
Katakana Warriors has educational quests that help to learn Japanese grammar such as verbs and adjectives beyond just katakana words (Hiragana warriors basically just focused on words) and a quest log that allows players to see what each quest was about (each quest has a theme).

Of all these games I would suggest playing Katakana Warriors first and then learning Hiragana elsewhere, or just memorize Hiragana through rote memorization and then play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198836356450', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1091, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1019, 'last_played': 1675291252}

review: I think the gaming side of this game is the best out of the three(hiragana,katakana,kanji) games.  Oh and I have know idea what the story was or the characters names. If you just want to focus on the learning you can just hold down the left mouse button and it was zoom by and you can get back to playing/learning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198321870839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1673134956}
review:
This is definitely a game.

There are substantial improvements over the first game in the series. 

The fighting mechanics were very improved, no longer as basic as the first game (though still pretty similar to it). In this one you actually see the enemies before they attack you (it's substantially less annoying/tiresome).

The gears, shops, missions and et cetera were more filled out (and more abundant).

The story was not really improved upon, however there were several more characters (and playable characters at that) which added to it.

I actually liked the soundtrack from the first game better. This one was clearly a bit higher production, but most of the tracks from the first one were better (at least to my musical taste). However, the new tracks seemed to not be repeated as much and never got to the point where any of them bothered me (which is an improvement).

The writing was... astounding. In my review of the first game I said it was a masterpiece of an 'ironic drama' because it made me cringe so hard that it was funny. This one took it even further. It blew past the funny side of cringe right around back to the deeply painful side. I was in physical pain every time there was a cut-scene. It takes real writing ability to make something so cringe inducing. Whoever wrote this is clearly a connoisseur and master of cringe. This is the work of a genius. In terms of pure torment, the pain conveyed is equivalent to the tragedies of Shakespeare (albeit a completely different kind of pain).
After praising the writing so much... I hate to bring it up... but there is a typo in the sequence after the last boss (of all places). 

All in all, this is an okay game (better than the first for sure), and a great learning tool (about equal to the first game).

Arigatou gozaimasu!

author: {'steamid': '76561198869979657', 'num_games_owned': 73, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1677887625}
review: Actually a fun way of learning Katakana.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977431487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1677095786}
review: I and the game both highly recommend a pad for taking notes. You will want to take notes at the very beginning. If you have the option, I recommend playing Hiragana Battle first, but it isn't mandatory. My perspective is coming from having completed Hiragana Battle, this is the second game I've started, and I haven't touched the kanji game yet. Notes are not overwhelming, I'm using the same journal for the second game as I did for the first. The whole first game only filled 12 pages of notes for me and that includes not skipping any side quests. This game seems to have more features in it compared to Hiragana Battle which has so far only increased the fun. The game is effective at keeping a high level of entertainment while still drilling in the concepts being learned. I always feel like coming back to it. There is more taught than just Katakana including vocabulary and some Hiragana words. One major notable difference in this game from Hiragana Battle is the encounters, unlike the random encounters of Hiragana Battle, this game features 'monsters' than can be seen roaming in the world allowing for the option to avoid encounters until you are ready. These 'monsters' also respawn when you come back to an area so you don't have to worry about limited encounters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198250218604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1708412528}
review: AMAZING I learned katakana PERFECTLY with this game, and the fact they swap into english characters half way through to really test your knowledge is truly amazing game design. Not so much a fan of the datin-sim aspect but over-all love the series!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001802717', 'num_games_owned': 341, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1661980970}
review: I will say that I admire the dedication Sleepy Duck put into this series of games. I cannot, however, recommend using the game as anything more than a distraction while learning, though. The pacing is just far too slow for what I'd consider the most basic and simple part of learning Japanese - reading the characters. I would LOVE to see this game translated into a style that more fits a speedy flashcard-style game. If they made a hiragana/katakana/kanji game that was reminiscent of "Typing of the Dead", I'd buy the heck out of it. I want to be learning and having fun, but at a rapid pace that doesn't take hours of my time to get anywhere! Once I learn the characters, I need to be able to work on my speed and accuracy. That's something these games don't offer. Sleepy Duck! Please!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198825856941', 'num_games_owned': 77, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1673089716}
review:
Super recommendable just like the first title. This one is more advanced and it is visible that they were able to put in more efforts (maybe more funds or people working on it). God bless RPG maker for enabling the most basic functions and for them to be costumized by other game makers. You have a little bit of character costumization and you can chose from multiple characters to join your team (Daisuke, Owen and Charlotte won't leave my team). Some parts are voice acted which is super cute and not gonna lie, some music slaps. Not sure if it is made by the makers or implemented from RPG maker.

Sadly I have a problem with the controls. You can switch between wasd-controls or arrow keys (or you can create your own costum layout). On my PC however the game failed to utilize the wasd layout for some reason. The log file also said that there is an error regarding the key-layout change.

EDIT: Now after finishing the game and having +45 hours in it (I farmed some), I gotta say that a domain in which you have to use the vocab that Daisuke slapped you with, would have been a good addition like in the first game (Hiragana Battle). Other than that the writing continued on being corny and selfaware at some parts which I love.

author: {'steamid': '76561199024165500', 'num_games_owned': 554, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1665215108}
review:
전작 히라가나편 보다는 훨씬 낫다 게임 썸네일을 보고 혹시 아예 장르를 바꿨나 기대도 했는데 그건 아니고 여전히 쯔꾸르기는 하다 그래도 조금 퀄리티 있는 쯔꾸르처럼 CG와 컷씬들이 많이 들어가서 더욱 풍성해 보인다 

전작에도 마우스를 이용한 이동성이 좋다고 했는데 우클릭을 통한 컨트롤들을 많이 추가해서 조작성이 더욱 좋아졌다

 또한 랜덤 인카운터가 흔히 쯔꾸르에서 쓰는 방식이기는 했으나 전작에서 혹평한 것 같이 전투와 학습을 합치려다 보니 워낙 전투가 별로라 꺼려지는 부분이 있어서 마주치는 것 자체가 스트레스를 주었는데

이번작에서는 그래도 미리 적이 다가오는 걸 보고 마주치는 걸 내가 고를 수 있어서 좋다 그러나 전작보다 스테이지 진행 상 X마리 토벌 등 제약이 더욱 강화되어 그런 단점이 있는 전투를 꽤 많은 양으로 수행해야 해서 여전히 스트레스가 있다

그래도 전투 시스템 역시 개선 되어 답을 할 때 선지가 아니라 바로 적을 클릭해서 선택하거나 턴 순서를 시각적으로 제공해서 턴 계산을 하는 전략적 요소 등 조금 더 게임 냄새가 나게 만들어져서 할만 한 듯 하다

author: {'steamid': '76561198061737345', 'num_games_owned': 788, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1664421923}
review:
[h1]Finally, I can wipe the stupid smile off ツ's face[/h1]
I've been living in Japan for 3 years now, learning the language as I go. Arriving with zero, I've slowly built up a basic understanding by means of textbooks, broken conversations and language-learning applications, of which this is one.

I'm embarrassed to say that, in spite of my growing proficiency, there were still some fundamentals which I was struggling to hammer into my caveman brain. My knowledge of katakana, a writing system which I had glanced over within my first weeks in Japan, had since been left unrefined, and I would often blank on the readings of certain, less frequently appearing characters, such as メ(め) and ヌ(ぬ). 

Cue [i]Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana War[/i], an educational [b]RPG Maker[/b] adventure, set in Japan. I think it's worth assessing it through the lenses of two seperate paradigms, first as a game, and second as an educational tool.

[b]A S / A  / G A M E[/b]

As a game, Katakana War certainly provides a decent chunk of story, though it's nothing particularly special. お化け(ghosts) have appeared throughout Japan in hordes, taking the form of Katakana. These spirits can only be vanquished if a human speaks their reading. This seems like it would be of little effort for native Japanese speakers to solve, but maybe the ghosts appear as difficult English words to them or something, I dunno. For plot convenience, you and a group of foreign-exchange students are the only ones who can quell the menacing apparitions.

The turn-based combat is very straightforward.  The moment-to-moment gameplay isn't exactly riveting by itself. You mostly wander through a relatively barren map and encounter battles along the way, which function roughly as pop quizzes, but with lethal consequences for failure.

Side-quests are unchallenging time-wasters, where you're typically sent somewhere to get a thing and return. At least you're given some very rudimentary vocabulary and verb conjugations as a reward for completing such tasks, but it feels like a missed opportunity to not use the information you've already been learning for side-quests. For instance, if we were asked to find a cola, there could be a specific vending machine out there somewhere with 'コーラ' written on it in katakana, so as to test your reading comprehension a little. We're instead left with a smattering of mundane fetch quests that do little to justify their existence, save for the reward at the end (disregarding a couple of quests, which actually ask you to source specific items using your katakana knowledge, I just wish more missions had been formatted this way).

The banter between the characters wasn't really for me, and I didn't find myself particularly invested in the plight of anyone. The dialogue felt like dialogue, rather than real people having genuine interactions. This wasn't helped by the fact that all the characters illustrations only have a single pose to work with, a piercing, beaming grin. When at one point the charismatic crew narrowly avoided death by explosion, they were still unnervingly grinning from ear to ear, all the while expressing supposedly genuine concern that the incident had nearly taken their lives. One or two pose variations would have gone a long way towards making the characters more expressive and relatable.

There are optimization issues, which is strange to say about a game as undemanding as this, but there were moments of genuine slowdown, especially when particle effects were on screen. 

[b]F O R  /  L E A R N I N G[/b]

For learning, Katakana wars isn't half bad. It takes on a 'drilling' sort of teaching style, but does it in a unique way.

Katakana is one of three writing systems used in Japanese, the other two being hiragana (ひらがな) and kanji (漢字). It's worth noting that [i]Sleepy Duck[/i] - the developers of this title - also have similar games based upon the other two writing systems.

There are 48 characters in Katakana, but this is excluding accents, which change the reading (for instance カ=ka, but with an accent ガ=ga).
Learning all the characters would easily be possible with independent study in a couple of days, using interval-based revision, but obviously Katakana Wars has advantages to its unique presentation and framing of information. Revising doesn't feel nearly as tiresome when framed as a game, and it almost legitimizes drilling as a method for teaching.

The opportunity to face シ(し) and ツ(つ) on the battlefield was long overdue, and after several hours of drilling, it feels good to finally be able to consistently distinguish between the two. 

Unfortunately, as the game goes on and the novelty wears off, it becomes more of a drilling exercise than a game, but the medium at least allows you to forget that you're technically studying for a while.

[b]To summarize[/b], Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana War is effective at teaching what it's trying to teach. Although perhaps a little convoluted as a learning methodology, it alleviates the mundanity of typical flashcard based study.

As a game it's pretty bad, and I wouldn't recommend it, but as a learning resource for absolute beginners, it might have a place. If you already know katakana and/or N4/N5 Japanese, skip this one. If you're just getting started with your learning journey, this could be worth giving a go.

5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198044732922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 774, 'last_played': 1663827939}
review: I took 4 semesters of Japanese in college, additionally I'm a speaker of Mandarin so Hiragana and Kanji were super easy for me. However, even after two years of study Katakana has always been a struggle. Especially the (Shi vs Tsu, Ji vs Du, and So vs N) since they look very similar. This game was a godsend. It was a bit of a grind but now I'm confident in my ability to read Katakana, though I still need time to figure out what the words mean lol. 8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198008670124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1655669163}
review:
Unlearn English to survive !

Le jeu est vraiment sympa, un peu moins engageant sur le vocabulaire que les hiraganas à mon sens.
De nouvelles fonctionnalités pour casser un peu l'austérité du précédent opus.

PRO TIP : Appuyer sur la touche 'W' permet de passer les dialogues à grande vitesse sans faire 100 clics / minutes.

Je recommande ce jeu pour commencer ou continuer le japonais. Si vous connaissez les hiraganas vous aurez quelques mots de vocabulaire en plus dans ce jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561199042657548', 'num_games_owned': 615, 'num_reviews': 281, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1654079215}
review:
𝐈𝐧𝐭𝐫𝐨𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧:

𝙰 𝚕𝚘𝚗𝚐 𝚝𝚒𝚖𝚎 𝚊𝚐𝚘, 𝙸 𝚠𝚊𝚜 𝚎𝚊𝚐𝚎𝚛 𝚝𝚘 𝚕𝚎𝚊𝚛𝚗 𝙹𝚊𝚙𝚊𝚗𝚎𝚜𝚎, 𝚋𝚞𝚝 𝙸 𝚜𝚝𝚒𝚕𝚕 𝚍𝚒𝚍𝚗'𝚝 𝚔𝚗𝚘𝚠 𝚠𝚑𝚎𝚛𝚎 𝚝𝚘 𝚜𝚝𝚊𝚛𝚝. 𝙾𝚗𝚎 𝚍𝚊𝚢 𝙸 𝚌𝚊𝚖𝚎 𝚊𝚌𝚛𝚘𝚜𝚜 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝟷𝚜𝚝 𝚙𝚊𝚛𝚝 𝚘𝚏 𝚝𝚑𝚒𝚜 𝚜𝚎𝚛𝚒𝚎𝚜 𝙻𝚎𝚊𝚛𝚗 𝙹𝚊𝚙𝚊𝚗𝚎𝚜𝚎 𝚃𝚘 𝚂𝚞𝚛𝚟𝚒𝚟𝚎! 𝙷𝚒𝚛𝚊𝚐𝚊𝚗𝚊 𝙱𝚊𝚝𝚝𝚕𝚎. 𝙸 𝚋𝚘𝚞𝚐𝚑𝚝 𝚒𝚝 𝚊𝚗𝚍 𝚋𝚢 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚎𝚗𝚍 𝚘𝚏 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚙𝚊𝚜𝚜𝚊𝚐𝚎 𝙸 𝚊𝚕𝚛𝚎𝚊𝚍𝚢 𝚔𝚗𝚎𝚠 𝟾𝟻-𝟿𝟶% 𝚘𝚏 𝙷𝚒𝚛𝚊𝚐𝚊𝚗𝚊. 𝙰𝚏𝚝𝚎𝚛 𝚊 𝚠𝚑𝚒𝚕𝚎, 𝚊𝚏𝚝𝚎𝚛 𝚜𝚎𝚎𝚒𝚗𝚐 𝚝𝚑𝚒𝚜 𝚐𝚊𝚖𝚎 𝚘𝚗 𝚜𝚊𝚕𝚎, 𝙸 𝚋𝚘𝚞𝚐𝚑𝚝 𝚒𝚝. 𝙱𝚞𝚝 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚑𝚊𝚗𝚍𝚜 𝚛𝚎𝚊𝚌𝚑𝚎𝚍 𝚑𝚎𝚛 𝚘𝚗𝚕𝚢 𝚗𝚘𝚠.

𝐆𝐚𝐦𝐞𝐩𝐥𝐚𝐲:

𝚃𝚑𝚎 𝚐𝚊𝚖𝚎 𝚒𝚜 𝚊 𝙹𝚁𝙿𝙶 𝚊𝚗𝚍 𝚒𝚜 𝚌𝚘𝚖𝚙𝚕𝚎𝚝𝚎𝚕𝚢 𝚋𝚊𝚜𝚎𝚍 𝚘𝚗 𝚕𝚎𝚊𝚛𝚗𝚒𝚗𝚐. 𝚃𝚑𝚎 𝚎𝚖𝚙𝚑𝚊𝚜𝚒𝚜 𝚒𝚜 𝚖𝚊𝚒𝚗𝚕𝚢 𝚘𝚗 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚜𝚝𝚞𝚍𝚢 𝚘𝚏 𝙺𝚊𝚝𝚊𝚔𝚊𝚗𝚊 (𝙹𝚊𝚙𝚊𝚗𝚎𝚜𝚎 𝚜𝚢𝚕𝚕𝚊𝚋𝚒𝚌 𝚊𝚕𝚙𝚑𝚊𝚋𝚎𝚝 𝚞𝚜𝚎𝚍 𝚝𝚘 𝚠𝚛𝚒𝚝𝚎 𝚏𝚘𝚛𝚎𝚒𝚐𝚗 𝚠𝚘𝚛𝚍𝚜), 𝚊𝚕𝚜𝚘 𝚍𝚞𝚛𝚒𝚗𝚐 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚐𝚊𝚖𝚎 𝚢𝚘𝚞 𝚠𝚒𝚕𝚕 𝚋𝚎 𝚝𝚊𝚞𝚐𝚑𝚝 𝚊 𝚕𝚒𝚝𝚝𝚕𝚎 𝚐𝚛𝚊𝚖𝚖𝚊𝚛 𝚊𝚗𝚍 𝚛𝚎𝚙𝚕𝚎𝚗𝚒𝚜𝚑 𝚢𝚘𝚞𝚛 𝚟𝚘𝚌𝚊𝚋𝚞𝚕𝚊𝚛𝚢.

𝙰𝚗𝚍 𝚜𝚘, 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚐𝚘𝚊𝚕 𝚒𝚜 𝚌𝚕𝚎𝚊𝚛, 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚙𝚊𝚛𝚝𝚢 𝚒𝚜 𝚊𝚜𝚜𝚎𝚖𝚋𝚕𝚎𝚍, 𝚠𝚑𝚊𝚝'𝚜 𝚗𝚎𝚡𝚝? 𝙰𝚗𝚍 𝚝𝚑𝚎𝚗 𝚏𝚘𝚛 𝟷𝟶 𝚖𝚊𝚒𝚗 𝚕𝚎𝚜𝚜𝚘𝚗𝚜 (𝚗𝚘𝚝 𝚌𝚘𝚞𝚗𝚝𝚒𝚗𝚐 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚜𝚒𝚍𝚎 𝟸𝟶 𝚖𝚒𝚗𝚒-𝚕𝚎𝚜𝚜𝚘𝚗𝚜 (𝚚𝚞𝚎𝚜𝚝𝚜)) 𝚠𝚑𝚒𝚌𝚑 𝚠𝚒𝚕𝚕 𝚋𝚎 𝚒𝚗 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚌𝚘𝚞𝚛𝚜𝚎 𝚘𝚏 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚐𝚊𝚖𝚎, 𝚢𝚘𝚞 𝚠𝚒𝚕𝚕 𝚋𝚎 𝚌𝚑𝚊𝚜𝚎𝚍 𝚊𝚕𝚕 𝚘𝚟𝚎𝚛 𝙺𝚊𝚝𝚊𝚔𝚊𝚗𝚊.
𝙰𝚗𝚍 𝚗𝚘𝚠 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝟷𝚜𝚝 𝚕𝚎𝚜𝚜𝚘𝚗 𝚒𝚜 𝚌𝚘𝚖𝚙𝚕𝚎𝚝𝚎𝚍, 𝚗𝚘𝚠 𝚢𝚘𝚞 𝚌𝚊𝚗 𝚐𝚘 𝚒𝚗𝚝𝚘 𝚋𝚊𝚝𝚝𝚕𝚎! 𝚈𝚘𝚞 𝚍𝚎𝚏𝚎𝚊𝚝 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚒𝚗𝚟𝚊𝚍𝚎𝚛𝚜 𝚠𝚒𝚝𝚑 𝚢𝚘𝚞𝚛 𝚔𝚗𝚘𝚠𝚕𝚎𝚍𝚐𝚎, 𝚊𝚗𝚍 𝚠𝚒𝚝𝚑 𝚎𝚊𝚌𝚑 𝚗𝚎𝚠 𝚕𝚎𝚜𝚜𝚘𝚗 𝚢𝚘𝚞 𝚏𝚛𝚎𝚎 𝚞𝚙 𝚗𝚎𝚠 𝚊𝚛𝚎𝚊𝚜. 𝙰𝚕𝚜𝚘, 𝚍𝚘 𝚗𝚘𝚝 𝚏𝚘𝚛𝚐𝚎𝚝 𝚝𝚘 𝚕𝚘𝚘𝚔 𝚒𝚗𝚝𝚘 𝚟𝚊𝚛𝚒𝚘𝚞𝚜 𝚜𝚑𝚘𝚙𝚜 𝚠𝚑𝚎𝚛𝚎 𝚠𝚎𝚊𝚙𝚘𝚗𝚜 𝚊𝚗𝚍 𝚜𝚞𝚙𝚙𝚕𝚒𝚎𝚜 𝚊𝚛𝚎 𝚜𝚘𝚕𝚍.
𝙿.𝚂 𝚎𝚊𝚌𝚑 𝚘𝚏 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚌𝚑𝚊𝚛𝚊𝚌𝚝𝚎𝚛𝚜 𝚑𝚊𝚜 𝚊 𝚜𝚌𝚊𝚕𝚎 𝚘𝚏 "𝚊𝚏𝚏𝚎𝚌𝚝𝚒𝚘𝚗", 𝚒𝚝 𝚠𝚒𝚕𝚕 𝚒𝚗𝚌𝚛𝚎𝚊𝚜𝚎 𝚘𝚗𝚕𝚢 𝚏𝚘𝚛 𝚝𝚑𝚘𝚜𝚎 𝚠𝚑𝚘 𝚏𝚒𝚐𝚑𝚝 𝚠𝚒𝚝𝚑 𝚢𝚘𝚞 𝚒𝚗 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚙𝚊𝚛𝚝𝚢, 𝚠𝚑𝚎𝚗 𝚒𝚝 𝚒𝚗𝚌𝚛𝚎𝚊𝚜𝚎𝚜, 𝚖𝚒𝚗𝚒-𝚍𝚒𝚊𝚕𝚘𝚐𝚞𝚎𝚜 𝚠𝚒𝚝𝚑 𝚎𝚊𝚌𝚑 𝚘𝚏 𝚝𝚑𝚎𝚖 𝚠𝚒𝚕𝚕 𝚘𝚙𝚎𝚗, 𝚊𝚝 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚎𝚗𝚍 𝚘𝚏 𝚎𝚊𝚌𝚑 𝚘𝚏 𝚠𝚑𝚒𝚌𝚑 𝚢𝚘𝚞 𝚠𝚒𝚕𝚕 𝚑𝚊𝚟𝚎 𝚝𝚘 𝚌𝚑𝚘𝚘𝚜𝚎 𝟷 𝚘𝚏 𝟹 𝚊𝚗𝚜𝚠𝚎𝚛𝚜, 𝚠𝚒𝚝𝚑 𝚊 𝚜𝚞𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚜𝚜𝚏𝚞𝚕 𝚊𝚗𝚜𝚠𝚎𝚛, 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚌𝚑𝚊𝚛𝚊𝚌𝚝𝚎𝚛 𝚠𝚒𝚕𝚕 𝚐𝚎𝚝 𝚔 𝚌𝚑𝚊𝚛𝚊𝚌𝚝𝚎𝚛𝚒𝚜𝚝𝚒𝚌𝚜, 𝚊𝚗𝚍 𝚊𝚜 𝚜𝚘𝚘𝚗 𝚊𝚜 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚊𝚝𝚝𝚊𝚌𝚑𝚖𝚎𝚗𝚝 𝚜𝚌𝚊𝚕𝚎 𝚛𝚎𝚊𝚌𝚑𝚎𝚜 𝚒𝚝𝚜 𝚖𝚊𝚡𝚒𝚖𝚞𝚖, 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚌𝚑𝚊𝚛𝚊𝚌𝚝𝚎𝚛 𝚠𝚒𝚕𝚕 𝚛𝚎𝚌𝚎𝚒𝚟𝚎 𝚊 𝚞𝚗𝚒𝚚𝚞𝚎, 𝚞𝚕𝚝𝚒𝚖𝚊𝚝𝚎 𝚊𝚋𝚒𝚕𝚒𝚝𝚢 𝚝𝚑𝚊𝚝 𝚌𝚊𝚗 𝚋𝚎 𝚞𝚜𝚎𝚍 𝟷 𝚝𝚒𝚖𝚎 𝚙𝚎𝚛 𝚋𝚊𝚝𝚝𝚕𝚎.

𝐓𝐞𝐜𝐡𝐧𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐥 𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐭:

𝚁𝚞𝚜𝚜𝚒𝚊𝚗 𝚁𝚞𝚜𝚜𝚒𝚊𝚗 𝚟𝚘𝚒𝚌𝚎 𝚊𝚌𝚝𝚒𝚗𝚐 𝚒𝚜 𝚙𝚛𝚎𝚜𝚎𝚗𝚝 𝚏𝚘𝚛 𝚒𝚖𝚙𝚘𝚛𝚝𝚊𝚗𝚝 𝚍𝚒𝚊𝚕𝚘𝚐𝚞𝚎𝚜, 𝙸 𝚠𝚊𝚜 𝚍𝚒𝚜𝚊𝚙𝚙𝚘𝚒𝚗𝚝𝚎𝚍 𝚝𝚑𝚊𝚝 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚁𝚞𝚜𝚜𝚒𝚊𝚗 𝚌𝚑𝚊𝚛𝚊𝚌𝚝𝚎𝚛 𝚍𝚒𝚍 𝚗𝚘𝚝 𝚑𝚊𝚟𝚎 𝚊 "𝚁𝚞𝚜𝚜𝚒𝚊𝚗" 𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚗𝚝 𝚊𝚕𝚊 "𝙻𝚎𝚝 𝚙𝚒 𝚜𝚙𝚎𝚔𝚎 𝚏𝚛𝚘𝚖𝚎 𝚖𝚊𝚢 𝙷𝚊𝚛𝚝", 𝚋𝚞𝚝 𝚝𝚑𝚒𝚜 𝚒𝚜 𝚙𝚞𝚛𝚎𝚕𝚢 𝚖𝚢 𝚚𝚞𝚒𝚋𝚋𝚕𝚎𝚜.

𝙸 𝚊𝚍𝚟𝚒𝚜𝚎 𝚢𝚘𝚞 𝚝𝚘 𝚐𝚘 𝚝𝚑𝚛𝚘𝚞𝚐𝚑 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝟷𝚜𝚝 𝚙𝚊𝚛𝚝 𝚘𝚏 𝚝𝚑𝚒𝚜 𝚜𝚎𝚛𝚒𝚎𝚜 𝙻𝚎𝚊𝚛𝚗 𝙹𝚊𝚙𝚊𝚗𝚎𝚜𝚎 𝚃𝚘 𝚂𝚞𝚛𝚟𝚒𝚟𝚎! 𝙷𝚒𝚛𝚊𝚐𝚊𝚗𝚊 𝙱𝚊𝚝𝚝𝚕𝚎, 𝙸 𝚝𝚑𝚒𝚗𝚔 𝙸 𝚠𝚒𝚕𝚕 𝚙𝚊𝚜𝚜 𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚝𝚑𝚒𝚛𝚍 𝚙𝚊𝚛𝚝 𝚘𝚏 𝙻𝚎𝚊𝚛𝚗 𝙹𝚊𝚙𝚊𝚗𝚎𝚜𝚎 𝚃𝚘 𝚂𝚞𝚛𝚟𝚒𝚟𝚎! review:
3 minutes in and all you'll hear is the most shitty, cringy, off-accent voice overs in your goddamn life and if you try to disable them, you'll mute 80% of the other sound effects.

There's a fix made by users but while you try and do that you might as well just go to the nearest library and buy a japanese learning book and start already. Not worthy.

review: Soy fan de los juegos de Learn Japanese to Survive. No solo aprendes escritura sino que te adentran un poco a la cultura japonesa y te enseñan vocabulario a través de las misiones secundarias. La historia es un poco loca pero es divertida y los personajes tienen distintas personalidades. Creo que son buenos para aprender escritura si lo acompañas con trabajo en papel y anotaciones tuyas. Personalmente, ya me sé los silabarios así que los juego para disfrutar de la experiencia, la diversión y la tranquilidad que me dan estos juegos :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198012050231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1647846629}
review:
The GUI has improved a little from Hiragana Battle and some new gameplay elements have been added to make it feel a bit more like a game than a lecture. The side quests aren't as educational as they could be as you usually only get new vocabulary as a reward rather than it being the actual task at hand.

Like with Hiragana Battle, this game will get you reading and writing the characters in no time! If you can spot this game (or the whole trilogy) on sale for pocket change, go for it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198056385859', 'num_games_owned': 161, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1664391859}
review:
Yes but please, get hiragana first. Follow the order, get a notebook and you'll do great. 
Actually for this second one is noticeable that the devs gave a lot of effort on creating it, it's great and I did stream of it a few hours ago. I LOVE how they managed with a RPG of learning a language. You rock, guys!!
I will continue "playing" it and then Kanji. It's a great way to learn a language like Japanese.
If you like RPG games this would be great, no excuses to learn katakana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070430902', 'num_games_owned': 988, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 930, 'last_played': 1647222875}
review:
First impression? (and the thought is still on, after the game)
I think that there is too much voice acting. I'm not saying that's bad or good - just the thing that the input could be put somewhere else.

Overall - developers did improve the gameplay itself - they brought better mechanics and solutions (especially, that's quite faster and skill menu is more readable) - but enemies have more HP what's quite a nonsense for me. If you know the answer and enemies are fairly easy (it's not like you give bad answer and die in two hits)... why would you prolong that "test"?

Plot is nice, characters are nice - but I have a question. Why can't you do a (let's say...) "bromance" team? Here are only two male companions. When forming male-only or (let's call it that way) "reverse-harem" team, you cannot really do that without having a handicap of empty slot in your team.

Last talk with one of the companions is... "laggy". Game stops working smoothly - text doesn't show up, just like the scene struggles with loading.
^ Just like in every RPG - save before talking with companions (just in case). Waiting is advisable - game should slowly unfreeze after a while. If you want a smooth animation - after finishing the whole dialogue, you may save on the new slot and reload the previous save - it should be working fine then.

Learning:
There still is lack of reliable revision/repetition segment where you can go and repeat what you've learnt (challenge me game, hmmm?). Instead we've got "reversed learning" site (finding character to written syllable), which wasn't available at all in Hiragana Battle - but don't be too enthusiastic - you cannot gain experience points from it.
I feel that side quests are made nonchalantly - メープル ケーキ (maple cake)- was it hard to put it in the quest? 

Still relying on 1 to 5 scale.
3,5/5 - I would say.
There is minor improvement (quality of life I would say) to the previous methods and game is really well done visually, but the methodology itself is not efficient enough (and still the same).
Completing every lesson took around 11 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046909876', 'num_games_owned': 648, 'num_reviews': 176, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1644791551}
review:
Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana War improves on one of the biggest issues I had with in their first game (Hiragana War). Game play now goes turn by turn, rather than queuing everyone up. This is a major improvement, since you don't end up wasting a turn trying to hit something that's already been killed. 

The game graphics and music are both much improved over the original, with the visual novel style working well for laying out the story. The story lines with each of the characters in the party is a nice touch as well. 

Unlike the first game, this game only uses katakana for words that would typically use katakana (except, perhaps for Daisuke's name, since it would probably be written in kanji or hiragana). The vocabulary words present you with 5 katakana words, and 5 hiragana words in each vocabulary lesson.

In the first one, they did give you a bit more testing on the vocabulary words. This one only gives you about 3 mini-tests; one vocab-to-katakana word at the end battle, and a two quests where you have to buy items at the store. 

Overall, a really good game for someone new to katakana. I find them harder to wrap my head around than hiragana, since you see them less frequently overall, especially while starting out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028537460', 'num_games_owned': 67, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 920, 'last_played': 1642961141}
review: O jogo pode até estar melhor nos gráficos em relação ao seu antecessor mas perde o seu foco principal que era ensinar japonês (um dos alfabetos). O jogo incluiu coisas fúteis e sem sentido como o nível de afeto com os personagens que você usa nas batalhas e que só faz você perder tempo com um monte de falas e cenas que não mudam absolutamente nada e itens que você compra e não usa pra nada também. Foi adicionado também a opção de usar magia em batalha e que causa dano nos inimigos (caracteres japoneses) sem você saber qual carácter é (uma opção que não serve para nada no requisito de te ensinar alguma coisa).

author: {'steamid': '76561198146551641', 'num_games_owned': 333, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1642101721}
review:
Muy bueno, mejor que el primero (el de Hiragana) en muchos aspectos!
Primero que nada, en lo que a aprender japones respecta, es una buena herramienta para conocer el Katakana. Esta bien ordenado, bien explicado y super completo, me sirvio muy bien como completo a mi estudio del Katakana.

En cuanto al juego: Todo el sistema de batallas es ampliamente mas dinamico.
En general se hace mas rapida la experiencia de juego, ya que uno no se pierde en las misiones y es todo mas llevadero. Tambien me gusta que se pueden esquivar enemigos y no estas obligado a pelear siempre al azar como en el juego anterior.
Tambien me gusto que se interactua un poco mas con los personajes y se puede elegir con quien jugar.
Vale la pena jugarlo si te interesa aprender japones de manera llevadera

Not a bad way for learning Japanese, but there are just other ways that are even faster if you are trying to learn asap.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190380543', 'num_games_owned': 613, 'num_reviews': 603, 'playtime_forever': 976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 976, 'last_played': 1637430297}
review:
This is the second entry in the Learn Japanese To Survive trilogy, a series of games designed to assist players in learning the 3 Japanese writing systems: Hiragana, Katakana and Kanji. The middle title is dedicated to Katakana, the writing system used for words of foreign origin. It’s the natural system to learn after Hiragana, since it shares a lot of elements. For the most part, it’s just different characters for the same syllables.
Once again, it’s alright as an educational tool, but isn’t enough by itself. It guides the player in using a notebook for writing the characters and corresponding romaji, while gradually introducing the characters in lessons spread throughout the game chapters. It teaches you how to write them, and the sound associated with them. Thing is, you’ll probably look at the notes a lot, which doesn’t help much with memorizing. For effective learning, you need other tools and find your own learning pace, but I suppose the game is limited in what it can do. It does what it can. It also teaches you some vocabulary and other rules, but they’re even worse because they’re never used in-game, they’re just exposition.
As a game, it’s still an RPG-maker title, but fortunately, it’s leagues above Hiragana Battle, which felt very generic and uninspired. Here, it actually feels like a proper game, and everything from the first game got revamped for the better. The combat follows the same principle of needing to answer with the correct romaji that matches the enemy Katakana character. It’s still a bit repetitive, but it helps you memorize through repetition. Sometimes it will reverse the matching, and there’s no word matching on the final dungeon this time, which is a bit disappointing. It was annoying in the first game, but at least it felt like a proper way to escalate the difficulty for the final level.
Fortunately, no more annoying random encounters everywhere! All enemies are visible on the map, so you know when to fight. It makes exploring dungeons more enjoyable. Magic and items are more useful as well, especially towards the end of the game. There’re AOE magic attacks, more focus on speed, more status effects (some even persist after battle), and even ultimate attacks! It’s not a lazy afterthought and adds much needed variety to combat.
Another big improvement is the story and presentation. There’s a lot of focus on your party members, with plenty of interactions and character development. There’s even voice acting and an affection mechanic where you bond with the characters you use the most. They’re also varied and enjoyable. The main plot is weaker, but it focuses on the characters. Each represent a different class as well, although some as better than others. The story is also slightly bigger.
Some stuff, like dungeons, loot, and side quests, still feel generic and uninspired. But there’re plenty of small improvements everywhere, like a better soundtrack and combat interface (selecting an answer is now neatly organized). There’re even achievements this time around!
Don’t get me wrong, the game isn’t amazing, because as an educational tool it suffers from the same issues Hiragana Battle did. As a game, it’s nothing special either, but a massive improvement over the first game. It made me appreciate the sequel more. And since Katakana is a separate system (and easier to write as well), you don’t need to play the first game to enjoy Katakana War. For this game I can actually give it a positive review and recommend it for what it is. It’s nothing special, but it’s good in its own right. Props to the devs for fixing the first game in the sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047160036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 790, 'last_played': 1632923102}
review:
I played previous version Hiragana Wara but stopped playing it cause grinding was tideous and it felt not that fun to play. But this game is great. I could see that the Devs definetly improved and improved a lot of things that wernt that great.

Lessons: You got a total of 10 lessons were you learn 5 words at the start and in the last 2 lessons only 3 including the Dakuten. Also you get taught a few vocabulary sometimes too.

Side Quests: There is a total of 20 Sidequests in a lot of places easy find ith the ! above them. You get Vocabulary and items from them.

Obake: The enemies you fight. Compared to Hiragana (I only played a few hours) you got the switches between the characters and the Romanji (English letters) which is nice and helped me learn them even better. (Was one of the bad things in the first game)

Battles: The battles arnt random (besides the boss monster) like in Hiragana, but are shown as characters or a ? on the map. So you dont have random encounters. Also sometimes you got a quest when entering an area like kill 6 enemies.

Characters: I looove them. Each one got a unique character and voice and the interactions in the scences are just fun and fitting. I enjoyed every one of them and how the groups friendship improved over time. 

Affection: You can have 5 hearts for each character that chose the affection they have for you. At 1, 3 and 5 hearts you got a cute interaction with the specfic character and a buff to their stats if you choose the correct answer when talkign with them.

Team: You can choose 3 of the 7 Character to join your team (You the maincharacter cant be switched out. Everyone with their own unique traits. You start with 3 and get to know the others along the storyline. I stayed with the same team combination of Daisuke Owen and Tia and only switched for raising affection of the others.

Challenge Castle: This is an unique place where you can practice all characters you learned till now (in Katakana or Romanji) with a healing spot nearby which can be killed with 1 hit. You dont get any experience or money from them so a simple place to train.

Achievments: It isnt a must have but a nice addition to the game that lets me keep easier track of my improvment. I am an Achievment hunter so this was even more rewarding for me.

Overall a great game when you want to learn Katakana and some Vocabulary. I wrote everything down an it helped me a lot learning it easier while I was learning Katakana in another course. It was fun and the only thing I would have loved to see was maybe a romance option (definetly not needed!) cause of my preference.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006408054', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 966, 'last_played': 1630360231}
review:
Let me tell you how much I hated learning games when I was actually in school. So much. They never were fun, they typically were just rote memorization and provided no clues as to how to more effectively learn. This was a loooong time ago, folks. So if all the newfangled games kids get when computers are more than the Compaqs of my day are awesome, then I'm sorry, I don't know how to express that I really enjoyed learning katakana in this game. Though, to be fair, near the end I was just spamming through the dialog because they tried a little too hard to make the game humorous. Anyways, pick this up if you want a cheap learning game that will help you learn the katakana alphabet.

So, what's the good, bad, and in-between for "Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana War"? I'm about to break that down.

Good: Learn lessons at your pace. Learn the syllables and the dakuten syllables at the same time. So much free gear and upgrades, I didn't even need to worry about money. There's a story. You can grind affection in the challenge dungeon. The game started off hilarious, imo. Andrea calls you all sorts of cute names that I absolutely loved. A game absolutely for beginners of katakana. Options to speed walk through the game. Options to remember last syllable chosen.

Bad: Game bugs out when each character besides Daisuke gets their level 5 affection special. The antagonist of the story made no sense, but sure, we'll go with it. 

In-Between: Battles are very forgiving. Learn words that might be helpful. I can't tell you when knowing how to pronounce or spell "oven" is going to be useful in life, but I sure learned it! You have to grind affection in order to get the full affection achievement. There's very little reason to actually buy upgrades as the game gives them all to you. There's very little reason to not buy upgrades, as you'll be rolling in the yen that the game gives you. The game attempts to stay humorous and doesn't quite hit the mark the further along you go. Affection earned is for being the best of friends, which sucked when Daisuke didn't want any of my male MC's D. Voice acting, you can take it or leave it.

The game could use some polish, but the system and art seem much better than their previous version "Learn Japanese to Survive! Hiragana Wars." I liked the story (sort of, the ending was...), and I'm sure it helped that I started katakana from scratch without prior learning. It was neat to learn new words from doing quests, but I think it would have been really cool to have those words worked into conversations in the game. Besides one quest, there was no real use of what I had learned of the alphabet. But, overall, I think this is a great game. I'm not sure how much mileage I'm going to get out of it now that I've finished, though you can apparently revisit any area for practice once you beat it. I guess we'll see!

author: {'steamid': '76561198056327431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 918, 'last_played': 1629086381}
review:
This game has many improvements over Hiragana War. The fighting system was changed to turn-by-turn which is a big improvement so that you party does waste attacks. Also, the katakana selection screen layout is far superior to the Hiragana War... you no longer have to keep scrolling down to find the right symbol. All the symbols are shown on the same page. Also, each time you attack you get an audio sound for the character and see the stroke order every time. I definitely recommend this game to help memorize the katakana.

One thing I don't like is that there are 2 characters that they made confusing. One is "di" and the other is "du". they call it "ji (D)" and "zu(D)". It was a little confusing until I figured it out.

Next, I understand they were trying to make the game more interactive. But, the voice acting is annoying and the story is very juvenile. I found myself just clicking through the dialog as quickly as possible. They tried to make this too much like a dating simulator. But, it is just a minor complaint that I don't hold against them for trying too hard. 

Finally, it would be nice if they provided mnemonics or pictographs for the characters to help remember them. I had another website open with katakana pictographs to help me memorize the characters.

Bottom line is that this is a fun way to practice katakana. It is slower than using flashcards, but I appreciate the fun factor. I definitely recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022046970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1187, 'last_played': 1628054160}
review: Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana War is an educational game and it fulfills its purpose of teaching katakana, one of three Japanese writing systems, to the player. The repetitive gameplay helps you memorize katakana characters easily. As this is a video game and not a dedicated learning material, you might find learning katakana elsewhere faster because of the time-consuming gameplay involved. We recommend this game to those who would like to continue learning Japanese after learning hiragana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121076993', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1588730403}
review:
7/10

Overall pretty fun for a bit...Not great but not bad.

Learning...
I already knew katakana before playing, so I may not have the most accurate account of learning from scratch. However, it does seem like it would do the job. It takes the time to give a lesson on a set of katakana. After, you have a mission in which you will have to fight katakana of the sort you learned about, as well as previously learned sets. I did find it nice that the game will teach you words and simple phrases too. This is scattered about the game in dialogue and such.

Gameplay...
It's an educational game, so it's not entirely made to be a purely entertaining and thrilling game. It's a bit clunky for sure, but I can't knock it too hard based off of the game's nature. Does get a bit repetitive but this could be expected as you are trying to memorize the katakana. Affection levels and events are a fun add in.
