author: {'steamid': '76561198158945336', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 665, 'last_played': 1625090064}
review:
Ce jeu est vraiment superbe.

Il permet d'apprendre facilement les différents caractères du katakana et de les mémoriser à travers les combats. Il y a également quelques quêtes secondaire qui met en pratique ce qu'on a appris et qui nous récompense avec du vocabulaire basique intéressant.

Comparé au premier jeu de la série (Hiragana), je trouve que tous les points faible du jeu ont été réglé.
- Les combats sont plus amusant
- Les monstres sont visible sur la carte et pas aléatoire n'importe ou
- Il y a une répétition des sons et de comment tracer le caractère pendant le combat
- Il y a plus de quête, d'histoire et objectifs
- Il y a un système d'affection qui permet de débloquer des dialogues avec des personnages (basique mais c'est amusant)

Pour résumé, je recommande vraiment ce jeu au débutant qui souhaite se familiariser avec le katakana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078786771', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1145, 'last_played': 1621826503}
review:
This is a solid tool for Katakana memorization and review. I look at this as a learning tool first and a game second and through that lens it meets and exceeds expectations. If you are looking for a solid RPG with language learning as a secondary, you will be let down. Is the game bad? No, it just isn't amazing and serves as a fairly basic RPG maker style game. Is the game capable to teaching Katakana in a more enjoyable method than flash cards and memorizing charts? Yes.

If you want to study Katakana and think doing it in a game sounds fun, then this should fill that role. I do advise to come back now and then with this as you will forget some of the Katakana if you are not actively using it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972223919', 'num_games_owned': 1463, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1059, 'last_played': 1619138615}
review:
A wonderful sequel. 

I highly recommend playing Hiragana Battle first. While it may not be required, I think the learning progression of Hiragana > Katakana > Kanji definitely feels natural. 

Additionally, Katakana War is much better balanced as an RPG in general where Hiragana Battle is fairly quick to become rather easy. The characters and story are more interesting as well, but not so much that they try to get in the way of the goal, teaching Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012383038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1619828676}
review: This game is absolutely fantastic. I was looking for a more fun way to study Japanese, and this was perfect. I beat it in a weekend and the lessons stuck. It's a little silly, but it's fun and it teaches in just the right pattern and timing that you remember everything easily. Thank you for making this! Can't wait to try Hiragana and Kanji! Would love to see more similar games focusing on reading and grammar, too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198318042774', 'num_games_owned': 295, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 783, 'last_played': 1657268471}
review: a vast improvement from the previous instalment in every single way, but retains the straightforwardness and simplicity as a fun little beginner's Japanese revision tool. the most obvious changes are in its presentation, with how the maps, characters and UI are designed, the music is good and there's even some pretty decent voice acting. it feels much more like a game than Hiragana Battle, albeit still much so a very straightforward and simple one

author: {'steamid': '76561198350287181', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1618185100}
review:
Similar to what another reviewer said this game is catered to sub cultures who believe they are fans of Japan, rather then presenting an authentic view of the country, the language and the grammar. There is a scene with a Buddhist monk in front of a Shinto shrine. This is highly offensive, as in reality the two religions are separate and it's disappointing that a game that purports to help customers with their Japanese does not have a basic respect of Japanese traditions. I would refund if I could, but I opened this some time after an initial purchase.  If I could, I would like to contact the developer, and ask what they were thinking.

Please do not support companies that portray Japan cheaply or disrespectfully!

author: {'steamid': '76561198190963539', 'num_games_owned': 90, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 946, 'last_played': 1671015488}
review: yeee

author: {'steamid': '76561198044003624', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1619674384}
review: Really good for learning Katakana characters, though was a little annoyed when character combinations were glossed over in a chart at the end rather than gone over one at a time. With Hiragana it wasn't as big an issue, since they can simply explain how if a character ends in "I", it can have a smaller "ya, yu, or yo" character next to it to change the sound. However with Katakana, there are a lot more examples and rules, which could've been its own 11th lesson.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141694619', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1615818174}
review: about the same as hiragana but i recommend learning hiragana first

author: {'steamid': '76561199131372190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 967, 'last_played': 1618358478}
review: It's pretty good

author: {'steamid': '76561198154098985', 'num_games_owned': 98, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1078, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1615223980}
review: Great way to learn katakana

author: {'steamid': '76561198100025570', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1614572230}
review:
Play this as a fun and unique way to learn katakana.

Can't speak for the story cuz i skipped it all but it was a fun way to learn Katakana. I haven't played any of the other games in the series but i really enjoyed the change of pace from flash cards. 

As far as the RPG elements go this game is pretty basic and obviously not really focused on the RPG elements as much as you would think. Most RPG elements here are useless and I don't think i bought a single item from the game except the side quests that make you do it so i just stuck with the basic roster and healed with magic. 

The game is very easy but at the end of the day its all about learning katakana without boring flash cards which i think it did very well. The ost is pretty catchy too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198036075924', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1613618000}
review:
This game is great. They kept all of the things that made the last game good - the ease of learning, effective memory techniques, and amazing music - and also increased the gameplay element, that was a bit lackluster before. 

Playing these two games alongside duolingo, I saw the different in aptitude immedately. These games are clearly superior, and I highly recommend picking them up! Looking forward to the third.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054616572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1614218730}
review: I have used other resources to already learn some of the language. This is a pleasant way to go through the drudgery of repeating characters over and over. I was looking for practice, and that is what this game is providing. Just enough of a RPG skin on top to be there and not get in the way of practice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198273262810', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1591844171}
review: not worth the $

author: {'steamid': '76561198139271741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 1113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1099, 'last_played': 1615418256}
review: Similar gameplay to Hiragana Battle, but with much improved presentation (and of course, Katakana). The fact that there was voice acting totally threw me off guard the first time I played this game, and I enjoyed most of the performances. Showing the katakana being written in battle, along with a voiceover of the sound when attacking, was a nice touch, too. Very helpful to play alongside an actual Japanese class.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137807914', 'num_games_owned': 190, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 822, 'last_played': 1568055032}
review: I am truly impressed with the improvement made after the Hiragana game. Better mechanics, gameplay and story. From the perspective of language learning it is not really necessary but can be helpful if you are struggling to get started. That said, you cannot learn Katakana turly without reading more after the game. (in my opinion)

author: {'steamid': '76561198088167957', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 575, 'last_played': 1611592102}
review: Played the gamed daily for a little over a week. And I can read all Katakana with ease. The game in itself is your typical RPG generic game. However, that is not the focus. Use the game as a tool to help you learn. I recommend you use a notebook and write EVERYTHING the game teaches you down. And I also highly encourage you to not cheat when playing. Don't rely on the notebook too much. Use it as the base to write the characters repeatedly to help you memorize them. Then hit the dungeon and do your best to remember. I can confidently read all hiragana and katakana when reading Japanese text thanks to these games. I may not understand all the words yet but atleast I know HOW to read each character. The perfect starting point to learning vocabulary and Kanji. BIGGEST TIPS. Play the hiragana game first and play this one on the hiragana difficulty. Do it daily. Do one lesson a day. Write stuff down and maybe try some digital flashcard apps. You can do it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198126893207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1272, 'last_played': 1703456459}
review: Best way to learn !

author: {'steamid': '76561197992591634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1017, 'last_played': 1611617920}
review:
This game will teach you the Katakana characters and some vocabulary. It's a hit and a miss at most time. It improved most of the  issues Hiragana Battle had.

First and foremost if you're looking to learn the Katakana characters, look no further. This is the game. If you're seeking for more than just the characters, this isn't the game.

Personally, it did seem daunting at first to learn another 20+ characters following Hiragana. You know,"you can't teach an old dog new tricks"? Well, I certainly felt like that and I can say I think I got a good grasp of the Katakana characters and more or less.

Gameplay:

The great addition to the game has to be voice over, it added a lot to the 'dating sim' genre and made the characters more alive than just text and a picture on the screen. The downside, there's only three scenarios per character to complete, but considering the length of the game, it what it is.

The ability to swap party members was a great addition, however, the game just threw almost all the characters at you at once, and since they're all low level, grinding them felt tedious and unless you're going for 100% achievement, don't bother, find the characters that work for you and stick to them.

This time around, they added a way to see who's next to attack, it made it slightly easier clear the Katakana characters without taking damage. They also cleaned up the attack menu to fill up to four attacks per line instead of two like the previous game.

They also included more magic and each character had their own unique spell, but spell itself is way too broken. The only saving grace about spell is that you can't defeat them with magic alone.  In all cases the Katakana characters are left with 1 hp and is forced to be finished with their corresponding Romanji. It made no sense to use spells most of the time, just continue practicing and learning the characters using regular attacks.

Couple big issues that should have been addressed since the game has been out for awhile. Back in Hiragana Battle, you can use WASD to move, and in this game you can select it, but they never worked.

Another issue, at the beginning I said, this game is great to learn the Katakana characters, but anything else you should seek an alternative?

Well, learning the vocab is nice, however, unlike Hiragana Battle's final map of the game it had enemies in Hiragana vocabs. This game gets you to learn the vocab, but don't ever make use of them and there were never any encounters of Katakana vocab monsters at all, until the final boss that makes you use カタカナ (Katakana) in your attack option. 

In the end, it achieved what I wanted and that was to learn the Katakana characters, however, in terms of learning it was a one-step forward and two-step backwards. 

If you want to learn the characters, go for it! 
If you want to learn vocabs, don't bother.

author: {'steamid': '76561198269417078', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1614809991}
review: Bastante bueno, se recomienda saber hiragana antes, o como en el juego dice, haber jugado Learn Japanese To Survive Hiragana War, te da una ventaja bastante buena al aprender

author: {'steamid': '76561198119834610', 'num_games_owned': 859, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1611534472}
review:
A massive improvement over the previous title, as all systems have been upgrades and polished: Magic is now actually useful (I'd spam Speed Up in LJTS: Hiragana, to try and "steal" turns, but would never use the other spells) as it allows you to damage the katakana enemies, but won't knock them out, so you won't miss out on practice. The "answer" attacks now display an animation of the character you're using to attack, so it's less punishing than the previous iteration in the series, as if you end up not using the correct character, you'll now know what that character (you used) looks like, in order to go ahead and learn, instead of getting a bland "miss" sound effect along with no damage done whatsoever.

There's also a lot of new vocabulary to be learned across the entire game (unlike, once again, LJTS: Hiragana, that would only teach you vocabulary really later on) and they've made the lessons more straightforward, removing the second writting animation (thanks) and sticking to a same design for the writting animation and example character.

Also, the new characters give you a lot of freedom to create a party that fits your needs. I for one was running Daisuke, Charlotte and Kyoko for the high-damage and survivability from the fact that I had 2 high DPS characters and 3 healers (Protagonist, Daisuke and Charlotte are good healers. Daisuke and Kyoko are good DPS characters).

The VN segments they added make the characters seem a lot more interesting than in the previous game. 

Well, you get me. It's better in all aspects. Some could say this is due to the fact that you'll be learning Katakana after learning Hiragana. But I'd say, this is proof of the fact that these devs have taken their time reading the reviews and improving their game based on that.
As with the previous game, this could be a really nice introduction to the katakana system. I'm feeling really confident in the fact that I'm now able to read both sillabaries thanks to this game series, but I didn't have this as my only source of learning, and I didn't really bother writting up the characters, nor making any kind of notes. This, however, would be most appropiate, as it will help you learn better, and will also help you in-game, as it would be a reminder about what characters you're facing. Either way, I decided against that, because that would be kinda like cheating I guess? I prefereed to commit them to memory the old fashioned way.

Either way, I highly recommend it to anyone trying to get their first steps in the japanese language. I'm using this game series and Duolingo myself, at least for the time being. I'd say that's a good place to start learning, and you'd be saving some money from paying for a complete beginner's course. It's better to pay later on, in order to improve your skills, or to keep going after you've gotten hard-stuck.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996622753', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1612415464}
review: カタカナ

author: {'steamid': '76561198022099334', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1275, 'last_played': 1635898849}
review:
The marrying of language learning and jrpg mechanics is a wonderful idea.  To learn a language one must repeatedly encounter it again and again, and by having the enemies you grind for XP be the words you know is like having continuous flash cards over and over. 

This game is really good at teaching you the core katakana letters. One potential issue is that you might start associating the symbols with their position in the attack menu rather than with sounds, but just make sure that you think of the sound or symbol before opening the menu and you should be fine. Another issue is that some areas aren't repeatable, especially the area where 'n' monsters were concentrated, which can make it hard to revise certain sets of katakana. 

Main bad thing is that the game goes over some bits of katakana really clearly, especially the little symbols (like the small 'tsu' that means you need to double the next consonant). These are mentioned, but not practised in game, so you might need to check them out separately. I ended up going to wikipedia to grab more info. 

Otherwise, is very good. I now know katakana enough to be able to read most any phrase I see, and I've a decent chance of being able to write something, too. I'll probably be playing through again to make sure that everything is hammered in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107143714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 618, 'last_played': 1624021778}
review:
A very educational game. I was skeptical at first but the game definitely helped me remember katakana characters through repetition. In a few months of on off playing I was able to read at a reasonable speed. 

Very recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062022078', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1609961124}
review:
Half-decent way to learn Katakana if you like RPGs.  Kinda slow and repetitive, but so are most RPGs.  Instead of pressing "fight" in the menu, you have to answer which character it is.  Other than that, it's a fairly standard RPG.  Not gonna win awards for story, but a whole lot better than staring at flashcards.  Art is not bad at all. 
 Voices are decent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088186976', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 712, 'last_played': 1674985226}
review:
I've learned a bit Japanes before, so I didn't start from scratch. Anyhow, to me this game was a great and motivating way to memorize Katakana and a lot of fun on the way.

So I recommend it as one piece of the puzzle if you try to get into japanese.

Got it on the winter sale together with Kanji/Hiragana, and totally worth the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040556681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1609970318}
review: Very creative! I got this game as a Christmas gift, it's been an unexpected gem. 3 hours in and plenty of Katakana learned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076910886', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1149, 'last_played': 1609043101}
review:
Like the previous game in the series, Hiragana Battle, this "game" isn't all that great. It's very basic and there isn't anything here as a game that you haven't played before if you've played any JRPGs in the past. The only way I would recommend this  is if you find it on sale and you need that extra motivation to study some Japanese language. In my case, it's more of a review of the second language that I learned in high school and then didn't use for nearly a decade, so I'm just trying to brush up on the written language again. 

As far as gameplay features, the music doesn't loop very well and ends and restarts abruptly. There are spells in the game and they actually have uses this time around, unlike the previous game, but that's only because they have a few mage characters that can't do normal attacks very effectively. Considering the amount of characters, I wish the ones not in the party would level up with the group, even if there experience out of the party was reduced by 25-50%. Because they don't, some areas were artificially difficult as I tried to level up everyone somewhat equally. Sidequests are very basic, but are fine for a small and simple game like this. The biggest issue in this game is the lag when you finish 90% of battles. The game just hangs on the experience screen and either takes a long time to load or wont load at all unless you switch the game from windowed to full screen and back multiple times or try using the mouse and a controller over and over again. This was the most frustrating aspect of the game for me. As a game, it's a little better than the previous one, but not by a lot.

Overall, not a great "game", but useful for those trying to brush up on their Katakana or who need that extra push to start learning the language.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168346778', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 1290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1290, 'last_played': 1607390093}
review:
This learning game for Katakana is an improvement over their previous one (Hiragana) in every aspect.

+ improved battle system: The commands for each group member are executed instantly now. No more attacking the wrong enemy because the assigned one died in the meanwhile.
+ improved Katakana mixing: You can encounter letters from earlier regions later on instead of having to revisit their original area
+ improved story/gameplay: They put more effort into storytelling and cranked up the number of recruitable characters for the group. You can now even date them.
+ the art style is beautiful. Especially the eyes of the characters are quite captivating.

The game can teach you to write and read katakana, but its use for learning the proper pronunciation seems limited. While all the syllables are voiced, male and female characters often pronounce them in a different way, leaving the player confused as of which one the right version is.
Examples:
WA is pronounced as WA by the female characters and UA by the male ones.
WO is pronounced as WO by the female characters and O by the male ones.

Not sure how they messed that part up... but aside from that, it's been a great (and often funny) game. And more than just a little inspired by other games and series. Charlotte feels like a copy of Fluttershy, from her voice/behavior to her colors.

author: {'steamid': '76561198364545558', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 624, 'last_played': 1606472926}
review: Katakana War (KW) is the second game in the Learn Japanese to Survive series. The first game was Hiragana Battle (HB). Although keeping the order is not necessary and you can just start playing KW, I recommend playing HB first and then continue with KW because in katakana lessons there are some references to hiragana and it can be a good opportunity to review your hiragana knowledge. More importantly, Katakana War is more refined than its predecessor, so it might be a bit rough to play HB after KW. In katakana war, random enemy encounter system is removed which makes the game more fun and dungeon crawling less tedious, the companion system is improved and you can have more versatile team strategy (in hiragana battle you had a fixed team with limited options) and the anime-like music/bgm made the game more enjoyable. My only gripe was the plethora of unnecessary and boring dialogues. Specially I felt like the ending/epilogue dragged on too long. But this is no big deal for an educational game and I'm looking forward to playing the third game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012297188', 'num_games_owned': 1424, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 15373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1709614682}
review:
As a person who is self studying Japanese, it's really great to find a game like this to freshen up the studying scene and make it feel like it's not studying at all. Through out this game you'll learn a variety of new words (around 100, I think.) to add to your vocabulary by completely simple side quests. The characters are cute and create an adorable band of friends, but I feel like there were 2 too many characters and the voice acting was painful. For an extra cost, what I would like to see is the devs create an additional mode where you have to spell the words you've learnt using katakana. It would help to teach "students" how to combine words to make different sounds.

All in all, fantastic game. I've spent the last 4 hours straight playing this to whip my arse back into studying, and they've helped me accomplish that. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198004842640', 'num_games_owned': 1058, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1605891862}
review:
Quem jogou o antecessor sobre hiragana e gostou vai gostar desse. 

Vários aspectos do jogo anterior foram polidos, como por exemplo os encontros de batalha que não são mais aleatórios, e novas funcionalidades foram adicionadas, que não interferem muito no aprendizado do katakana mas enriquecem a experiência de jogo, como uma quantidade maior de personagens e o relacionamento com eles (ainda que a personalidade deles seja bem clichezona). A história também foi um pouco mais desenvolvida nesse título que no anterior, embora ainda continue bem simples, o que é condizente com a proposta do jogo. 

Para quem sentir falta dos encontros aleatórios, existe um castelo dentro do jogo no qual você pode participar de quantos combates quiser, para praticar mais. 

No mais, um bom jogo que cumpre aquilo que se propõe a fazer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984872411', 'num_games_owned': 1210, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 674, 'last_played': 1637956285}
review:
This game, part 2 (though not necessary to play them in order) of the "Learn Japanese to Survive" series, shares the core framework of the previous game. It's a turn-based JRPG, where your enemies are the symbols used in japanese language (specifically Katakana). They've added in voice acting to some cutscenes, added more playable characters (meaning you can swap based on preference), made improvements to the flow of combat (turn order is based on character speed, as such it is no longer ENEMY TURN/PLAYER TURN sort of deal. You can command a character to act, and once confirmed they will act) and also removed random battles, this time all enemies are visible in the overworld/dungeons and can be avoided unless otherwise advised.

Team Sleepy Duck has done a good job of trying to make learning the Japanese language a bit easier, and perhaps more intuitive for fans of JRPGs, and the repetitive flow of gameplay, which lends itself well to learning and memorization.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084076229', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1006, 'last_played': 1702369924}
review: Esse segundo jogo é alguns passos bem mais polido do Hiragana Battle, aqui você aprende Katakana. Tem uma mecânica nova de 'afeição', os personagens ganham afeição em batalhas e quando tiver pontos suficientes você tem uma cena dublada full mais um boost nos stats do personagem. Ah, tem magia, mas não mata, então o método é lançar magia AoE e responder qual katakana é. Aconselho demais para qualquer um que está iniciando a estudar japonês, praticamente não estudei katakana exceto jogando esse jogo e reconheço todos, mas lembrar de alguns na hora de escrever ainda vai demorar um pouco.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201528455', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 986, 'last_played': 1605314133}
review: Way better than the first game in terms of UI, battle, and companion characters. As a study AIDE this is great, but not a replacement for full study. Good game overall, if not typical.

author: {'steamid': '76561198832119803', 'num_games_owned': 590, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 846, 'last_played': 1605456701}
review: This game is great for learning Katakana, and improves on a lot of the weaker aspects of the first game in the series. For example, combat is much less tedious both because there are no random encounters so you have more control over when you do and don't engage enemies, and because each character attacks as soon as you give them a command, rather than going in rounds, which makes it much easier to avoid wasting attacks on the wrong enemies. These and many other improvements like voice acting and a more interesting cast of characters made this game feel much more fleshed out than Hiragana Battle, and I can't wait to see what they improved on in Kanji Combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198181907162', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1139, 'last_played': 1632118886}
review:
Learn Japanese to Survive Chapter 2: Katakana War is awesome, with this game, you will easy to remenber Katakana easily, and will not forget if 1 or more katakanas appeared frequently.
Pros:
Awesome Storyline.
You(the protagonist) are able to restore your or other character's health if it is low and every character(not include the protagonist :( ) has 3 special abilities to help you fighting Obake easier.
Awesome fighting system, and some of them are golden Obake(For example: パΩ) which is very rare!!!
Japanese speakers to pronounce every Katakana; for the first time playing I thought that Alec Shea would pronounce every Katakana but actually won't.
Awesome Music Collection.
Form your best team with these characters.
Cons:
Only 10 chapters on this game; it should have 11 chapters after learning ワ ヲ ン,
You can only form your team at Osaka that caused time wasting.
Not much randoming your enemies, especially chapter 9 and chapter 10.
Some mistakes of Katakana database existed like トゥ is "tu" not "to(ト)" and ドゥ is "du" not "do(ド)".
Anyhow, if you were enjoying this game and play more, then you would memorize all Katakana perfectly and correctly.
Points: 10/10 and 92/100

author: {'steamid': '76561197980759599', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 943, 'last_played': 1635597038}

author: {'steamid': '76561198105034993', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 730, 'last_played': 1610983818}
review:
The game makes learning Katakana a fun and enjoyable experience, just not always for the right reasons. The main gameplay loop of fighting Katakana enemies forces you to memorise each character, and is a great way of revising what you've already gone over, especially since every character you've learned can show up to a fight. Most dialogue with characters is humorous in some way, and the game makes sure that there are a few jokes before each lesson to make sure that even the driest parts of the game are still enjoyable.

Of course, then there's the voice acting.

The voice acing was a mistake. I'm sure the voice actors themselves are very talented and I wish them a long and successful career in voice-acting, but the voices here are terrible. Everyone in the game, whether they're Australian, Japanese, German, French, Russian, whatever - all of them have the same American accents. And a lot of it sounds terrible. Daisuke (The main teacher, who you will CONSTANTLY have to listen to) sounds especially bad. And before you ask, no, you cannot turn the voices off without removing other game sounds.
However, my opinion of the voices was changed as soon as I heard the voice of the main villain. Holy shit, she is spectacular. I can only assume that her voice was made deliberately terrible, because it is so incredibly hammy and over-the-top that it totally saved the voice acting of the game. She is spectacular, she is best girl, and I love her voice. Buy the game. Buy it for her.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127880332', 'num_games_owned': 82, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 629, 'last_played': 1650721182}

author: {'steamid': '76561198385666083', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 209, 'playtime_forever': 1024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1024, 'last_played': 1600292112}
review: [b]Katana V.S. katakana, get ready (it's lame but I couldn't help it)[/b][list][/list]Le jeu le mieux abouti de la série à tous points de vue.[list][/list]Jouabilité : Un seul crash, une accélération sauvage de texte dans le chapitre 4 et le bug des scènes d'amitié de niveau 5 à signaler. C'est plutôt correct. Les combats sont plus difficiles que dans les deux autres volets, ce qui rend l'expérience plus stratégique et ludique. L'histoire est davantage crédible, ce qui n'est pas plus mal.[list][/list]Apprentissage : Des leçons équilibrées, sur le même modèle que pour les hiraganas (enchaîner directement les syllabaires n'est pas forcément une bonne idée... ça se mélange un peu dans ma tête). En revanche, ce que l'on gagne côté gameplay (réelle utilité de la magie), on le perd côté pédagogie (moins d'efforts de mémorisation).Petit bémol cependant : on ne nous explique pas les règles qui s'appliquent pour l'utilisation conjointe des alphabets au sein d'un même mot, ni pourquoi certains mots qui ne semblent pas d'origine étrangère s'écrivent en katakana.[list][/list]En bref, l'ensemble des 'Learn japanese to survive !' est à mon sens une bonne passerelle vers une méthode d'acquisition du niveau B1.[list][/list]Petit bonus : des succès faciles à débloquer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198353600289', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 968, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 968, 'last_played': 1590385309}
review:
I wish there were more educational video games. This one is cool and i like it for what it is but there is so much more you can do with the genre and language learning. If you're interested in learning japanese i recommend it but if you're not give it a pass.

Wouldn't it be nice if there was a game that could be both though? A fun video game for normies and a fun educational game for nerds like me? Someday... but until then we have to sing praises for this game which is good don't let my bitter tone bring it down. It is good my only disappointment is how much more it could have been.

author: {'steamid': '76561198894477125', 'num_games_owned': 183, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1598562845}

author: {'steamid': '76561198071706352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1598098560}
review:
After playing Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle, i thought this game would be a good way to learn katakana. I was wrong.

First off, there's too many bugs in this game (at least for me), enemies not responding, being stuck in the after battle screen, having the same dialogue playing again and again when entering the apartment, etc.

And the second thing is, it has some false information/wrong teachings like how the characters ア,イ,ウ,エ and オ don't use a dakuten when in reality they do.

Third and last thing, it's a personal thing but when given the vocabulary lessons, some still use hiragana,  if you're gonna play a game about katakana why would you put some words that have hiragana in them.

The only Learn Japanese To Survive game that is worth playing is Hiragana Battle only

author: {'steamid': '76561198371988356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1599704513}
review:
I can't recommend this game due to a few flaws it has:

It's not optimized for computers the options provide a choice to use the wasd keyboard config but it doesn't work, and despite being no more graphically intense than a super nintendo game this game eats up CPU like crazy making it hard to run. My PC fan is at full blast and you can still feel the tower being hot to the touch. 

Next the hamfisted attempt at humor in this game is so terrible, it's the most basic non offensive elevator music tier humor possible. I didn't even crack a smile once the whole time, I try to skip through as much of the dialogue as I possibly can and even that is slow because of how poorly optimized this game is. Worse even still is the youtube fandub tier voice acting that they somehow felt was needed in this game  with NO option to turn off. It boggles my mind that they would spend money to hire these people as they give some of the worst most cringe worthy performances possible.

review: За счёт добавления персонажей игра немного потеряла в балансе, но по-прежнему остаётся достаточно увлекательной, чтобы выучить вторую часть японской азбуки также легко и быстро, как и первую часть. Рекомендую.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004275158', 'num_games_owned': 320, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3098, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2724, 'last_played': 1601505233}
review:
This is a great wrapper for what is basically just randomized flash-cards. There are standard RPG elements & magic spells that don't involve learning Katakana too, but, obviously if you're not playing the game to learn Katakana, there are MUCH better RPGs out there.

The story is "enough" that it's not just a flash-card game, but other than the novel enemy design, it is a completely generic and mostly boring RPG. I'd even say some of the character dialogue is "cringy" at times. But if you let yourself have fun, it *is* much more fun than flash-cards. The main draw of this game over a traditional course is that it feels good to correctly identify the enemies (Katakana glyphs) and "defeat" them, and it feels good to "level up".

My main criticisms for this as a learning aid would be: 

1) I would like to have more fonts shown, to see what Katakana really looks like when it's not calligraphy. They show it sometimes, but not often enough.

2) It took conscious effort not to learn the characters by *position in the attack menu*, but by their strokes. I would really like an option to randomize the order for the attack menu, but having them in a consistent order did make it easier to learn them too, so it should just be an option that can be enabled/disabled during battle maybe.

3) Some of the RPG elements detract from studying. For example, every time Tia uses her maximum friendship spell, she says the name of the spell out loud, in English, and I have to try and ignore it because it is distracting and takes me out of "Katakana mode". You don't have to use the spells, but they are helpful for the RPG part of the game.

Overall, yes, I can recommend this game as a learning aid for Katakana. It kept me interested in the subject long enough to learn them all, and I imagine I'll keep coming back to the game if I need to refresh my memory.

author: {'steamid': '76561198834500805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 816, 'last_played': 1595211752}
review:
Me encanto el juego. Es evidente que le han dado muchas mas horas de trabajo, invertido muchos mas recursos. Hay un salto enorme en calidad con respecto a su predecesor.
 
Estan bien explicadas las katakanas que es lo principal.
-Mucho vocabulario adicional (me parece que mas que el de Hiragana)
-Desarrollo de personajes, 
-Se agregaron detalles en las peleas,
-Podemos elegir los integrantes de nuestro equipo.
-Equipamientos con diferentes caracteristicas para el gusto de cada uno.

A quien este comenzando con Japones se lo recomiendo sin duda. 

Aun asi pienso que pueden seguir mejorandolo. Veremos como es el de Kanji

author: {'steamid': '76561198390983427', 'num_games_owned': 58, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 792, 'last_played': 1597875919}
review:
This is a lot better than the previous one (Hiragana Battle).
It has a more engaging story and charismatic characters; you can see the enemies on the map so you're not forced to fight all the time; it has better visuals, even though it still has that 'RPG Maker' look it clearly looks much better than the first game.
The voices are cool but a bit cringy sometimes.
Only thing I missed is having diagonal/8 directions movement, since the maps are kinda big it would make exploration more enjoyable.

And yes, it does teaches the Katakana alphabet very well, so it's a good way to learn or to reinforce your knowledge (which was my case).

I'd give it a 8.2 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198446160817', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1608651388}
review:
Fun and educational game. Got me hooked and finished in 11 hours. You can finish in 10 hours because my computer crashed and an hour worth of save was gone. I picked the swift gecko, maybe wrong choice as its not the strongest character but to deal the most damage pick Tia, Daisuke, Owen in the beginning and after you unlock Kyoko change Owen with her.
Tİa: Strongest and has great defence. Dont use magic spells.
MC (Swift Gecko): Great strength and Magic, defense is a bit low but equip the best things on yourself and its no problem
Daisuke: Pretty much matches MC, his ultimate is handy, slightly better defense than MC
Kyoko: Not so  strong at attacking but if you use magic spells she is the best.
Owen: Strength is as good as MC but lacks magic damage. Slightly better defense.
Mischa: Good attack but weak overall.
I don't recommend using Charlotte and Andrea.

I  couldnt do it but to do max damage in a battle let Kyoko strike first or second so she can deal huge damage with magic spells and it will take 1 hit to finish every enemy one by one. In my case always Tia stroke first and MC could finish only 1 enemy so the battles lasted longer overall.

I made a mistake by playing this first as this is the second game, but i will start the other one  later.

Story is good characters are good (except Charlotte, she is annoying imo).

During affection events it would be better to answer more questions rather than 1 but its ok.

Would like to have access to Kyoto and Tokyo in this game but i guess they are for other games.

Overall the game is a must-buy as it is a fun way to teach the basics of a language with a different alphabet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198203167365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1593801188}
review: The game is decently fun for what it is. They made some good improvements since the first game, namely being able to see enemies in the field as opposed to random encounters and attacking with one character at a time to speed up battles and prevent repetitive clicking.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041499783', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1622, 'last_played': 1592600272}
review:
For those who don't know: play the three Japanese-learning game in this order:
1) Higana battle, 2) Karakana wars, 3, Kanji Combat.
It's a good sequel to Hiragana battle, and it really does help to learn & remember Katakana. The playability has also been improved a lot. There's less grinding and the menu to select an answer is really much more user-friendly.
The trial castle is a great addition too!
The only downside is it would have been best to propose an option to avoid translating hiragana in romaji and perhaps also to place hiragana and katakana side by side.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988999542', 'num_games_owned': 1080, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1140, 'last_played': 1592220844}
review: So much to learn. The first game is great followed by a fantastic second game. Looking forward to the third!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009517770', 'num_games_owned': 527, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 826, 'last_played': 1605943516}
review:
Just like its predecessor, Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana War is a great stepping stone for learning Japanese. You will need to supplement the game with other resources (I recommend using this guide for the first game https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1573508156 but instead use the Learn Katakana page from the Tofugu website that it references here: https://www.tofugu.com/japanese/learn-katakana/) and you will need to go beyond the game once completing it, but it is a great start. 

Unlike the first game, this game also provides a Challenge Castle that allows you to practice previously learned Katakana characters. It also has a few nice JRPG touches, like an Affection system that encourages grinding but is actually a guise to review old material. I recommend trying to get every achievement in this game if only because doing so will strengthen retention for the most part (some achievements are just for fun but are easy enough to get that you might as well as try). Superficially, the game also has a great soundtrack, just like the first game. And the story is about as enjoyable as a story that can be concocted for an educational game masquerading as a JRPG but I still enjoyed it.

There are a few nitpicks, though. For example, there is some minor slow down at parts, but never enough to destroy enjoyment of the game. I also encountered a few times where my game refused to save, but exiting and re-entering the menu remedied that. The game also promises that you can re-map keys but I was unable to get this to work.

That said, this game is a great start to learning Japanese. Playing the first game, Learn Japanese to Survive! Hiragana Battle, is recommended but not needed. You also do not need to necessarily memorize much of the vocabulary in this game because once you can read Katakana, most words become instantly recognizable. This is because Katakana is mostly used for foreign loan words and these words are often borrowed from Romance languages and English. Therefore, once you can read the Katakana, you can usually understand the word provided you can read or speak English or other Romance languages.

All in all, you could definitely do worse for a game that takes roughly 13 hours to beat, so I highly recommend it if you have any interest in learning Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198174044439', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1014, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 671, 'last_played': 1610161040}
review: Got this as a gift. Great game for learning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043782587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 598, 'playtime_forever': 1016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1014, 'last_played': 1591666871}
review:
I have an announcement: That punch-a-face femboy ダイツケ has just went and stole my Rus rockstar girl, the light and the joy of my nationalistic Eastern Slavic eyes, right when I was about to make a move-a-pop. That's right, this plimpleless mutant of a nerd and geek culture ninja-quackd me with no sense of honor and then he said "My quiz today will be THIS long". If he wants his yakuza clan to not fall into dirt and disrespect, he will perform a せっぷく by tomorrow morning. This is deeply emasculating and I can already feel my shoulder bones shrinking.

(EDIT: Above part is actually was supposed to be sarcastic tongue-in-the-cheek after I read too much r/gamingcirclejerk, combined with Eggman announcement meme. Sorta making fun of terrible things I read on Internet. I am not a terrible person, but too creative for me to edit out.)

On a serious note tho, Daikatana War is a sequel of Higurashi Battle, still being a multimedia edutainment. It doesn't exactly require you to beat Hiragana, it even threw the plot hook down the window. So, education and entertainment.

For entertainment part, the game is a big improvement over the complete amateur bedlam that was Hiragana. They actually got an artist to draw character. Seems like they got music that isn't exactly self-made but isn't part of RPG Maker stock. Story is less stupid than Hiragana plot and semi-works at entertaining you somewhat albeit the new inclusion of voice acting is easily multiplying the cringier parts by ten. The rest of the stock assets was used in a way that it doesn't look too out of place. Katakana War has a look of respectable RPG Maker budget title. Kudos to devs for actually improving instead of sitting and sitting and sitting and sitting.

The combat now has a system where you give orders to individual characters and they act immediately, so you don't ultramegakill a single kana. It also seems to go faster in how it feels? Answer menu is now sorted like a proper table that fits to the whole screen, bringing joy to mouse users as well, as game has improved interface, you can actually point at Kana here. You still have to click and double click more than you should be if you are using mouse, so it's not quite there yet.
No more random battles either, all enemies encounters are represented as characters you can avoid in overworld. And less grind required, I feel.

There are more RPG elements, such few equippable items that aren't just direct upgrades in stats, having to build up a 4 member National Japanese Empire party from 8 chars and date them. Actually, no dating, more of hanging out after you battle enough, just small dialog. I am pretty sure this feature was taken from whatever jRPGs are popular now, I haven't kept up since 90s, it sure has little meaning there as all characters are cliches in personality... and same-face syndrome but that's same as saying "anime".

The balance however was still not quite on par. It started out semi-interesting in combat, with more bosses, and all that but half-way through the game I have managed to get a party and equipment that I could beat every non-boss encounter without a single loss of HP or MP, the spammable "once per battle" 0MP nuke of a magic that one of characters learned after doing all the dating scenes being the key. The idea that magic can't kill enemies by itself got annoying. And I never needed major healing powers, minor was still healing everyone perfectly.

So entertainment is fairly there but sadly edutainment remained largery on the same level.

The game is mostly only good for somewhat reinforcing kana characters in memory. Sorta. There are no true random battles, yes, but I still think that what formation you battle is still taken from few presets for each area. The picking of kanas per area was better than in Hiragana but I still felt annoyed at repeats of same battles as well as well, as felt that I rarely met few particular kanas. In the end, the best way I memorized katakana is by making myself write down a whole table of what I learned from memory each night, as I was slowly playing through the game. Yep, multiple sessions. If you are the power gamer who beats games in a single day while using guides, you are an idiot and an amateur in the wrong hood. Overall, it's still a bit weak in reinforcement and you can beat the game while not really memorizing the whole table correctly.

The variety battles when you encounter romaji and have to give the answer in kana are complete failures, just like in Hiragana. The systematically sorted answer menu allows you to easily cheese it by figuring out where such romanji would stand without actually remembering the kana writing.

The game is happy to give you random phrases and words as rewards for side-quests as well as random vocab lessons with barely any reinforcement. No, immediatelly quizing in 5 seconds once doesn't count as proper reinforcement. Not even for final level. Yes. That's right, my ever vigilant reader from whomsth hawk eyes see every spec and sliver. I was complaining about final level in Hiragana doing exactly that. But first, I would have been happier if I was properly reinforcement through whole game. Second, in Hiragana the phrases were random and the only good fundamental usage of it, the numerics, was used only once at final battle. However, vocab challenge would have fit to Katakana War as katakana words are often loan-words, making it easier to guess their meaning. It would have been perfect here, not in Hiragana. What a waste of potential.

Overall, hummmmm, I don't knooooooooow. 6 years ago I have abandoned learning Japanese very early at Katakana alphabet (I like to excuse that I was busy being a student), while now I actually memorized the table while playing this game as supplemental. So I guess Katakana War is good and I shall leave positive review despite numerous faults. But make no mistake, it's good only because of edutainment value it brings alone. If it was just a mere le entertainment, I would have kicked it down the stairs. It still could be so much more, and if better edutainment game comes out, you can forget about this one.

Oh, and there is a glitch where max affection may heavily lag your PC during screen color changes. I thought it was not-top-tier (oh, soooo not top and not even tier) laptop with backward OpenGL renderer suppport being naughty, as RPG Maker MV engine that this game runs on makes use of WebGL from my knowledge, for sake of mega-crossplatforming. But few people complained as well. The only solution is to suck it up and wait out the lags.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044588347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1594564357}
review:
Wie schon der erste Teil der Reihe, gut geeignet um die Grundlagen, in dem Fall Katakana zu lernen.
Die Anzahl der Vokabeln (neben Katakana) ist in diesem Teil etwas größer und man lernt auch verschiedene Zeitformen.

Wie der erste Teil, leider nur auf Englisch, wer also kein Englisch kann wird hiermit auch kein Japanisch lernen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263824172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 879, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1605461987}
review:
It takes the premise which worked quite well in Hiragana War and vastly improves upon it! The combat is better (though I would appreciate some more randomizing with the enemies that appear, both in terms of more old characters being brought up for refreshing and not repeating the same groupings of characters), the general gameplay is improved, and I really appreciated the amount of extra "quests" you could do to learn some vocab (though it'd be great if there was even more, as I found myself wanting more opportunities to practice reading and learning full words).

Overall, worth buying and a great study supplement. I really hope they make more educational games. Perhaps something more grammar and vocab-based next?

Note: the game does NOT assume that you've played Hiragana War (or even that you know hiragana), so don't feel like you have to have played it as well in order to enjoy this. However, if you do not know hiragana, I'd recommend checking it out first as the usual best order to learn is hiragana > katakana > kanji.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022399207', 'num_games_owned': 284, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 958, 'last_played': 1590330079}
review:
Отличный способ изучить Катакану, когда не знаешь с чего начать! Рекомендую перед этим пройти такую же игру но про Хирагану (или изучить где-то ещё).
Единственный ньюанс для русскоязычных игроков - на русский некоторые символы Катаканы (как и Хираганы) пишутся по-другому! Поэтому изучая по этой английской игре, потом (или сразу) сверяйте звуки с русскоязычной таблицей.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981141328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 331, 'last_played': 1593629140}
review: So far, so good. Much like "Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle," this title is choice for learning, memorizing, and becoming literate in Katakana. The story so far is quite good, though the playable characters/voice acting aren't to my personal taste (very cutesy and annoying style voice acting/character design). However, this does not detract from being able to learn with maximum efficiency, which is the point of the game. At a surprising $7, if you have any interest in becoming literate in Japanese, this is an enjoyable and proven place to start.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006824332', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 909, 'last_played': 1566907929}
review:
This is the second game in the "Learn Japanese to Survive!" series; I am writing this review after having completed all three games of the series.

Katakana are one of the writing systems of Japan, used for representing the sounds (rather than meanings) of words.  They represent the same sounds as hiragana, but are used for writing foreign loanwords - the meaning of many words written in katakana can often be guessed by sounding out the word, and recognising the foreign word it derived from.  In this game you have to defend against an army of monsters shaped like katakana by correctly identifying the sound of the characters.

There is a story, a map to explore, and combat against the monsters; these are much better developed than in the first game - the story is much more fun and the exploration is made much better by removing the randomness of encounters with monsters in favour of seeing them on screen before meeting them.  Unlike the other games in the series, you have to make some choices about the equipment to use, as different items emphasise different stats, though ultimately this doesn't make that much difference.  There are also some side quests, which try to teach you a little about Japan, and are sufficiently distracting.

Of course the main point to the game is teach you to read katakana. The game teaches you to recognise the characters, it also shows you how to write them, though there is no assessment of writing, so it is entirely up to you if you want to practise writing or not.

In summary, this is a big step up on the previous game in terms of game mechanics, making for much smoother game play.  It is still a little basic compared to "non-educational" games, but the main point is to learn katakana in a fun way and in this it certainly succeeds and I would recommend it to anyone looking to learn these Japanese characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008367456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1488, 'last_played': 1587776998}

author: {'steamid': '76561198868336904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 997, 'last_played': 1611193990}

author: {'steamid': '76561198003508577', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 719, 'last_played': 1586885855}
review:
Finished this after Hiragana Battle. Although you don't need to play one to get the other, I think it's best to go Hiragana then Katakana because it builds a lot on what you learn as well, refreshing two for the price of one. 

Overall, I was impressed by how much MORE this game could have over its predecessors: So much more character! (The skits and friend scenes along with the voices really bring the charming characters to life! I almost lost track of what I SHOULD be paying attention to, almost wishing it was a dating sim instead, or at least in part!). I adore how fun the developers have made learning Japanese in such an easy, effective and memorable way!

The end battle was easier than the Hiragana one, but I love the stinger at the end for the Kanji War, which I'm off to shortly do. I honestly can't believe just how much progress has been made over the course of two games, how much Learning Japanese to Survive has evolved and I absolutely adore it. Thank you again for this educational game, the only way it seems to make self-motivated Japanese-learning stick in my brain! Ja, mata ne!

author: {'steamid': '76561198977480000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1618708112}
review:
I found this game very enjoyable to learn Japanese. I already knew katakana in general, but because I do not use it as much as the hiragana, I had trouble telling apart certain katakana characters, hence I bought this game to help me with those few katakana characters I get mixed up with.

This is perfect for someone just starting to learn Japanese. I recommend you get the trilogy. £15 for 3 games that will teach you hiragana, katakana and something like 200 kanji is really a bargain and it is really a fun way to learn the scripts and there is a lot of repetition.

The game is very well made. The graphics are awesome, the kinda old school type, reminds me of "Zelda". That is the thing, games in the past were like this, very interesting and unique. The music is really nice. The audio for the vocals of the characters are very good quality, though the guy from Australia has an American accent, same with the Russian girl, same with the German girl. Would be even more unique if the voice actors were from the specific countries the characters represent to give it that extra feel to the game. The story is very interesting.

I really hope the developers make more in these serious. Some suggestions:

1) Make a game focused on learning vocabulary, loads of vocabulary.

2) Make the next part of the kanji learning.

3) Make a game of that sort that will teach all the particles and their different uses with sentences and other grammar etc.

Thank you for what you have made already. Great job!

author: {'steamid': '76561198307360004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1265, 'last_played': 1592279608}

author: {'steamid': '76561198165837142', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1585964277}
review:
This is a somewhat difficult game to review, but ultimately I DO recommend it for anyone wanting to brush on their Katakana or are first learning it.  Here's my pros, cons and bugs:

Good:
+Good way to practice Katakana
+Some of the characters are enjoyable and the voice acting for most is pretty good
+Art style is engaging and fun
+The story was good and tied in Katakana very well

Bad:
+I feel that this game could've been fleshed out a lot more, and it felt too short
+Due to the above, some things felt half-baked in and it really would enhance the game to actually utilize those things (i.e. affection)
+Some characters were....annoying.
+There were a couple bugs that need to be fixed (see below)

Bugs:
+I Played the Mac version and it wasn't until I didn't get my first achievement that I did some research as to why. I then found out that the developer made a statement there was a problem with the syncing....please fix this.
+Some lag in the final battles (enemies and bosses)
+Cutscenes that occur when you reach top affection level with characters glitch out (nothing crashed, but I was convinced it was going to)

author: {'steamid': '76561197995782746', 'num_games_owned': 1051, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1584234134}
review:
- Is it viable as a stand-alone game?
Absolutely, you don't need any knowledge of the predecessor or any hiragana knowledge.

- Does it work as a method to learn katana?
Absolutely, yes, when you successfully finish the game you will have no trouble to read katakana.

- Is it fun as a RPG?
Well, it's short and very basic, so as a PRG game it could satisfy absolute beginners in that genre, but nothing more.

---------------
What does it better than the predecessor?
- Better graphics, better artwork
- FAR better music
- Better battle system (the action choice is not done for one character at a time on their turn and not for all characters at the beginning of the round)
- The enemies are now visible and can be avoided which is a big plus
- Character affection system for those who care about such things
- Better kana selection system in the battle

What does it worse than the predecessor?
- The final boss and the final 'dungeon' phase is way simpler, less challenging and not interesting at all
- The story seems to be even more cliche 

It is still a great learning game, very much recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198076296740', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 698, 'last_played': 1583300030}
review:
[h1] Katakana War! Review [/h1]

LJTS! KW is a big improvement compared to its previous game, Hiragana Battle. While I do say that it is improved, it still is an average and honestly I can even say its a good game, but not the best in the world (but hey not much you can do with RPG maker and its creativity) The following review will go into comparing the two games a bit and what I say is the Pros, the Neutral, and the Cons.

[b] Comparison [/b]

So after playing the previous game (Hiragana Battle) I took time off between playing (about a month) and then played this game within a 2 week span of 40 min to 1 hour sessions. Hear is what I can say about this game.

Comparing this game to Hiragana, this game improves in many ways and basically fixes a few of criticisms I had of the last game (such as the ending in Hiragana was bad and some other elements. Further detail in that review)

While in my last review I said that HB was a good secondary help to learn hiragana, this game for some reason I used it more as a primary, but maybe because of the help of HB maybe made it easier to use im not sure. I still will in repeat memorizing both scripts as time goes on just to keep it in long term memory.

[u] Pros +: [/u]
Study Guides: Just like HB, this game has study guides in-game in case needed to remember some characters. I only ever needed it about 2 times with characters like ス and ヌ or ワ and フ.

Level Design: the level design is pretty good in this game. Only thing that kinda sucked is a area in the game is a 1 time deal to learn the "Na" series so only way to reinforce it was study guides or challenge tower.

More Content: this game has a lot more content than HB had, considering I beat HB in 8 hours and it took this game 11 hours, ranging from the Challenge tower, a bit more side-quests, and a affection system (which is good but also has a bit of flaws IMO, more on that later)

[u] Neutrals +- [/u]
Gameplay: For a RPG Maker game, the gameplay isn't too bad. As well as a improvement from HB, Magic has a better and actual usage. I can say combat in this game is practically the same from HB, just when you hit them, it will have the character written out and pronounced. IMO I am not a fan of the pronouncing part but I liked the writing out. and again, the battles like HB are not 100% random, the groups are somewhat the same 3-4 groups.

Story: like HB, this game's story is pretty average

Characters: I think the characters were pretty interesting in this game and better with having more than 4 party members to change out. But at the end, you will have the "Main team" that will basically be OP. The affection mechanic was cool to have companions gain extra stats which was cool, but easily exploitable thanks to a guide in the community. BUT the worst part about the characters IMO is the voice acting. I wasn't prepared for the voice acting and I personally didn't like it, especially one character had an annoying voice.

[u] Cons - [/u]
Voice Acting: as I explained I wasn't a fan of it and it wasn't professionally done so it threw me off at times.


All in all, this game is better than HB, but not the best game in the world. But I can say this game was a good learning tool.

[h1] Final Verdict: 7/10 [/h1]

tl;dr: This game is better than its predecessor but not by much. and IMO it was a good primary source but to others might be better as a secondary source

Update (3/7/2020): Lowered score by 1 point as IMO 8/10 felt too generous where 7 feels more right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025981970', 'num_games_owned': 412, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 973, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 973, 'last_played': 1582247108}
review:
Pod wieloma względami jest to prosty j-RPG wykonany w RPG Makerze. Bitwy są z początku średnio łatwe, a pod koniec gry robią się śmiesznie łatwe dzięki umiejętnościom specjalnym. Jednak tutaj najważniejszy jest aspekt edukacyjny. Naszymi przeciwnikami są potwory w kształcie znaków katakany. Podstawa metoda zadawania im obrażeń to dopasowanie do nich odpowiedniego dźwięku. I choć aby odblokować jedno z osiągnięć wymagane jest grindowanie, to w grze edukacyjnej jest to moim zdaniem zaleta; w końcu powtórki są ważne, żeby utrwalić wiedzę.

Gra okazjonalnie próbuje nas nauczyć paru słów i zwrotów, ale nigdy nie jesteśmy z tej wiedzy później sprawdzani (poza kilkoma zadaniami pobocznymi, gdzie mamy do rozwiązania jedynie króciutki quiz), a żeby sobie je poprzypominać, trzeba chodzić między NPC-ami rozsianymi po całej mapie. Nie są również sprawdzane nasze zapisywania znaków, ale nauczyciel pokazuje, w jakiej kolejności należy stawiać kreski i zachęca, abyśmy powtórzyli to w zeszycie.

Ogólnie rzecz mówiąc, polecam, jeśli chcesz nauczyć się czytać katakanę.

author: {'steamid': '76561198344468718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1581936794}
review: Great game, good idea on memorising katakana and a bit of Japanese. The final affection events are a bit slow to render and if you play well, the use of status items is pretty non existent. The challenge castle I feel is lacking as a battle area since its one hit to kill the enemies and two hits to kill one of your party members. A nice story and a good end game. Would recommend to those wanting to learn about katakana or in my case, have a bit of a refresher.

author: {'steamid': '76561198371456239', 'num_games_owned': 1081, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1655441510}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995298721', 'num_games_owned': 2566, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1580491942}
review:
I really wish there were a lot more educational games available on Steam. It feels pretty good being able to play a video game while also learning something worthwhile and valuable in real life (not that I go outside besides work). That being said, the "Learn Japanese to Survive" series are [b]more educational than they're games[/b], although they try really hard to be both at the same time, it's not working very well - the game part at least. The first thing I've noticed is how annoying the characters are, they use the lingo of a 12-year old and more importantly, they're all American and/or they speak English natively, rendering them kinda worthless if you're expecting to learn some vocabulary - sure there're sidequests that "teach" you vocab that include a native speaker pronouncing the words, but you're not gonna actually remember those unless you write them down and who wants to do that while playing a video game, you might as well just grab a Japanese textbook... But before that, let's talk about the story first. It's dumb and you should skip through it. OK, moving on.
The gameplay consists of study sessions where you learn characters used in combat against Obake ("monsters", read [O-ba-ke] or as the voice actors pronounce it, [Ohbahke] if you prefer the English way) in a somewhat streamlined way of playing, go and kill X monsters, go and rescue X... besides that, there're 20 very simple sidequests, [b]totaling 10ish hours to complete the game in its entirety[/b]. As is tradition in RPG-maker games, you're presented with a variety of items and equipment that no one really cares about as you're here to learn, not collect legendary loot.
To answer the question you're sure asking, because who the hell plays an educational game for the gameplay - am I actually gonna learn anything playing the series? I could answer with a yes or no, but that would be too simple and simplicity is for autists. In other words, [b]yes it is somewhat useful.[/b] 
To elaborate - for those who aren't profound weebs like myself, the Japanese language consists of three alphabets - Hiragana, covered by the first game of the series, Katakana and Kanji - partially covered by the third game and the most complicated of the alphabets (mostly Chinese characters). 
[b]Now the reason why I'm rating the Katakana game positively while I'm most likely never gonna play the other two games, is because Katakana is the least used of the three alphabets (exclusively for foreign words) and thus harder to practice[/b] as you'll encounter it less often compared to the other two alphabets and let's be honest, I'd do anything to avoid learning from textbooks and spending hours staring at Katakana, trying to remember the characters. I wish the game offered more ways to study besides the obvious "choose the right character" and "assign the character to its pronunciation", e.g. translating entire words, writing practice, etc.
So there you have it, the gameplay's pretty bad and the story's worse, but I'd still take this over a textbook. 5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198144857957', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1234, 'last_played': 1579975300}
review:
Very Creative  !!! 
( Amazing Learning Tool ! )
