author: {'steamid': '76561198018134069', 'num_games_owned': 211, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 752, 'last_played': 1577926524}
review:
Katakana War is awesome, and a huge improvement over the already good Hiragana Battle! Almost everything has been built upon to be bigger and better, from the art and music, to the writing, characters, and gameplay. Even the educational segments felt better. If you liked the first game, you'll be overjoyed with the experience in Katakana War and you won't want to miss it for the world. 

Katakana War seems to provide a better educational gameplay system, as the menus are cleaner and easier to navigate, and enemy encounters involve more variety in their kana. The problem of "memorizing" a group of kana and simply going through the motions is far less severe, as different areas are more likely to include kana from previous chapters as well as providing the challenge of the new kana you've learned. Since Katakana symbols are more similar to each other than the Hiragana symbols, it's more difficult and more rewarding for remembering and interpreting of what you've learned. I especially like how "older" kana are weaker than newer kana, and it continues to spice up the gameplay by having you fight the English alphabet, forcing you to find their Katakana equivalents (though I was disappointed that the game includes almost no instances of "phrase" making as what was seen at the end of Hiragana Battle, which is a step-down). Furthermore, the gameplay in general has more depth and appeal, as there are magical attacks that are actually worth using compared to just straight answers, and there's seven characters alongside the protagonist to play with--meaning that you get to mix and match parties based on your favourite characters. There's a "dating" simulation where you build friendship affinity to unlock abilities, more weapons, armour, and items, and a stat system which is easier to understand. Overall, it's just more fun to play.

The educational component is very similar to the first game, but because they can draw upon your hypothetical prior knowledge of Hiragana and the new Katakana you're picking up, they can share more words with you and provide the proper way to spell them. If I recall, Hiragana Battle would only write syllables in English if you didn't know them, and had almost no appearances from Katakana symbols. This game fixes that issue by simply having the kana "faded" out to indicate you haven't learned it yet, so you can still write it down in your notebook to get a headstart. It also mixes vocabulary written in Katakana with vocabulary written in Hiragana. If you wish to practice with a "flash card" system, it's easier thanks to the Challenge Castle, which pits you against foes that are defeated with a single hit, but are made up off all the Katakana you've learned thus far, and this is also useful for leveling friendship affinities. As I stated, I was disappointed it doesn't test your phrase-making and memorization of vocabulary, as this helps in reading Katakana overall, but I think it's a fitting successor to the last game.

There's more musical variety, an interesting mix of levels that are solely focused on Japan this time and not just a random fantasy backdrop, and the art has improved a ton. It could pass for something done by a genuine mangaka, rather than an amateur Westerner. One of my favourite details is the inclusion of heavy voice-acting. Though it's a mixed bag, with some awkward and strange acting, and variable mic quality, every actor puts so much energy into their role I can't help but grin like an idiot while I'm listening to it. Every character is so likeable, and their voice is such an inseparable part of their identity. It reminds me of the best JRPGs where you get attached to the characters from so many amusing exchanges, and you don't want to say goodbye. 

Learn Japanese to Survive is a sleeper, and well worth the price. If the games keep improving as much as Katakana War did, I cannot wait to try out Kanji Combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068596996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 645, 'last_played': 1577682727}
review: This one is much better than its predecessor, Hiragana Battle in terms of gameplay but all three of these series were still helpful with teaching everyone the basics of Hiragana, Katakana, and Kanji. I would recommend that you start with either Hiragana or Katakana since both of them are quite easy to learn then start transitioning to Kanji. Again, all three of these series were really helpful in memorizing Japanese characters and I would highly recommend everyone to play this game if you want to start learning how to read and write in Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108270275', 'num_games_owned': 825, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 1102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1102, 'last_played': 1573073809}
review:
Osaka est sous l'emprise des Obake, d'obscures créatures qui ont pris l'apparence de Katakana, conquérant l'archipel nippon. Avec l'aide d'un professeur d'anglais adoptant le rôle de sensei de japonais, un groupe de touristes étrangers devra apprendre les caractères japonais pour repousser leurs étranges ennemis ainsi que leurs alliés.

Learn Japanese To Survive! Katana War reprend les mécaniques de son prédécesseur, Hiragana Battle, afin d'initier le joueur au système d'écriture japonais. Cette fois-ci, au tour des caractères servant en retranscrire les mots et sonorités étrangères. À travers une série de courtes leçons, on sera mené à maîtriser les Hiragana, tout en apprenant un peu de vocabulaire, armé d'un bloc-notes et d'un bon crayon.

Le système de combat d'Hiragana Battle est repris pour ce second opus, agrémenté de quelques améliorations, comme des attaques automatiques au tour par tour, de nouveaux boss et des combats plus animés. L'apprentissage est d'autant plus facilité que les caractères appris dans les chapitres précédents reviennent couramment tout au long du jeu, et pas seulement ceux du chapitre en cours.

Ce petit JRPG des familles n'est en soit ni trop difficile, ni trop facile (selon notre capacité d'apprentissage bien sûr). Sinon, on peut toujours compter sur un peu de magie pour s'en sortir si on a un trou de mémoire. Le jeu est relativement court, se terminant en une bonne quinzaine d'heures si on prend le temps d'explorer le sol japonais et de compléter les quêtes qui nous sont offertes.

À noter que le jeu est entièrement en anglais, sans être d'un niveau trop complexe. Si vous avez aimé le précédent opus, ou que vous avez envie d'en apprendre un peu plus sur le japonais à votre rythme, ce jeu est pour vous!

review:
This game is basically the perfect sequel to the previous title, So many improvements... and to think it only has been the span of a year between games. It's surprising.
The graphics are superior, the artstyle is significantly better, the characters are more likeable, since this time you can actually befriend them. The fighting mechanics no longer rely on Random battles, which is the best improvement this sequel has going for it. It also took me a little longer to beat it, when I totally skipped some side quests.

Great game, and a really well done sequel. I totally recommend this game.

Good Improvements over the past game.

Having played the Hiragana version and being frustrated by it's combat system that made it very hard to win fights even if you knew all the characters I was hesitant about the Katakana version, however that concern was not required.

They have apparently taken on board feedback from the first game and the combat system has been greatly improved. Also the story has better grounding and characters.

review:
After 13 hours of gameplay I have learnt to read katakana. I did play Hiragana battle before I started here, so I knew what to expect. I did the same as I did with Hiragana battle, by writing down each character as I learnt them and also writing down some of the extra stuff.
My party was around level 26 when I finished the game, I didn't even need to grind any levels. They also added a challenge castle in which you can practice very easily.

The only problem I had with the game was that some of the side quests were difficult to find (I still have 2 missing). 

All I have left is Kanji combat, in which I don't know if I'm looking forward to it or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198185519011', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2513, 'last_played': 1649729328}
review:
Ok this game is real good (my favorite in the trilogy) and here's why

So first of all the actual Japanese learning portion of the game is fantastic it helps you learn katakana through giving you the lessons (through showing you the characters, showing you how to write it, and showing how to pronounce it) and you are required to understand the characters in order to beat the game (hence the name of the game and assuming you don't look up the answers which defeats the entire purpose). The game plays as an RPG and so you can enter in combat with Katakana characters, allowing you to remember the characters in an entertaining way.

In terms of a functioning game in all aspects this game is great: good music, good characters, story is alright, and overall it's been a great journey, learning Katakana and having fun in the process.

One thing I recommend is that if you're playing this game to learn Japanese, play Learn Japanese to Survive! Hiragana Battle before this game and if you want Learn Japanese to Survive! Kanji Combat after this game.

Hf gamers. B )

author: {'steamid': '76561198410080038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2864, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2862, 'last_played': 1659059391}
review:
Hello Everyone,

This is going to be a review of developer Sleepy Duck’s second instalment in there three part Learn Japanese to survive series that helps teach the basic aspects of the three different Japanese writing systems. In “Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana Wars” the player will be learning about the Katakana writing system. Hope you enjoy. 
Now in the words of Daisuke Sensei “Its Study Time!”

Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana Wars is a classic style RPG game that focuses on teaching the player the Basic structure of the Japanese Katakana system. The game does this by having the player participate in ten study sessions where they will learn the 46 Basic katakana characters (which are called Gojuon) along with 20 dakuon, and 5 handakuon (these are modified forms of some of the katakana characters). In the game it also mentions 1 sokuon and 36 yoon characters however, this dimension of the katakana system is not focused on as the player engages in gameplay, so it can only be considered as a side note in the game. There are also different vocabulary words that the play has the option of learning in the lessons as well as during side quest but after these words are mentioned they do not have a specific purpose in the game. Throughout the game’s lessons/side quest it also mentions hiragana characters but does not focus on them since the introduction of these characters were done in their first game “Learn Japanese to Survive Hiragana Battle”. The main aspect of the katakana system that is focused on is Gojuon, Dakuon, and Handakuon. From my experience the game explains this portion of the Katakana writing system rather well and it helps make the memorization of the characters seem slightly more engaging than just memorizing the characters from a book. With that being said, I would say that this game is for novice Japanese learns or intermediate learners that want a referrer of some of the Katakana characters. This game is not made for you become a fluent speaker over night or for you to decide that this will be the only instruction that you will need to make your next big trip to Japan. In short, this game is either a supplemental resource to help you learn katakana characters for the first time or a supplemental resource to help you to reinforce the Katakana characters that you all ready know. Regardless, if you decide to purchase this game because you/a friend/a family member wants to learn Japanese, you/they will still need to buy other books, flashcards, video tutorial, learning software, games, or other supplemental materials if you/they are serious about learning Japanese. Now that is out of the way let’s get to the games story.

The story of “Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana War” occurs ten years after the events of “Learn Japanese to Survive! Hiragana Battle”. The story begins with four foreign travels that enter the city of Osako Japan with absolutely no knowledge of the Japanese language. Suddenly a series of homicidal spirits that have taken the form of Katakana have started attacking the city with the hope of destroying the people of Japan. The spirits that have emerged can only be defeated by being properly pronounced. This leads to these travels finding a teacher that helps them learn the Katakana writing system in order to help them save the country of Japan. With this being the main primus of the story, it becomes quickly apparent that there is a huge contradiction in this story’s plot and that is “Why do people from Japan need to be saved by foreigners that know nothing of their language when Japan has a country full of fluent speakers?”. It is possible that this plot element could have easily been corrected by changing the setting of the game to a different country that does not speak Japanese. If this was done it is possible that the story would have had a stronger plot. I understand the game was also trying to show players a few cities in Japan but because this is Japan that this crisis is occurring, I found it pulled me out of the plot of the story more than I would have liked. Besides that, I found that the story was enjoyable enough to keep me playing and I found it had a slight ting of humour along the way. Next is the gameplay.

The gameplay in this game has the player engage in turn-based combat where the player has the option to Answer (normal attack), use magic (special attack), or use items in battle in order to defeat their opponent (Katakana Characters) in battle.  The player has the option of fighting in a party of 1-4 in game characters with a choose of seven different characters that you can choose from. The enemies in the game can inflict four negative side effects to the player while attacking on specific levels in the game. These side effects are bleed (drains health), poison (drains health), restrict (restricts action), silence (restricts magic). There are 10 chapters in the game that you have the option to engage in three phases before you move on to the next stage. The first is the lesson stage that the player learns around 5-3 new Katakana characters along with their modified forms. The game focuses on teaching the player how to pronounce the Katakana, the proper stroke order, and the function of the modifiers that are placed on the Katakana. In the lesson phase you also occasionally have vocabulary lessons that teach you 5 words using Katakana and 5 using Hiragana characters.

The second is the side quest phase that the player has the option to look around for side quest/restock health items/purchasing equipment/rest to recover energy. If side quest are completed you will receive a few bonus points that can be used to increase your entire parties level. It is also during this phase of the gameplay that the player gets to view friendship events with your party members. The affection system in the game essentially increases with the players in your party each time you engage in battle. There are a total of three friendship events that give the members in your party increased stats each time you make it to one of the three heart events that each of the 7 characters have. Once one of your party members makes it to their final heart event they will have a moment of enlightenment, which will change their class classification and give them one new special ability. I find that it is also worth mentioning that if a player wants to review any of the material that they learned during their lessons/side quest this would be the phase to do it since all the material can be reviewed at this time. There is also a practice castle that will unlock once you get so far into the game that allows the player to just practice their retention of the materials that they covered with various enemy types. 

The third phase of a chapter is the battle phase where the player has to complete the mission objectives to get to the final boss of the chapter that has multiple health bars of various katakana characters. Once a chapter is complete your player returns to their apartment to rest and start the cycle again. All the equipment that the player can acquire are either purchased, rewards from side quest, and found in chest. There are equitable item drops from the katakana that are defeated, the only thing that is dropped occasionally are shard fragments that can be converted into potions that can permanently increase a character’s stats. Unlike some other games of the RPG genre there are no item drops from specific enemies that gives the player an additional incentive to engage in battle with a specific enemy type. 

To be continued in comments.........

author: {'steamid': '76561198043887256', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 729, 'last_played': 1561680399}
review: If you want to learn Katakana in a gaming environment, then here it is. It has pretty sub gameplay, story, and music but for the purpose of learning Katakana, it gives you a story to keep grinding for - and you have to learn to progress. I'd pay this each time to learn katakana in 10 hours anyday.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020624321', 'num_games_owned': 584, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 799, 'last_played': 1560909364}
review:
An okay RPG, probably made with rpg maker(hey, not a bad thing, i know it's potential) that's an helpful tool in learning the katakana writting system.

I already knew hiragana completely before playing this game. I have not played LEARN JAPANESE TO SURVIVE! HIRAGANA WAR i thought it would be a bit pointless to me although i may play it at some point.

I didn't know much into katakana and was struggling to difference many of them. I've been learning japanese for a year and a half now with no true appliance to katakana.

This game sure helps you memorize them. Love how the final items in the game are also in katakana so you could try and read em out for yourself.

I feel like this game was not necessary to my japanese library, but it helped as well.

For the game itself its really just your typical rpg maker game with not too much in. You probably won't care about the story of the game either and that's okay, you're not here for that either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081823292', 'num_games_owned': 807, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1564266994}
review: This could of really done without the voice acting in the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043675871', 'num_games_owned': 98, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 669, 'last_played': 1559204055}
review:
There is some improvement from previous game.
It still has a lot of problems too.
Story is more worse than in Hiragana war. 
There is at first glance good affection system but at the end of the game when you want to max out last character affection you have to grind few pointless hours. 
There is no difficulty settings, so i killed last boss without using a single skill or potion. Compared to previous game this doesn't even include any special boss mechanic. 
I've experianced some lags when opening "answer" attack, and massive lags every time when maxing out affection event occurs.
I thought few times that autor would create great game if he was working in some Unity like engine.
There isn't much games like this for learning Japanese, so i would recommend this for purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022264921', 'num_games_owned': 249, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1558984806}
review:
Someone gifted me this (thanks?), and I already know the language far and beyond anything this could ever hope to teach me, so this is mostly a review for the game itself (I wouldn't recommend this as a learning tool either though, for a number of reasons).

By itself, the plot doesn't make any sense at all. Oh no! Katakana are attacking Japan and the only way to defeat them is to...pronounce them correctly. In Japan. I'm pretty sure a threat like that would realistically be a non-issue, lol.

It is kind of amusing though, once you realize that it's just a bad SMT fangame made by weebs in RPG Maker pretending to be a Japanese learning game (replace the katakana monsters with SMT demons, and you'll get what I mean). The writing is about what you'd expect in a fangame too, and the devs put less effort into faking nationalities than a low-budget anime. All in all, I'd only recommend it if you're one of those people that like playing bad RPG Maker games for shits and giggles, but there's a lot of those you could play for free instead, so idk.

I'm going to finish playing it, but only because someone else paid for it and I feel obligated to.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019576097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 322, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1540177254}
review:
[h1]As a way to learn katakana, it's ok. But as a game, it's way too slow...[/h1]

I get it, the whole point here is to master this japanese alphabet. However, if you already know it, you'll get bored too fast.

Plays like a SNES Final Fantasy, the only twist is, you have to choose the correct romanji to attack the kanas (the game monsters).
Think I'll check Kanji Combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133805927', 'num_games_owned': 241, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1486399521}
review: If you are completely new to Katakana, this game would probably be a good (all be it slow) way to learn Katakana, although when I bought it I already knew quite a bit, so starting right back at the basics was really boring...

author: {'steamid': '76561198083974456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 1403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1232, 'last_played': 1616667471}
review:
Отличная игра, обучающая японской азбуке Катакана!

Я её прошел на запись:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J0wtFfKMMP8&list=PLkGyZcxsQFo2qTSbw43CRdye9BcfTMsNT&index=2

Из достоинств:
1) игра действительно развлекает и играется как обычная J-RPG !
2) игра увлекает. То есть Я ставил задачу играть по часику в день, но часто увлекался и играл по 3 часа.
3) за месяц действительно учит Катакане и можно начинать читать японские надписи
4) также игра учит некоторым фразам и основным глаголам, но их запомниать сложнее.

Из недостатков:
1) затянутые диалоги, которые под конец хочется пропускать. Можно было удалить 30% диалого и только лучше бы стала игра!
2) разарботчики просто ничего не ответили на Мое предложение о переводе игры на русский язык, за 50% продаж в зоне РУ. В любом случае они бы получили дополнительные деньги, а так - просто глупо отказались от денег и не дали заработать тоже. Потому игра ТОЛЬКО НА АНГЛИЦКОМ.
3) нет повторения слов, потому слова и фразы запоминаются сложнее, чем иероглифы Катаканы.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041788458', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1551969238}
review:
Better then hiragana in terms of combat (its faster so you have more time to actually learn)
story and character are just as cringy as in the last game.
overall a very good learning game, especially for the lazy people like me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038284321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 925, 'last_played': 1551658813}
review:
Pros:
-Great resource for people wanting to learn or refresh their Katakana
-Side quests are great for vocabulary, especially if you've learned hiragana
-Major improvements over the previous Hiragana game in terms of combat
-Boss music was good

Cons:
-Story was OK, nothing special
-Combat seemed very easy. I guess this helps people with no Katakana background be able to make mistakes in combat, but if you know your stuff you will literally never die or need to use items.

Overall great game

author: {'steamid': '76561198010548985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1011, 'last_played': 1549834946}
review: Katakana War, like its predecessor Hiragana Battle, is a good learning tool for people looking for a fun way to learn the Japanese "alphabet". The affection system added into this game feels a lot like a traditional Japanese dating sim, but without the dating and adult scenarios. It's a little repetitive, but considering this is a LEARNING game, that's to be expected. The game does decently well with drilling the individual Katakana into your head, though it IS missing the character for the Japanese (or in this case, foreign) V: ヴ. It uses the character while mentioning different combinations, so it isn't completely absent, but it won't be in your drills. This game really shines in its vocabulary, giving an absolute TON of new words in both Katakana and Hiragana. Overall, a wonderful play that I will be coming back to again and again for reviews, and recommending my daughter who is interested in the Japanese language try it too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004173934', 'num_games_owned': 297, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 708, 'last_played': 1549307550}
review:
[h1][Septième évaluation] 
Pour consulter d'autres évaluations dans la même veine, rendez-vous sur  [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34625938/]ma page de curateur[/url]. Bonne lecture.[/h1]

Yay, un RPG éducatif !

Pour vous donner plus de contexte : je me suis mis en tête d’apprendre le japonais avant de partir au pays du soleil levant, et… j’ai un peu trop rechigné à apprendre les différents alphabets jusqu’à présent (faut dire qu’ils ne nous facilitent pas vraiment la tâche avec leurs systèmes de symboles complexes). Pourtant, vous vous doutez bien qu’une fois les clefs de la compréhension écrite en main, il vous est largement plus facile d’apprendre du vocabulaire, d’échanger avec des internautes à l’autre bout du monde et de traduire des dōjins frivoles (ce que je ne fais pas, cela va de soi… enfin, pas pour l’instant). C’est donc avec cet objectif en ligne de mire que je me suis lancé dans l’aventure Katakana et son bachotage relativement supportable grâce à « Learn Japanese To Survive! ».

J’avoue, il fallait y penser. 

À l’instar de nombreux autres J-RPG avec un système de combat tour par tour, vous devez terrasser vos ennemis et triomphez de boss redoutables grâce, non seulement, à vos compétences physiques et magiques… mais aussi et surtout grâce à vos connaissances dûment développées lors de « pseudo-cours » en classe, dispensés par votre sensei des temps modernes. Au programme, 5 signes par leçon (10 dans certains cas) et une petite aventure pour mettre en pratique ce que vous avez appris. Les objectifs sont très simples : vaincre X ennemis, se rendre à tel endroit, vaincre untel… et pour avancer, vous devrez donner l’équivalent sonore des signes Katakana qui vous agressent. Évidemment, plus vous apprendrez, plus le spectre de monstres deviendra large. Prenez des notes au fur et à mesure des leçons, cela vous évitera de passer 20 tours à chercher l’équivalent pertinent parmi une cinquantaine de propositions.

En dehors de l’aspect éducatif, de quelques anecdotes sur le Japon et d’expressions/mots passe-partout, ne vous attendez pas une histoire et des graphismes de qualité. Le jeu a été créé sur RPG Maker avec les ressources de base, l’univers est ultra-plat/simplifié et les dialogues insipides/ennuyants. Pour tout dire, je me contente de spammer les boutons « Skip » lorsque les personnages discutent entre eux, et n’ai aucune honte à l’avouer. Je pense que l’accent n’a pas du tout été mis sur le fond, et que seule la forme est synonyme de qualité (puisque l’apprentissage progressif des caractères nous pousse à terminer le jeu).

Je recommande ce jeu uniquement pour son aspect « pratique ». Il n’est pas extraordinaire en soi, et ceux qui apprennent les signes en ligne n’y verront probablement aucune utilité. Pour ma part, cela me permet de faire du bachotage et d’enfoncer (au marteau) ces foutus Katakana qui se ressemblent à deux-trois détails près !

Ce que j’apprécie :
💹Le système d’apprentissage, plutôt efficace.
💹Le contenu « bonus » (guide d’écriture PDF et l’art book)

Ce qui aurait pu être amélioré :
💢L’histoire, les décors et les personnalités des personnages.

author: {'steamid': '76561198802663391', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1548019979}

author: {'steamid': '76561198169157549', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1548881608}
review:
So far, better than the previous installment, but I have one question. Why is it that in Japan, they would have any major problems defeating these monsters and have to rely on foreigners who don't understand Japanese? Think about it. In order to defeat the monsters, you have to pronounce the syllables each symbol represents. You average Japanese child could defeat these monsters. Holy crap. This is the equivalanet of English alphabet monsters invading an English speaking country. I'd be able to defeat those when I was 2 years old, since I was already reading at that time.      

Okay, onto the real review.      

Graphics have improved. Slightly better tilesets. Custom portraits. The enemies look nicer.      

Voice acting is here! It sounds corny and not believable, but it's still nice to have.      

The gameplay has improved. Slightly more treasure chests for exploration. There's a visible queue for every charcter's turn, and each character does the action right after you select it, instead of you selecting all the actions and then waiting. When you attack a katakana symbol, there is an audio sound and a visual representation of the stroke order, making it that much easier to remember the symbols.      

Overall, a good game if you want to learn katakana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035555701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1543940084}
review:
Es un  RPG cuyo formato de pelea me recuerda a los primeros Final Fantasy.
Es entretenido y aprendes mientras juegas, conforme más se avanza, más complejos se hace, aunque no deja de ser un juego bastante sencillito.

De cara a aprender Katakana, quizás funcionen mejor las reglas nemotécnicas de autores de libros como Remembering the Kanji.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075822074', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1237, 'last_played': 1545973487}
review: Отличный способ освоить японский даже если вы не знаете английского (гугл транслейта под рукой более чем достаточно).

author: {'steamid': '76561198004519882', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1545590780}
review:
If you want to learn katakana, just pick any other method. This is just a typical turn-based JRPG with all its negatives. Mainly it's sooo boring. First you learn five syllables - a,i,u,e,o - which is simple enough, but still you have to win 10 awfully boring battles where you must repeatedly cast these 5 basic letters. During 9th battle one of my characters died and I thought that he will resurrect as is usual in similar games, but no - my second character was left alone in 10th battle and died as well. And then I found out that your progress is NOT automatically saved and I stood all the way back before the 1st battle -- UARRGH -- UNINSTALL.
Plus the graphics looks like something from SNES or Gameboy Color. Terrible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198210220596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 8515, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2612, 'last_played': 1635961901}
review: I think my hours on this game speaks for itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140308190', 'num_games_owned': 753, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1534941694}
review:
Ludic and pretty efficient way to learn Katakana. 
Many improvements have been made on the game design compared to the previous game (Hiragana), as for example the sorting of the Katakana in the "attack choice" menu (5 rows, 1 for each vowel). 
Still, some game design mistakes remain (I think you could emphasis the learning and give less place to the gameplay as the purpose why we play the game is learning, and the fun is just an addition to make the learning process easier).
Well if you want to learn Katakana you'll surely enjoy this game. I'd recommand that you start with Hiragana tho', as they are even more used (but both are necessary in the end).

author: {'steamid': '76561197967039541', 'num_games_owned': 410, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1505658262}

author: {'steamid': '76561198073401688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2227, 'last_played': 1587226758}
review:
This is a very good learning game. However, if you use notes AND do every single side mission and loot every box, the game will become very easy very quick. I recommend you make a choise between using a notebook and 100% completion.
EDIT: If you get graphical issues like screen tearing and flickering, try using it in windowed mode.
There are more than one way to run a "fake fullscreen mode" that makes the game look like full screen mode, but have the performance of windowed mode

author: {'steamid': '76561198004838476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1658234003}
review:
На данный момент, лучший интерактивный учебник иностранного языка в принципе.
После прохождения(причем не пробежал и забыл, а именно сидения с тетрадкой и учебы хотябы по 2 часа в день) всех 3-х(на данный момент) игр можно спокойно и самостоятельно садиться за みんなの日本語. But, the main problem is... that this game is fully English. Without it, don't bother yourself. =3

author: {'steamid': '76561198054437136', 'num_games_owned': 512, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 627, 'last_played': 1543444203}
review:
Neutralna opinia (negatyw, bo 92% na+).
Gra o charakterze edukacyjnym, biorąca za "główne" zadanie nauczyć gracza znaków katakany, czyli japońskiego pisma używanego do zapisu nazw z innych języków. 
Tych znaczków najlepiej się uczyć poprzez powtarzanie i twórcy tej serii postanowilii użyć RPG Maker VX czy tam nowszy program i powtarzać tobie mocno uproszczone kolejności, bez kierunków kresek w każdym znaku. 
Powyższa wada prowadzi do tego, że tak naprawdę uczysz się tylko czytać katakanę. W zasadzie i tak lepiej zrobić sobie zeszycik na znaczki, więc jest sensowne minimum... 
Jest fabuła poprowadzona w stylu anime z gaidzinami i senpaiem uczącym ich katakany, aby niszczyć inwazyjne obake.
Głosy są okropne, amerykańskie- nawet senpai straszy swoim "maj nejm is dajske". Najwięcej ich w intrze, minimum w dialogach,  w nauce są TYLKO przy znakach i słowach, więc użerasz się z idiotycznymi wstawkami niezwiązanymi z napisami i również tylko czytasz przy lekcji (a potem w dialogach gadają jak to fajnie ich Daisuke uczy etc. xD ).
Są minimalne elementy visual novel- scenki co ileś punktów znajomości zdobywanych po walkach, straszące przybliżeniem (gejoza alert).
Balans walk słaby- na planszach po jednej nauce masz przeciwników 95% z ostatniej lekcji, a ci z poprzednich są na hita. 
Robienie aczika na znajomość ze wszystkimi wymaga ode mnie walczenia na konkretnym etapie nauki, bo postacie po za drużyną nie levelują jak w normalnych jRPG-ach i powtory były by za silne potem. Robię to na dodatek na najłatwiejszych znaczkach, f- (mimo, że to praktycznie 15 znaków). 
Niby jest Challenge Castle, z potworkami na 1 HP, ale szybkością niemałą, i do tego są czasami literowe (romaji) więc szukasz idiotycznie znaku, bo wymowa łatwa. I do tego kapsuła regenerująca wszystko...
Dlaczego neutral, sam nie wiem, tak samo dlaczego w to gram, zamiast zrobić ww. miejsce na odręczne pismo. 
-70% to sensowna cena, mówiąca sama za siebie.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978440900', 'num_games_owned': 1698, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2353, 'last_played': 1589152594}
review: A very fun way to learn Japanese Katakana characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061815256', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1515937216}
review:
A forma que esse jogo usa pra ensinar é incrível. Aprendi Katakana em poucos dias!
É absurdamente inovador!

author: {'steamid': '76561198135018057', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 9918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8857, 'last_played': 1544725274}
review: Игра, которая действительно помогает выучить катакану. а заодно не забыть английский. Приятное оформление, персонажи не раздражают. Кроме того, геймплей намного удобнее по сравнению с предыдущей игрой разработчиков - Hirgana Battle.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198020473811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 526, 'last_played': 1541182991}

author: {'steamid': '76561198029266683', 'num_games_owned': 630, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1547547044}
review:
Fantastic addition to a great educational series. Fun, with a cute and engaging narrative, while also being a great resource for drilling your katakana learning. It helps if you played the first game or already studied Japanese before coming here (especailly learning your hiragana). But if this is somehow your starting point, it will do its best to guide you along. 

The only real downside to this game is that it was made SO WELL in comparrison to the first game in the series. While Hiragana Battle is great in its own right, the game is very old and clunky, and has not aged well. It feel like comparing one of the classic Final Fantasy games to something more modern in that series, like Final Fantasy VI or VII. With Katakana War, the game is fairly well optimized, with lots of quality of life improvements that are non-existent in its predecessor: no more random encounters, more simple and fluid leveling system, achievements, an endless dungeon for easy drilling of everything you've learned, and even lots of scenes that are fully voice-acted, which was a extremely pleasant surprise. 

This all means that if this is your first time engaging with the series, it will be REALLY hard to go back and play the first game after this, without all those quality of life additions. So it's recommended that you start with Hiragana Battle before Katakana War, and tough out learning your hiragana before you move on to the katakana edition. Which, honestly, is the more appropriate way to learn the language anyway, so you're doing yourself no harm by starting with Hiragana Battle. Once you graduate to the sequel, you'll be pleasantly surprised by how much the team has been able to develop the series, and excited for their upcoming Kanji release.

author: {'steamid': '76561198262862967', 'num_games_owned': 205, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1539289869}
review: This entry in the series is much improved over the first one. You can see the enemies in the over-world this time versus random encounters. Although, the friendship/affection events meant to echo dating simulator-type gameplay felt silly. I enjoyed the voice acting and the style of how each character was drawn and how they all came from different places and their personalities. One thing this game lacked was  putting to use the words you learned as vocabulary to use in combat like the first game. That would've been an improvement.  If you're learning katakana for the first time, I would once again recommend a notebook and pencil. But since I already knew hiragana and katakana, the game was very easy. It took me about 8 hours to complete everything minus getting everyone's affection up to 500. I liked that there was Steam achievements for this game. I wished all the members of your party leveled up with you, though, so you wouldn't be stuck using the same members you chose at the beginning of the game just to avoid hours and hours more of grinding (and yes, I know there were bonus points available, but I didn't use them). I also found the final boss of the first game just a bit harder than this one, because of the use of actual words used to beat the boss. Also, the characters felt deeper than the first game. Also, since everyone's coming from a different country, it would have been great if everyone had an accent speaking in English. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198241039650', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1537301756}
review:
Don't get me wrong when I'm saying this. This game is awful, probably one of the worst games I've ever played. The story sucks, the battles are pretty much just a rip-off pokemon battle, I wanna kill myself when I hear the voice acting, controlls works..

Tho what you learn from this game is on a whole different level. I've been studying Japanese at the Stockholm university for a month now and been having troubble reading katakana, got recomended this game from a friend who had played the hiragana verion of it and thought it helped. This is probably the first and last time I'll get a game because of school reasons. But just, wow, you learn a lot, and fast from it.

To sum it up:
-Game sucks. If you want a good game, this is not for you
-Fantastic learner. If you want to learn Japanese (Katakana), this is for you


Oh yeah!
This is also pretty much a dating simulator if you want that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129188230', 'num_games_owned': 1565, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 1297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1297, 'last_played': 1536614683}
review: i went into this super pressed for time cause i had a katakana test in a week and i could barely read any of the characters. now, two days later, ive beaten the game and ive been able to memorize all 46 characters! i love this series a lot honestly. being a first year japanese major, i need all the help i can get to memorize everything. of course, having 6 years of experience with chinese helps with kanji, but not katakana or hiragana. i now know all 46 katakana and all 46 hiragana thanks to this series, though, and im sure the kanji game will help me tons with the japanese pronunciations of everything!! i'd seriously recommend this if you want to learn japanese for fun or youre taking courses for it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198132030143', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1535327092}

author: {'steamid': '76561198215640665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1541434754}
review:
Совершенно бесподобная игра, как и ее предшественница по хирагана. С точки зрения геймплея это очень непритязательная к игроку РПГ - не нужно выбирать тонны шмота, чтобы пройти игру, сверяя характеристики: если тебе что-то нужно, оно все равно упадет.
С точки зрения пользы для обучения: если не прописывать иероглифы, как тебя просят об этом авторы игры, какие-то вещи не запомнятся. И в принципе знаки, которые ты проходишь в самом начале игры (и встречаешь чаще) запоминаются лучше, чем самые последние слоги. С их идентификацией в дальнейшем могут возникнуть проблемы. К счастью, есть тренировочный режим, где можно укрепиться в этом знании, если хочется делать это внутри игры. 
Если вы уже знаете кану, игра покажется вам скучной из-за объяснения уже пройденного материала - но это все еще довольно милая казуальная RPG в японском стиле.
Отсутствие поддержки русского не угнетает, тем более что английская транскрипция, кажется, все же ближе к аутентичному японскому произношению, нежели транскрипция по Поливанову. Если вы давно хотели потыкаться в японский, но не знаете с чего начать, и кана вас отпугивает - победите ее в Hiragana и Katakana war, а дальше решайте, чего делать с новообретенным знанием.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201157027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 892, 'last_played': 1545342683}

author: {'steamid': '76561198308931305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1240, 'last_played': 1523579317}
review:
In terms of gameplay, like its predecessor Hiragana Battle, Katakana War utilizes the repetitive style of an RPG to practice sets of Katakana. Because of this, I would recommend players who tend to grind and have some serious determination toward remembering all the Katakana to buy this. Having been through this rodeo before with Hiragana Battle, memorizing the Katakana was pretty easy. Just time-consuming.

Happily, this game improves upon Hiragana Battle with wonderful art of all the characters, voice acting (which I admit is sometimes cringy, but heartwarming all the same), and a little bit of visual novel action too. It was pretty fun getting to know all the characters PLUS getting the rewards when I totally befriended them. There's also a visual display of the turn system, so you don't have to memorize every character's speed stat (which gets a bit confusing with 6 different characters). There's tons of other gameplay details too, but those aren't as important as the Katakana learning of course.

Unfortunately the achievements only work for Windows users, so I'm going to have to go back and replay the game, but on the bright side I can practice my Katakana even more!

author: {'steamid': '76561198029615849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1536651038}
review:
Les katakanas m'ont poser plus de problèmes que les hiraganas. Ce jeu est juste excellent pour apprendre et maîtriser un des 3 systèmes d'écriture japonais.
Il  y a tout, l'ordre des tracés, la prononciation, les "accents" s'il y en a.

Le fait que ce soit un RPG et qu'il faille retenir les katakanas pour progresser dans le jeu rend d'autant plus efficace l'apprentissage. De plus, les quêtes secondaires permettent d'apprendre du vocabulaire japonais par thème, ce qui est un plus très agréable.

Je conseille très fortement ce jeu, mais n'oubliez pas de pratiquer en parallèle sur des cahiers le tracé de chaque Katakana car cela reste très important.

PS: le jeu est en anglais, si vous n'êtes pas très bon ce n'est pas très grave, mais vous ne comprendrez peut-être pas certaines explications lors de certains cours sur des katakanas précis.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121161049', 'num_games_owned': 313, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 871, 'last_played': 1527971337}
review:
[i]Up ahead info: I'm basing of many points in comparison to the predecessor of this series ("[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/438270/Learn_Japanese_To_Survive_Hiragana_Battle/]LJTS: Hiragana Battle[/url]")![/i]

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ you learn the whole japanese Katakana alphabet
+ makes the blunt memorizing of the characters much more enjoyable & entertaining
+ you learn japanese vocabulary written in the katakana, but also hiragana set
+ low price for fun >10 hours of learning through playing
+ overall many improvements in comparison to predecessor:
   + now a variety of good (<3 <3) battle & general music, that was needed but missing in the last title of the series
   + new gameplay mechanics like an basic affection system, a better fight-order instead of round-based fighting system
   + charming characters have more personality, interaction between each other and even some minor character 
      progression/development!
   + many characters that you can choose from to build your group
   + voice actors for the main cast! (even though not every line is spoken out loudly..)
   + no annyoing & high random encounter rates anymore (thank god), but free roaming enemies that follow you (you 
     could basically slip past most of them, but that would mean less XP too)
   + the character-drive story is a bit better then before, for an educational game where it just encompasses the learning- 
   aspect I find it good. Don't expect too much here though..
      enough.. 
   + minor quality of life enhancements (like that the whole set of characters is in one ordered & color-coded list, that you 
   navigate thorugh whithout scrolling)
   + many side quests, where you can learn extra vocab, if you please to do so

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
~ still no full HD (cmon devs, even with the RPGMaker I'm sure it would be possible ;))
~ grammar is utterly left untouched. Of course that's neither what the games aims to accomplish nor is grammar a small 
   topic you can rush through, but a bit of insight would be appreciated
~ many vocab-words that you learn throughout the game demand, that you know Hiragana..

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- I still think that the fighting mechanic could be expanded upon, especially approaching the end..
- the boss battle was less demanding and epic in terms of gameplay then in "Hiragana Battle", at least that's my opinion
- dungeon design is still way to straight forward, I think basic puzzle elements for the stages (that maybe even involve japanese culture) could have been added easily and would make the gameplay more refreshing!

[h1]All in all[/h1]
A big improvement towards the previous game of the series! Really helpful & entertaining way to learn the Katakana symbols. Even though it is not mandatory I would suggest that you first learn the Hiragana alphabet, so you won't miss out on any vocab content in this game (check out the previous game ;)). 

クール ゲーム!

As a more personal note, I'm also looking forward to the [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SoFdcCD0UZA]already announced[/url] "Kanji Combat"!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198337331101', 'num_games_owned': 66, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1244, 'last_played': 1526602445}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972439154', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 954, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 954, 'last_played': 1517129667}
review:
Does pretty much exactly what it sets out to do and teaches you Katakana.  Would recommend to anyone who is brand new to learning Japanese and has already learned Hiragana or played the previous game.

Can't really recommend it to anyone else.  The gameplay is very repetitive and basic, the music is decent and serves it purpose, the voice acting is mediocre to bad.  It's a very standard RPG Maker game but the game is designed with a specific purpose to teach you Katakana and it accomplishes that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087805916', 'num_games_owned': 204, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 998, 'last_played': 1609227024}
review:
I really enjoyed this! They fixed a lot of things that annoyed me from the first game (set turn order, random encounters, not knowing the health of enemies) and it felt A LOT smoother of a game. And it's just fun to learn Japanese this way!

I did find it interesting how they removed vocab for the final section like how they had it in the first game. That was a good way to force you to review some of the words. ANYWAY this is still a great teaching game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198344330698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1522898599}
review:
I dont normally critique games so take this review (if you choose to call it that).

The pros of this game is that it improved a lot on the first game's fight mechanics by setting your answer options in a 5 column spread making it easier to find the answer. It pauses before each character's turn so that you dont super overkill one letter. It also draws out your answer in a sweet little graphic when you attack which helps learners with stroke order.

My critiques stem from the fact that the concept of a random battler to help you study characters is briliant! its basically a flashcard game in a lovable and relatable format. The problem I personally had with it, is the game became too much like a JRPG. It has too many distractions, and obstacles that detract from its original function. I know I am the vocal minority, so I wont spend too much time on this subject. IT would be nice to get the game in a simpler more linear format like the first game for a lowr price point. 

Also.. the voice acting is...erm... 
Would have liked the ability to shut the voice acting off lol sorry! A+ for the effort though!

author: {'steamid': '76561198012127280', 'num_games_owned': 121, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 797, 'last_played': 1522796490}

author: {'steamid': '76561198118275098', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1519574560}

author: {'steamid': '76561197968618795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1518951082}
review:
I learned Hiragana the boring way, by writing each character loads of times and gradualy integrating them into words. Couldn't face doing that again with Katakana so thought I'd give this a bash.


First thing I should say is that it works: you'll learn Katakana by clicking on the sound (denoted by roman characters) that corresponds to the right katakana character in JRPG-style battles. It's easy, quick and much less boring and laborious than writing it down over and over again. 

The lessons that introduce the characters are good - you're taught how to write and pronounce the characters and given tips on how to remember them. Words spelt with the characters you've learned are also introduced gradually, which is nice. 
This game rewards players who've learned hiragana with vocabulary lessons written in the same, but knowing hiragana isn't a requirement as the romaji spellings are also given.

One thing I worried about before buying this was whether it'd strike the right balance between game and language learning tool. I think it mostly gets it right - within 5 minutes you're practising Katakana and it's very accessible and easy to get to grips with. However, the battle system is very simple and gets boring after a while. Although you're given the ability to use magic early on in the game, it does nothing to enhance your learning and it barely does more damage than just choosing the right answer. There's a variant on the combat later on whereby the romaji and katakana characters become inverted, meaning the enemies are now romaji and you have to choose the right katakana. This was welcome, but that's about the extent of the variety offered (90% into the game, anyway).

On the other hand, it sometimes errs a little much on the side of being a JRPG for my liking. I completely tuned out of the  redundant storyline very quickly, and fortunately you can easily skip all the cut scenes and dialogue; however there's surprisingly a lot of the latter considering the game's remit is teaching you a writing system, and the sheer volume you have to click through gets a bit wearing after a while. 

In sum, having a podcast or something else going on while you play is essential to avoid getting bored and irritated by the simplistic battle system and superfluous game elements, but if you want a cheap, quick and easy way to learn katakana you can't really go wrong with this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076654090', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1518824961}
review:
I like this game a lot actually. It's basic, straight forward, and old school. I've picked up some letters in Japanese, even saw them on a sushi menu and knew what they were, which I thought was actually really cool.

If you're interested in this game, know that this game "Katakana War" is for words that the Japanese adapt like pizza, hamburger, soccer, etc. If you want to learn Japanese for every day words like you're reading in this review, then you want Hiragana. 

I really suggest actually writing the characters out when you learn them, then reference them when you're in battle. Once you begin to recognize the character, you won't need the cheat sheet you made. It helps a lot. 

The game is long winded with dialogue that you just click through tirelessly. That's about the only pain in the ass. The characters are also from other countries but all have American accents (but who really cares, you get the idea).

author: {'steamid': '76561197972167989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 939, 'last_played': 1666996805}
review:
I really like this game.  I gives me that good old FF6 feel.  All the while teaching me japanese. 

I purchased this game because, for the life of me i struggle remembering Katakana.  I remember Hiragana very well because its what i learned first.  But the later is hard for me...and its the most important in my opinion, because many western words are converted to Katakana.  So i feel like i learned in reverse...

So, i purchased this game to help with this, and I have to say, its getting the job done nicely.

Having a blast with this game too.  Very fun!  Even though im pretty good at Hiragana, i purchase that version of the game too just to enjoy the gameplay :-)

Best $7 i ever spent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118814059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1645597383}
review:
First if your going to buy this game to learn japanese in any intermediate level I would direct you elsewhere, but if your new to Japanese this is just for you! I have been studying Japanese for over four years now and have always feared katakana words because I had learned hirigana first (often cheated and just use hirigana). This game changed that, as most games simply throw letters at you endlessly until you can guess them well enough, this game decided to make them enemies. At first it was offputing, but after a little while it became the thing that helped me finally learn katakana! The difference? Like other games you learn attack patterns and what they look like to determine how you battle. This is the same approach katakana war took to teaching you katakana. First you have a lesson, then you begin to fight the embodiment of the letters as you move down the katakana table. At first this can feel a little tedious as all the enemies are from the vowel row, but bear through it as it gets better. 

In Conclusion: if your new to japanese or just never bothered to learn katakana like me then this is a must pick game is for you.

Pros:
- Story? (good to have it, gave me a reason to just keep playing and have fun)
- Different way of teaching
- Bonus vocabulary that is reviewable
- Enemies are the vocabulary so you begin to recognize by whats needed instead of just flat out memorizing

Cons: 
- Made with rpg maker (game was programmed quite well, but thought I'd mention it just in case)

author: {'steamid': '76561198349313695', 'num_games_owned': 1689, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 970, 'last_played': 1516758949}
review:
I love this game. 

I have played both games and I'd say it's fairly easy if you have previous knowledge of the language, but if you're freshly new to it, you might struggle with the pace. There's loads of chance for practise and going through the nicely broken up lessons though.

A definite step up from the previous game (combat wise). I already really liked the first one, but grinding is so much more fun on this on. The additional play of sort of platonic friendship dating sim stuff is seriously adorable and a nice break from routine.

You should let us be able to romance the weapons clerk though.~

It sucks that Macs don't let you log achievements but hopefully that'll be sorted soon? Really not a deal breaker.

Can't wait for the Kanji one to come out! :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197972404696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 818, 'last_played': 1517598195}
review:
Ce jeu peut valoir le coup si vous avez du mal à apprendre les katakana par vous même (par coeur + papier/crayon). C'est peut être plus long d'avancer avec le jeu car vous devez faire des quêtes et vous deplacer. Le jeu en lui même n'est pas interessant (l'intrigue, la psychologie des persos, ...). Néanmoins je le recommande à ceux qu'un livre, une méthode d'apprentissage, etc ont pu refroidir. Là on joue et à l'instar des persos, on apprend quelque chose. C'est une initiative sympa mais dispensable.

A noter que vous aurez besoin d'apprendre à écrire les katanas que vous utilisiez ce jeu ou une autre méthode.  Donc papier + crayon quoi que vous décidiez.

Le vrai point négatif du jeu et sa réusabilité. Vous aurez besoin de reviser souvent pour bien mémoriser. Des outils d'apprentissages en ligne sont bien meilleurs à ce niveau. Là, les menus, les cours divisés par type de katakanas n'aident pas.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314683', 'num_games_owned': 563, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1516279333}
review:
Let's get the non-negative stuff out of the way first, which is the most subjective part of my review.  I enjoyed the music and artwork for a $7 title.  I'm mixed about the voice acting; the competence of each actor varied quite a bit, and Satomi's was the only one who stood out to me, albeit in a positive way. Understandably, all of the characters have an American accent despite their backstory.  I don't have much to say about the story and whatever else I don't mention.

As for the negative:
– No real-time challenges. Whenever you read, speed is important, and this game offers no benefit for speed. Even just having a FF7/8-esque ATB system would be a huge improvement.
– Difficulty is extremely low. I just rushed through the story and absolutely destroyed everything, including the final boss.
– The organized Answer menu makes it way too easy to deduce the correct answer for romaji enemies without learning the katakana well.  You can ace all the answers by memorizing slightly over 20% of all the katakana.  OCR could be used instead.
– The vast majority of the enemies have attributes that scale with how recently you received their associated lesson, making it even easier to deduce the correct answer without learning katakana.
– Too often, the same enemies will appear in exactly the same positions. Compounded by a menu that remembers your previous commands, this makes it even easier for players to succeed without learning much katakana.
– Poor balancing between the number of katakana enemies and number of romaji enemies.
– The challenge castle is pointless. The NPC who takes you there makes it sound like a big deal, but it looks like unfinished content.
– Katakana [i]words[/i] are shown literally once ever in battle.  In my experience, I've only really encountered individual katakana characters in manga, and they aren't very important.
– Some of the sidequests require you to purchase a specific item so that you can receive the lesson that helps you identify that item. This is backwards and I don't understand the logic.
– Barely any "RP" in what's sold as an "RPG".  Your choices are basically inconsequential, and only have a minor impact during the character affection sequences.
– The gameplay and design have nothing interesting at all.

There are way better budget RPGs out there, and if you just want to learn katakana, there are plenty of free katakana flash games out there that would help you learn much faster.  Personally I think playing with a katakana Anki deck is one of the fastest ways to drill individual characters into your head, and if you can't even handle that, then good luck making any meaningful progress towards learning Japanese, one of the hardest languages for people who don't natively speak an East Asian language.

author: {'steamid': '76561198285605207', 'num_games_owned': 2608, 'num_reviews': 534, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1515317137}
