author: {'steamid': '76561198337214950', 'num_games_owned': 777, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 855, 'last_played': 1544835940}
review:
A great game to learn the basics of the Japanese language, this time katakana. Compared to the last part, now you can see the enemies on the map, and they do not appear out of nowhere. JRPG part is also made at the highest level, liked the fighting with hieroglyphs. Simple but addictive plot. 
I recommend to those who have just started to learn Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984752312', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 722, 'last_played': 1513947775}
review: The game itself is pretty easy, but it's great as learning tool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120553714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 930, 'last_played': 1511724315}
review:
Not a perfect game neighter as an rpg or a tool for learning japanese, but still entertaining and manages to awaken my hunger for both playing rpgs and learning japanese. Also makes me wish I had the knowlegde and lets face it WILL to make my own game. In short this game is a diamon in the rough. 

Bad stuff:

A1. Dialog in english.
A2. Missed opportunity at writting actual word in battles.
A3. Enemies are quiet alike..
A4. Repeative missions
A5. Forced lessons to proceed

Good stuff

B1. affection meter
B2. character seperat story
B3. side quests
B4. crystal store
B5. short game
B6. achievements

The bad in more depth:


A1. Dialog in english.
It's a issue I have with most language tools. Too much english. A option for having the dialog read in japanese would help me learn even more. Listening to english kinda feels like a waste of time when I trying to learn japanese and since there are subtitles why not? I could listen to the japanese and read the english. Of course I do understand that newcomers might find listening to japanese overwhelming and finding and recording dialog in 2 languages (and translating the dialog) cost more money. Yet it would have been a nice option.

A2. Missed opportunity at writting actual word in battles.
The monsters or Obake you fight appear in shape of japanese letters. In most battles there are multiple letters on screen. Yet they don't say anything. This feels like a perfect opertunity to teach some more japanese words or remind us of words we've seen earlier in the game. All that would be needed is just to arrage what letters pop up at a specific battle and maybe the translation of the word writen at the top of the screen. A missed opportunity.

A3. Enemies are quiet alike
Not much difference between one battle and the other. Only difference was the bosses which change from one letter to another once the last one had been defeated until the final form. In my oppion this should have been the model for the normal enemies. Once I attacked ア with A there is no educational value in me attacking it with A again with a different member of my group. However if it after the first attack switched appearence to a different katakana which I would have to identify then we would learn more wouldn't we? Maybe some of the enimies could have cofused a party member. Maybe the others could have cured this by spelling out his or her name! There were of course some battles that toke place in another dimention where the monsters appeared as latin letters and one had to defeat them by attacking with right katakana. A good idea, but it wasn't used enough. Also a sweet idea that just poped. If one could attack Obake from both dimetions at the same battle. Maybe once party memebers could switch between the option of katakana or latin. Might take a move to do. Hmm...
And maybe throw in some really hard enemies once in a while... wait the game did this, but there weren't just hard enough. There's a escape button that I rarely use. 

A4. Repeative missions
This wasn't a issue at the start of the game while one was limited to the first town. But the later part when one has to travel to another part on the map to fight some small Obake before a bossbattle only to end up back in town 1 to repeat the process in the next part of the game. No sleep overs, No traveling without a party member or wich a curse one has yet to learn how to remove. Now the game is not the only rpg with this problem. And as I said before this isn't a problem in the begining of the game. Maybe because you can kinda see what difference you've made.. or because the walk to the action was shorter.

A5. Forced lessons to proceed
Kinda a part of the last complaint, but it comes from a different place. I've tried to learn japanese on and of for some years. So I kinda don't need these lessons, but to progress in the story and to get access to other "tools"(in lack of a better word) in the game to teach me some japanese I don't know I have to sit thorugh them. Kinda wish this would have been optional.

Good stuff more in depth

B1. affection meter
Done a lot of ginding in other games to empower my partymembers. Rarly grinded to improve affection. Still grinding, but now it had more of a pay off. A simple short little cut cusceen. Well done! Grinding now has more of a purpose.

B2. character seperat story
The charaters in the story are kinda simple minded, but still kinda entertaining. Or maybe it just me. Yet The final cutsceens (especially Owens) gave me such hunger to learn more. Well written.

B3. side quests
The side quest were enjoyable and the reward was a to learn more japanese words and sometimes there was a quiz at the end. Those quizes were fun... maybe because they were so easy that I acced everyone except the ones that I kinda messed up on...
Also The simple bubble with the text "rock on super star" that appeared everytime you finnished a quest. Really got me hyped for some reason.

B4. crystal store
In some battles you receive crystals which you can exchange for items that permanatly boost your characters stats. Love having this opion. So now I can make my weakest character the strongest or the slowest the fastest or... I could just speed up my mages for the best results in future battles... Yet the option to modify like this gives freedom to do it all. Turn a warrior to a mage or a mage into a battle mage. Freedom like this is oe of the best features in gameplay probably only riveled by joy of double jump.

B5. short game
I'm old. I have a job and lots of other things I want to do. So Good things come in small packages and don't take up to much of my time. I rather play a short game than a long one that looses it's charm because of the time it steals from other activities or because fun of the game stoped being fun after 50 hours and you still have 100 left,,,
I know there are young people out there that want a game to last forever,,, but you will learn.
Still a ultimate boss to fight after would have been nice...

B6. achievements
Never thought that this would ever become important to me, but it did... and that is why I haven't fibbished Hiragana wars... Yet I found myself playing though this game in less than a week. Nice upgrade... Now please path the first game so with achievements as well... please..

Special thanks!

To Sleepy duck! I might have called your game a diamond in the rough, but that's still a diamond. Please continue your work. I want more fun japanese education and you seem to pretty good with motivation as well. Keep making more! Looking foward to playing kanji wars. puzzled by how it will work with the battle mechanics. Guessing you are not going to inclued all what 4000 kanji... Rock on super star!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198219449433', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1273, 'last_played': 1512712730}
review:
Good game to begin learning the Katakana if you don't know where to start. It's easy and fun. 

And there are a number of good surprises about this game.

Plus it is well put together with a good story line.

I played this game twice over. The first time was to learn the Katakana. The second time was to see how fast I was at reacting to everything that was thrown at me. I was amazed at the second time around, I was reacting quickly and accurately. It made going through the game even easier and faster the second time around.

Intermediate students may find this a bit more tedious, but the game play will still be fun. Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057370688', 'num_games_owned': 396, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 799, 'last_played': 1512579718}
review:
Fiz a analise do Hiragana Battle e agora volto pra falar de Katakana War, fazendo algumas comparações com o jogo antigo.

Em primeiro lugar, você não precisa jogar o jogo antigo para jogar este, mas vai te ajudar MUITO se o fizer, já que o jogo tem palavras escritas em Hiragana o tempo todo, além de que, existem simbolos em Katakana muito parecidos ou iguais ao Hiragana, como exemplo: 
He = へ　
Ya = や/ヤ　
Ka = か/カ　

Bom, Katakana War não segue uma continuação do jogo passado, mas segue o mesmo estilo de gameplay: uma cidade foi invadida por símbolos japoneses e é seu dever acabar com eles.

LADOS POSITIVOS:

1.Aqui já temos um progresso, uma vez que, no jogo passado, ele funcionava igual grama do pokemon, que tu passa em cima várias vezes até encontrar um oponente, mas nesse jogo você vê a letra e tem a opção de mandar o ronaldinho nela, evitando um combate. Isso faz com que o jogo, em primeira instancia, pareça mais dinâmico que o anterior, mas existem problemas aqui que serão falados mais pra frente.

2. Outro ponto positivo é o menu de letras estarem infinitamente mais organizado. CUIDADO! Não decore o simbolo pela linha que ele se encontra. Entenda que, esse é um jogo educacional, então duele com todos os monstros se possível e decore de forma com que você não esqueça.

3. Nesse game temos dublagem. Ela é uma merda, mas auxilia na hora do combate. 
Quando você vai lutar contra um simbolo e aí seleciona uma tradução, o personagem fala em voz alta o que foi selecionado e escreve na tela. Isso é bom por termos tanto apoio visual quanto auditivo e facilita na hora do aprendizado. 

4. O uso das magias, pelo menos pra mim, foi superior tambem. No jogo passado era só pegar o personagem, socar level e itens que dão força pra dar hit kill mas nesse aqui, os personagens são mais fracos e as magias auxiliam. (Charllote é healer e roubada, use-a)

5. O jogo também tem nível de interação. Tu consegue fazer amizade e super amizade com a sua party e eles ganham buffs adicionais.

Agora vem os defeitos:

1. Me incomoda o tanto de diálogo entre personagens. Eu particularmente não dei a mínima pra interação dos personagens e nem pela história, que é completamente enfadonha. O jogo é educacional e deveria se comportar como tal. Isso faz você perder algum tempo só tendo que dar skip.

2. Tem um bug chato que faz o fps do game cair pra 1 quando seu personagem vai upar de classe. Isso faz você perder tempo também.

3. Achei os mapas bem pequenos, então se você for apressado, tu pode sair rushando o jogo e não aprender muito, o que no jogo passado, era impossível.

4. Dublagem. É ruim gente, desculpa.

5. Acho errado num jogo que era pra focar apenas nos simbolos querer me ensinar palavras. A melhor forma de aprender palavras é em textos, não no avulso. Pelo menos o final não teve o lance do final anterior, então ta bom.

CONCLUSÕES FINAIS:

Sim, você aprende jogando tanto esse quanto o outro, mas não sei ao certo o quão efetivo é. 
Posso dizer que, pra mim, os dois jogos me deram o pontapé inicial e eu consigo ler hiragana e katakana com facilidade, mas eu uso outros sites de apoio e estou sempre escutando o idioma, talvez tenha sido mais fácil, não sei como vai ser pra você.

Quero só ver como vão fazer com o jogo de Kanji (que parece que a Claire vai voltar <3)

author: {'steamid': '76561198263440997', 'num_games_owned': 120, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 663, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1526943602}
review: I'll be honest, it's not the most fun game out there. However, it's a lot better than studying out of a book, and that's what I used it for. Really helped me to focus on memorizing the Katakana for my college Japanese class. If you want to be able to read Katakana, pick this up. If you want to learn to speak Japanese, you learn some phrases but not many.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008009643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1495931164}
review: Pretty helpful with learning the basics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198170866389', 'num_games_owned': 37, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1524, 'last_played': 1549417600}
review:
Although the title would suggest otherwise, Katakana War is a pleasant RPG focused more about learning to read and write from the fundamental form of the language of a country which has never fired a missile outside its own territory, and is among the highest among both the Human Development and World Peace Indeces.

It's also a lot less about combat in any sense, and more about having Pokemon battles with Unown-like creatures. And, of course, getting to know your "characters" better! :P

author: {'steamid': '76561197971595199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1508970822}
review:
Nice game, but hiragana (part I) was much better... This gme is quite to easy... In the hiragana version you had to grind a level one or two times to make it, use items and magic wisely... In this game you can simply ignore all items and magic and running throuhg... Because of that you do not repeat the katakana signs often enough to be able to remember them a day after you learned it...
Besides of that i still am missing some of the side quest, even I had revisited all the places, I still do not know where to find them...
Still it is a nice game, but the quality decreased massivly relatively to the first episode... I hope the Kanji part will be better again...

author: {'steamid': '76561198273880942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1506263162}
review:
What a fun way to learn Katakana. This game surprised me, it is quite captivating even though there are a few bugs here and there (WASD controls don't seem to work even though it's a setting). It works the same as the Hiragana version, only it seems more polished than the previous one. The gamestyle and gameplay reminds me of the old Pokemon games.
I will totally be backing a Kanji game if there'll ever be one!

author: {'steamid': '76561198073743251', 'num_games_owned': 372, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 543, 'last_played': 1567224449}
review:
More fun than I expected haha ^^

I do find myself actually enjoying the game and its mechanics while still learning Katakana characters; which means the game does its job well.

All in all, definitely recommended for those looking to learn Katakana.

author: {'steamid': '76561198306368153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1505647735}
review:
To put it bluntly, I was fairly impressed by the game despite a few minor bugs.

Pros:
-For $7, it is entertaining and it gets the job done. 
-You'll pick up some vocab words you may or may not have known already. 
-The production quality is better than pretty much every indie / rpg-maker-like game I've played on Steam. It's painful how serious that statement is, but at the same time my hat is off to the devs.
-They cleaned up the answer table in the combat system from hiragana battle. It is much easier on the eyes
-The voice acting is straight up better than like 75% of dubbed anime, which was a pleasant surprised
-Inclusion of a 'practice' mode unlocked through normal gameplay (I think it was chapter 5 or 6). Didn't use it yet, but I might come back to it if I feel I need to review.
-This game has a bit more personallity than it's predecessor which was a nice touch

Cons:
-A few bugs, Couldn't get WASD controls to work. Final affection cutscenes lagged / froze to the point where I thought it would crash the game (it did not). The game did crash on me once after running it for  about 6 or 7 hours, I'm not sure why. I didn't bother checking the error log and it didn't happen again. And yeah, I played this from start to finish in one sitting. I know, I'm such an overachiever, stop, y'all gonna make me blush.
-If you played Hiragana battle you probably remember when they switched the Hiragana enemies for Romaji ones and you had to answer with the corresponding Hiragana. It really helped etch those suckers into memory IMO. This happens in Katakana War as well, but it's too easy. That new cleaned up Answer table makes it a little too easy to common sense your way to the correct choice (Ie. If you remember which column is which vowel). This is essentially nit-picking as any practice is helpful, but I figured I'd mention it.
-They cleaned up the combat gui a bit which, while asthetically pleasing, leaves me with one eensie-weensie bone to pick. In Hiragana Battle when selecting the Hiragana to answer there was another box in the menu you could look at to select the hiragana as well as the highlighted sprite. This was nice because the hiragana were displayed there in a more normal text-like font as opposed to the sprite's more artistic / calligraphic versions. I can't read the common text katakana nearly as well as I could the common text hiragana right after finishing the game. It's not a huge deal, there are only a few that look all that different, and if I stop and think for a minute I can usually figure it out without having to check an appendix or anything like that, it's just that the comprehension isn't quite as well as a result of not seeing both for the 8 or 9 hours I spent playing / learning. Ironically the best resource for reading the texty fonty katana is that Romaji Answer table I just whined about. After unlocking all the Katakana I took a moment to look it over and screenshotted it for reference.



TLDR: Will teach you Katakana in an entertaining fashion. Eagerly awaiting Kanji Combat which I believe was confirmed by the devs on a forum post somewhere, although there is no Kickstarter page as of 9/2017.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138116264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1533599399}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995353124', 'num_games_owned': 1623, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 746, 'last_played': 1503681602}
review:
This is a really good game to get into. I have played the Prequel before and I can recommend both.

Katakana War brings a lot of new gameplay features which makes playing and especially learning japanese much easier.

the Voice Over is cringy a lot of times but it is pretty fun. I wouldnt be playing this game in a local cafe anyways but it really is something else and refreshing to have a jiggle.

if youre interested in japanese I can recommend to play the first one (Hiragana Battle) first and afterwards Katkana War.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037510879', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1503522627}
review:
Straight off the bat I can see just how much worse this is than Hiragana Battle.

- Cringey voice over that if you want to disable, you have to lose all your basic UI sound effects as well.
- Battles are way, way slower paced and thus more time is wasted not learning. Characters yell the sound of the katakana they are attacking which sounds awful and makes the player less likely to sound out the katakana themselves. (Again, this can only be disabled if you also have disabled all of the game's basic sound effects.)
- Battles no longer have you select the character in a window showing the character in computer text. I liked this in Hiragana battle as it further cemented my memorization and allowed me to regularly see characters in both written and typed font styles.
- The writing animations in lessons are way too slow.
- Story is worse and gameplay focuses too much on being an RPG instead of actually learning like the first game did.
- BUGS. The game has been out for 8 months now and not a single patch. Really? Keyboard configuration is completely broken, and from reading what others have said there are even incorrect translations which will cause player confusion.

Overall I would have rathered a carbon copy of Hiragana Battle with katakana subsituted in than this mess. Personally I'd advise people to find another way to learn their katakana, which is exactly what I'm going to do as I'm now getting a refund for this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077987889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1502374924}
review: While the package hasn't changed much the contents in it are vastly better than its predecessor Hiragana Battle. Katakana War takes the existing battle system from Hiragana battle and improve upon it immensely making the process of learning Japanese much more fun. The voice acting wasn't my cup of tea but I slowly adjusted, the story is slightly better this time around. Magic system is a new inculsion and is handeled very well, it doesn't 1 hit kill anything but it does a ton of damage (depending on the character). The learning guide which was inculded in the deluxe addition helps greatly and is very appreicated and well put together. Katakana battle takes the Learning to Japanese Franchise and moves it forward and hopefully will continue to with Kanji Combat. Buy it if you wish to learn Katakana in a fun and compelling way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004715298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1061, 'last_played': 1500828884}
review: Much like it's predecessor, Katakna war is an educational memory game but with katakana instead of hiragana. The art and the controls have improved a bit since the last installment imo. I recommend it for those who want to try a bit more fun way of learning kanas, than googling it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019698222', 'num_games_owned': 417, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1656383184}
review: I learned Magic faster than I learned Katakana

author: {'steamid': '76561198026637992', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1834, 'last_played': 1650645978}
review:
For as much as I really enjoyed playing Hiragana Battle, this game took the whole concept and implemented it at whole new level. The level of polish on this game was above and beyond what I was expecting. Everything from the enunciation of the syllables (with both male and female audio as appropriate to the character) to the excellent side quests that allowed you to learn new words in an unintimidating manner were just excellent.

The game built on the previous game without the player "really" needing to have played it which was nice. Characters in this game were actually really well developed and I had an authentically good time with the RPG elements of the game.The maps were a little visually busy and I still think both games would've been better if the characters had dynamic expressions that changed to fit the situation rather than one genetic portrait... but there were small things like shaking the portraits and the voice acting that added a lot more life to the characters which was really awesome. 

Also, on that note, blown away by the inclusion of voice acting, it really added an extra layer of depth to this game that I love. I also like that the game has return-ability, unlike Hiragana Battles, there is still an end game that you can continue going through to practice and catch up on things you missed, which I absolutely love. This is genuinely a really good game, whether you're trying to learn Japanese or not, I would definitely recommend this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198079558994', 'num_games_owned': 753, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1502070680}

author: {'steamid': '76561198108831924', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 740, 'last_played': 1502374548}
review:
[b]Story[/b]: 
Shape-shifting monsters called Obake started appearing all over Japan, You, as a foreigner teamed up with other people to learn Katakana (one of the three writing systems in Japanese) in order to defeat the Obake, as the only way to defeat them is to call out the name their shape represents.

[b]Gameplay[/b]:
The gameplay is similar to that of a classic RPG game. You form a team of four, battle in turn-by-turn combats, collect items and money, and interact with NPCs. Through the repetitive battling, you'll learn Katakana while playing the game. In addition to that, the game also features light dating-sim elements and pure lecture scenes.

[b]Graphics[/b]:
The pixel graphic is detailed, the characters has traits that make them stand out from the others. However I wish that the texture of the floor has more variations as they look very repetitive. I also wish there are different animations for different magic skills. Lastly, which I think is the most important issue here, the artwork of the character that appears when they speak should have more variations. Because there are only one artwork for each character, so sometimes they don't match what they're saying (Like someone is saying something furiously but their artwork shows them smiling).

[b]Sound[/b]:
I like the background music of the game, especially the battle themes. However, I think different magic skills should have different variations of sound effect, it'd make the game more enjoyable. The voiceover is good, but could use some improvements in my opinion. During battle, I wish the characters would speak the answer in their own voice instead of two generic voices for male and female. The voiceover is not full which means most dialogues don't have full voiceovers. I have no problem with that but sometimes the voice is completely unrelated to what the character says. I get slightly annoyed when that happens.

[b]Performance[/b]:
Even though it's a 2D RPG game, I get some performance issues when playing the game, It could be an issue that only happens on my PC though. After every battle, when the score screen appears, the screen would freeze for a few seconds and during that time I can't do anything but to wait for the freeze to go away. This issue happens after almost every battle which can be a bit annoying. But luckily the freeze don't aways happen right after the score screen appears, so if I'm lucky I can skip the screen before the freeze happens to avoid the freezing. I use a game controller to play this game, it works fine except one part: when you're running, if you let go of the run button, your character would stop moving instead of continue walking. This is not a serious issue and will not affect the playability of the game.

[b]Conclusion[/b]: 
If you want to learn Katakana in a fun and relaxing way, then I recommend learning it through this game. If this is the first time you're learning Japanese, then I recommend you to play the Hiragana version first. It's made by the same developer and is a prequel to this game. After playing through this game, you should be able to recognize all Katakana characters. So why not do the learning through playing a game? Although the story and RPG elements of the game is very basic, it's still a good game. Remember, it's an educational game. At the end, you can learn so much just by playing a game, and how many game allows you to do that?


[spoiler]I'm looking forward for a Kanji version.[/spoiler]




[spoiler]Also, I must try out the corn soup when I'm in Japan.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198281198008', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1121, 'last_played': 1502308215}
review:
Очень ждала эту игру. Я испытала счастье, пройдя её и залистав блокнотик с иероглифами катаканы до того состояния, когда он развалился на отдельные куски. Хорошее продолжение игры про Хирагану. После обеих частей игры решила, что однажды во что бы то ни стало выучу японский. 

Игра построена так, что ты можешь проходить её с удобной тебе скоростью, без спешки заныривая в онлайн переводчик или отвлекаясь на заваривание чая. 

Из минусов - странное подвисание игры в определённые моменты общения с персонажами. Когда запустите игру и немного поиграете, поймёте о чём речь. Возможно, это изначальная задумка разрботчиков, чтобы я лучше осознала важность определённых моментов общения...Впрочем, больше и придраться не к чему. 

У игры свой стиль, своя манера общения с игроком. Мне импонирует подобная дружелюбная интерактивность со стороны персонажей. И этот стиль рисовки маленьких чибиков, спасающих Японию от всяких неприятностей - ммм, он иронично трогателен и омурмительно хорош. Няшные и отважные:D 

Все итак уже поняли, что игра понравилась, так что не затягивая с дифирамбами подытожу - любителям жанра и в особенности данных игр (Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana War и Katakana War) стоит поиграть.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010241108', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 583, 'last_played': 1501991806}
review:
This was my first experience with learning Japanese, and the game worked well with my complete lack of knowledge. I was never particularly challenged, with there being very few difficult knowledge checks. I feel like this will serve as a good foundation for my Katakana learning, and now that I have the basics I can find slightly more advanced training. You're going to want to write things down as you play; while there is a study guide, there isn't a prepared alphabet chart for you, and making one good alphabet chart will help you beat the game (and learn Japanese) with less trouble.

The total runtime of my game, where I completed *most* sidequests I ran in to and didn't experiment with my party very much, was 9 hours. Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War was a nice way to spend a weekend, and I would recommend it to any fan of anime as a first step in to learning Japanese. (I think, I haven't really "learned" it yet!)

For the game itself, I have a long list of gripes and wishes. These are mostly going to be negative things, but I want to note that the experience overall was very enjoyable.
- The music has a very short loop in some places, with obvious stumbles between loops.
- It feels like the engine can't handle having so many attack options; later in the game, the game will lag slightly every time you open up the Answer menu
- The final boss will also cause a slight bit of lag when particles are on him
- Some areas, such as the mountain, have very avoidable combat. I felt like just walking around monsters instead of fighting them. This is a gamer-thing, but it may have robbed me of some practice?
- There was very little reinforcement for vocabulary; only a few side quests quizzed your vocab retention
- The fonts chosen can cause some confusion; I didn't realize "shi" had that slant to it until it was randomly put next to "tsu" for a word, or that the "a" letter didn't connect at the top
- I enjoyed seeing my party interact, but I wish they would talk about Japanese a little more; there was a person who taught me about sports words like Tennis and Surfing, and I wish my friends would talk about learning the words for their hobby
- The very end of the game had a cool puzzle, buy a Radio using the japanese word, and the last few weapons were in japanese; I really enjoyed that content and translating the words to Romaji, and I wish there was more things like that

author: {'steamid': '76561198198275063', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 742, 'last_played': 1519451893}

author: {'steamid': '76561198016138401', 'num_games_owned': 267, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 643, 'last_played': 1501109813}
review:
[h1]Русского языка в игре нет![/h1]
Рекомендую игру для тех кто в состоянии читать тексты на английском и понимать хотя бы основную суть. Не знаю, хватит ли школьного уровня, тут скорей все упирается в словарный запас.

[h1]Введение[/h1]
Давным-давно загорелся желанием выучить японский, но все не знал с чего же начать. Однажды наткнулся на 1-ую часть данной серии [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/438270/Learn_Japanese_To_Survive_Hiragana_Battle/]Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle[/url]. Приобрел ее и к концу прохождения уже знал 85-90% Хираганы. Спустя некоторое время, увидев в продаже данную игру, приобрел и ее. Но руки дошли до нее только сейчас.

[h1]Геймплей[/h1]
Игра представляет собой JRPG и полностью построена на обучении. В основном делается упор на изучение Катаканы (японская слоговая азбука использующая для написания иностранных слов), также по ходу игры вас немного обучат грамматике и пополнят ваш словарный запас.
В японию вторглись пришельцы в форме слогов из Катаканы и вам нужно освободить ее от них. Единственным способом победить их является правильно назвать их. К примеру: イ - И (i), カ - КА (ka). Вам представляется возможность собрать пати из 4-ех персонажей (одним из которых является созданный вами в начале) по ходу игры вам откроются новые персонажи, каждый из которых обладает своими особыми скиллами и характеристиками.
И так, цель ясна, пати собрано, что же дальше? А дальше за 10 основных уроков(не считая побочных 20 мини-уроков(квестов)) которые будут по ходу игры, вас прогонят по всей Катакане.
И вот 1-ый урок завершен, теперь можно и в бой! Побеждаете захватчиков своими знаниями, с каждым новым уроком освобождаете новые области. Так же не забывайте заглядывать в различные лавки, где продается оружие и припасы.
P.S у каждого из персонажей есть шкала "привязанность", она будет повышаться лишь у тех, кто сражается вместе с вами в пати, при ее повышении откроются мини-диалоги с каждым из них, в конце каждого из которых вам придется выбрать 1 из 3-ех ответов, при удачном ответе персонаж получить + к характеристикам, и как только шкала привязанности достигнет максимума, персонаж получит уникальную, ультимативную способность, которую можно будет использовать 1 раз за бой.

[h1]Техническая часть[/h1]
Интерфейс простой и понятный.
Присутствует английская озвучка для важных диалогов, огорчило, что у русского персонажа не было "русского" акцента аля "Лет пи спик фром май харт" но это уже чисто мои придирки.
Саундтрек в игре очень хорошо написан, особенно вдохновил трек в самом конце игры.
Так же хоть и в сюжете не было ничего особенного, в самом конце игры саундтрек и актеры почти что заставили меня пустить слезу.

[h1]Итог[/h1]
В итоге считаю, что игра достойна для своей скромной цены, со своей задачей прекрасно справляется. В этот раз за 3 дня игры выучил 95% Катаканы. Советую пройти и 1-ую часть данной серии [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/438270/Learn_Japanese_To_Survive_Hiragana_Battle/]Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle[/url], еще в конце разработчики анонсировали 3-ую часть Learn Japanese To Survive! Kanji Battle, очень сильно жду ее, учитывая сколько кандзи в японском.  По ходу игры вам дропнется 4 карточки, каждая из которых стоит 12-15 рублей.

[h1]P.S[/h1]
Если чего-то не написал об игре, можете задать вопрос, отвечу или дополню обзор.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111263701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 737, 'last_played': 1500562289}
review:
Katakana War reprend efficacement le principe de Hiragana War.
Si je résumé très brièvement le principe : on mélange le grinding / level up des rpg pour mémoriser les katakanas.
C'est simple - mais fallait y penser - et ça marche.

Les développeurs ont même fait quelques améliorations par rapport à Hiragana War, notamment au niveau des graphismes, mais aussi quelques petits ajouts inutiles mais sympathiques, comme par exemple le système d'affection ou les trophées. Ca ne sert pas à grand chose, mais ça donne un prétexte pour s'entrainer un peu plus. Alors bien sûr, c'est du rpg maker, mais j'ai vu largement pire pour des "vrais" rpg. Pour le reste, les leçons (courtes mais claires) et le système de combat (décodage et parfois encodage) contre les katakanas sont identiques. Evidemment, il ne faut pas s'attendre à une histoire génialissime, mais tel n'était pas le but.

En ce qui concerne la difficulté, j'ai trouvé que les katakanas étaient beaucoup plus facile à apprendre que les hiraganas. Vivement la suite, avec Kanji War !

author: {'steamid': '76561197983082568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 2338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2337, 'last_played': 1554178171}
review:
‘Learn Japanese to Survive: Katakana Wars’ on PC / Steam 
Score 9.5 / 10 The pleasure is in the mind, and only for linguists.

Easy not is Japanese Katakana; ノ
Patience and commitment require you; ユー
Katakana spell can PC; カタカナ
Hardwork is カタカナ. 
カチング　Cart to add.

Your acquired knowledge of Katakana is the only way to win in this very light Japanese Dungeon RPG. The RPG elements are simple and fun and given that the only rate limiting step is your knowledge winning battles is deeply satisfying. 
You don’t like Japanese language? Forget this game.

Oops did you study too much? The game is too easy (me)
Ooosh*t did you think this was gonna be easy? Epic Fail ! (haahaaa)

Katakana == Japanese alphabet for writing non-Japanese words. (This game)
Hiragana == Japanese alphabet for writing Japanese words. 
(A different game by the same developer see below)
Kanji == Japanese ideograms with characters similar to Chinese (very hard and not in this game. I sincerely hope that this will be made into a game by this developer)

Arigato gozaimashita. 100% Achievo and solid Katakana knowledge in 30 hours (or less). I wish there was a second level to this. Only for those wishing to acquire language. July 2017.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/438270/Learn_Japanese_To_Survive_Hiragana_Battle/

author: {'steamid': '76561198071703209', 'num_games_owned': 1462, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 1219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1219, 'last_played': 1500326081}
review:
TLDR: Sí, aprenderás a leer Katakana. No, no te volverás un experto en japonés con este juego, pero sirve.

Definitivamente mejoraron la jugabilidad y el aspecto gráfico respecto a 
[url=store.steampowered.com/app/438270/Learn_Japanese_To_Survive_Hiragana_Battle/] Hiragana Battle [/url] ; el juego cumple perfectamente con su función de enseñarnos Katakana 「カタカナ」; aunque no es estrictamente necesario, es una buena idea jugar Hiragana Battle antes o tener conocimiento del Hiragana ya que algunas lecciones están basadas en este (aunque no afectan el progreso). También puedes aprender un poco de la cultura japonesa y conceptos y frases importantes.

Reseña completa: http://www.untaldex.com/2017/07/resena-de-katakana-war-learn-japanese-to-survive/

author: {'steamid': '76561198171017269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1273, 'last_played': 1617485966}
review:
It actually doesn't much matter if you learn hiragana or katakana first, katakana might be even better for foreigners because katakana is all about foreign words. 
Will this game teach you katakana? Yes it will. I was always too lazy to learn katakana the traditional way. So i found this game series and decided to give it a fresh try. I didn't buy Hiragana Battle because of the reviews saying that Katakana war is far better developed and less repetitive. And also has Steam Cloud and achievements. Even the art looks better from the previews and still the games cost (now) the same.. 

This game got the main point through. I am able to read words in katakana now, sometimes slowly, but i can do it!

I really hope developers will read this, however (SPOILER ALERT!):
1.Would have been nice if i was able to choose the order of attack on characters. It seemed sometimes too random and unexplained. I always had to attack with my character first. Would have been nicer if there had been more varierity to that.
2.There could have been so much more to do! For example, friend rooms. At least the option to add them to party or maybe discover some items in their rooms would have been interesting. 
3.Also would have been nice to travel using the train station, much more logical than just leaving the town. At least have an option to travel after finishing mission there.
4.The WASD keyboard setup didn't work. Please fix.

I suggest maybe developers make updated/improved versions of hiragana and katakana games.  Hiragana battle 2, Katakana war 2, etc... But of course kanji combat would be awesome too! I am so waiting for it!

But overall: Thank you for making the game :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198062405721', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1842, 'last_played': 1526157653}

author: {'steamid': '76561198207416317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1066, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1066, 'last_played': 1499652247}
review:
I've always wanted to continue learning Japanese after i left Japan after living there for some time and i never got to learn as much as i wanted. This game, however caught my eye and peeked my interest. After playing both Hiragana Battle and Katakana War, i was very happy with the adventures i had went on and the knowledge i was provided with. 

This game and it's prequel are both very fun RPG's and are great for learning the building blocks of Japanese. They provide you with the basics needed to really make your lessons in Japanese soar. I highly recommend these two games and a possible sequel that we may get in the future. Fingers crossed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035810296', 'num_games_owned': 1694, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 728, 'last_played': 1499339355}
review:
To answer the question most of you have, yes, this works. Much like the Hiragana focused prequel that is also wonderful.
The game touches a small bit on grammar, as well as gives you a handful of vocabulary words. The two games are a great place to start learning the language.
As for the game itself, it's fine. I wasn't particularly a fan of some thing about the game, like how long it takes to grind up affection.
Asides from that, despite having more fleshed out characters, and a bigger cast, I found myself enjoying the first game more as far as the story, and characters go. Especially the final section of the game. I definitely think the first game was more enjoyable as far as that goes.

Regardless, I had a lot of fun with this game, and given the ending, I look forward to the future of the series!

author: {'steamid': '76561197975293555', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1057, 'last_played': 1622682156}
review:
This is an excellent learning game, which gives a fun was to drill your letters.  Generally, this is the most boring part of learning a language but the game made it fun to keep practicing.  It also gives a fairly large vocabulary, and even a number of verbs and verb forms.   In this way, it was a great improvement over "Learn Japanese To Survive! Hiragana Battle."

The vocabulary lessons are easier if you have already learned Hiragana, possibly through playing the prequel.   On the other hand, it was mildly annoying that the storyline in "Katakana War" did not connect with the loose ends of "Hiragana Battle".  In terms of the learning experience this didn't matter at all, but in terms of enjoying the denouement at the end, it was a mild let down.  

There are some extremely good jokes made by all the other characters.  Andrea is possibly the most annoying female I've ever played with, and Kyoko's experience of "having a conversation" made me laugh out loud.  

If you are trying to have a fun way to practice your first lessons in Japanese, this game and it's prequel are really great learning tools that are fun to use.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159387182', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 285, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1499695114}

author: {'steamid': '76561198019202486', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 830, 'last_played': 1564744150}
review:
As a person who is self studying Japanese, it's really great to find a game like this to freshen up the studying scene and make it feel like it's not studying at all. Through out this game you'll learn a variety of new words (around 100, I think.) to add to your vocabulary by completely simple side quests. The characters are cute and create an adorable band of friends, but I feel like there were 2 too many characters and the voice acting was painful. For an extra cost, what I would like to see is the devs create an additional mode where you have to spell the words you've learnt using katakana. It would help to teach "students" how to combine words to make different sounds.

All in all, fantastic game. I've spent the last 12 hours straight playing this to whip my arse back into studying, and they've helped me accomplish that. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198277632819', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1530117527}
review:
Great game to learn all the Katakana!
It's done better than the first one (Hiragana Battle!) with more varied enemy waves, instead of the same batch of letters in each new area. It's easier to retain all the letters in your memory this way.
The voice acting is very distracting though... The actors aren't the best and although it makes sense that they're talking in english between them, since they're all foreigners learning japanese, japanese voices would help you with pronunciation for example.
It should have an option to at least turn off the voices.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169169714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1514852422}
review:
As someone who has gone through learning the kanas I found that this game really does help people memorize and familiarize with the kanas. Learning the kanas is usually boring, difficult, and... well... boring, but this game makes what's supposedly a good medicine for insomnia into a fun activity.

The plot of course, isn't all that great. I mean, what would expect from a game whose main objective is to teach people? But the gameplay is, not only functional, but also unique enough to be interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996876589', 'num_games_owned': 935, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1659303097}

author: {'steamid': '76561198084387544', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1495325981}
review:
Brilliant game, really good for learning Katakana, I found it useful that I had learnt a fair bit of Japanese first, but my Katakana is really rusty so needed help.

This game is cheesy AS HELL, but that is part of the reason why it is so good! Really nice way of helping you repeat and practice the letters without it seeming boring and repetitive! You can’t KO with magic, which means each time you fight you have to at least once, actually hit it with the correct sound, which is really good, makes you think and remember more! 

I think they did a great job and recommend it to anyone who needs a boost with their katakana!

author: {'steamid': '76561198052947855', 'num_games_owned': 172, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1486276529}
review:
You know, I realize I never made a review for this, 3 months later. Alright, let's go.

If you have not played Hiragana Battle and are planning on playing Katakana War, please buy Hiragana War first and then Katakana war. The best way to learn Japanese is almost for sure Hiragana -> Katakana -> Kanji. 

Learn Japanese to Survive! Katakana War is the sequel, in more than one way, to Hiragana Battle, which are both games that introduce you to the Japanese language with an interesting take: mashing it into an RPG, putting some decent graphics in, and making it something you're willing to invest into. This game does not fully replace a Japanese class, but serves as a great introduction to Japanese and gives you a nice head start if you get into an actual Japanese learning program. After playing Hiragana Battle and seeing the Kickstarter for Katakana Battle, I knew I'd have to buy it first day. And then I got the email and I did. I'm not disappointed in one bit. I may or may not have made a meme out of it, just don't worry about it, let's talk about the game now.

So, what is Katakana? Katakana is a writing system in the Japanese language similar to Hiragana, except these characters are used for words of foreign originality, such as specific locations (ex. Los Angeles = ロスアンゼルス [Rosu-Anzerusu]), foreign names (ex. John -> ジョン [Zyon]) and other loanwords. Hiragana is used for words original to Japanese and articles of the language, and Kanji is used mostly for readability and to clear up the several homophones within the Japanese language.

Similar to Hiragana Battle, you will learn all 46 characters (plus some nuiances with Katakana, specifically) of the Katakana writing system along with a bunch more words and a couple more phrases in both Katakana and Hiragana (which I very much requested for and was happy to see!), along with them being written in Romanized English, or Romaji, for easier understanding for English speakers. Again, similar to Hiragana Battle, it's really quick and easy to learn all these characters, words and phrases to 100% the game (with an actual indicator that you have indeed 100%'d the game this time!), however this time after having experience with Hiragana, it was much quicker and much easier to understand how it all works. Plus I marathoned it over 9 hours straight on my stream, which was decently fun and helped all the lessons move on faster. And again, I highly recommend taking hand-written notes, with paper and pencil.

TL;DR: Slightly higher than my score on Hiragana Battle, I give this a 9 out of 10. It's a great game to play after conquering Hiragana Battle, still is a great way to memorize the basics of Japanese, and it still does not quite replace a class yet, but I will leave a couple handy resources below for that. I have learned way more Japanese after this game, and can confirm this as a very handy tool before getting into Japanese seriously, and will still buy the Kanji equivalent just to see it continue as a great tool.

スリーピングダーク、どうもありがとうございます！これは楽しいかった！

Now, as for the nice resources to use:

First of all, being able to type the Japanese you learn is probably going to be more important than anything else. For Windows users, refer to [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g5zpoYHlNT4]this link to enable the Japanese IME input for your keyboard[/url], which will allow you to type in the all-so-familiar Romaji. For Mac and Linux users, sorry but I don't have anything for you. You'll have to look it up yourselves.

Next, this game isn't everything you need. I wish it was, but there are great resources to use after finishing up with Hiragana and Katakana instead of sitting there saying "...So when's Kanji? Grammar?" My first go-to source was when I finally learned about Duolingo a few months ago and found this website since Duolingo didn't have Japanese lessons, and the website is [url=https://elon.io/]Elon.IO[/url]. Elon.IO offers a Spanish mini-course, Turkish, and the one I wish to highlight, Japanese. The course goes through all the Kanji taught in grade school, Hiragana, and Katakana (which you should have down well already! Benefits, woo!), along with a lot of grammar and phrases, and best of all, it's completely free and repetitive enough to [i]really [strike]frustrate you with the same phrase fifty times just because you typoed once[/strike] ingrain it into your mind.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198049170610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1599, 'last_played': 1501556759}
review:
I feel like the is absolutely worh it if you're trying to learn japanese ( more specifically katakana ). I'm eagerly waiting the kanji sequel. That said I'm not impressed with the story and battle mechanics. The characters are as cliché as it gets, and the story is pretty mediocre. That was what I expected though, since I played game 1, hiragana battle ( which I also recommend, and preferably first, since is more important to japanese than katakana, although you don't need it to learn katakana ). The battle mechanics are okay, but they could be improved a bit, for example  the enemies are not random and so you battle the same enemies too much, and when you battle letters from the roman alphabet you can do it just by remembering the order of the katakana lessons. I do like the learning mechanics quite a bit though, and the pacing is good also.The side quests are very nice also, allowing to learn some sentences and words at the same time you're learning the katakana. 

Buy if you are trying to learn katakana, it gives you incentive to keep learning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123351840', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 737, 'last_played': 1493758705}
{'steamid': '76561198307832590', 'num_games_owned': 316, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1530763601}
review:
If you want to learn Katakana syllabary in Japan, this is a perfect game for you. This is an educational game in which you will  be a protagonist who'll gather allies as you counquer japan by defeating this "Katakana Monsters" (Those are just Katakana symbols anyway..)

This game will teach you Katakana symbols, all of them (Kanji and Hirigana not included) step-by-step, even the pronounciation and how to write them. The more you progress the game, the more Katakanas you'll learn. Not only that, there are mini-games in the game in which you will also learn different commonly used greetings and polite words. Plus, you can raise flags (Affection meter, Love-love thing or whatever) in your allies.

Well, just try playing the game for educational purpose, leisure time or just play this if you are very desperate going to Japan and speak their language. Highly recommended and enjoy the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043875917', 'num_games_owned': 463, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1492954506}
review: Was made with some obscure engine that, while apparently it causes a lot of antivirus programs to be suspicious of it, it also makes the game impossible to capture in OBS using Game Capture or Window Capture. I bought the game with the intention of streaming it, like I did with the first game, which worked fine, but with this one, it doesn't. Because I trusted the developer too much (I guess I didn't have a reason not to, their other game was fine), it was more than two weeks after I bought it that I got around to trying to play it, so I don't qualify for a Steam refund. I guess it's good that I learned this lesson with a fairly cheap game, because being stuck with a game I bought and can't even really use does suck, but I will make sure to try all games immediately after buying in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069159152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2420, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1492512377}
review:
This game is obstensively the sequel to Hiragana Battle. In this game, you will learn the second writing form: Katakana. Premise is a bunch of people from overseas (US, Australia, France) are in Osaka due to varying circumstances (one guy was supposed to go to a surf competition in Okinawa but... bought a plane ticket to the wrong destination). Added to the mix is you. There is a short question session at the beginning of a new game to create your character (gender/play style/name). You and the three others are swept into a war when katakana characters suddenly appear in the streets smashing things. (Since their only weakness is to the katakana vocalizations, one would think more than just the teacher you happen to meet would be able to defeat them, but... whatever.)

Anyway, you need to learn how to read/write Katakana to win this war. Perhaps with a little pronunciation thrown in.

There apparently is a third volume in the works: Kanji Combat or something like that. That should be... interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035284221', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 995, 'last_played': 1491765662}
review:
Damn worth it! The teaching method works for me, finished the game within 2 days (had 16.6 hours spent on this game upon posting this). I can fairly read Katakana characters now, will probably spend the next week practicing it before proceeding to Hiragana. That aside, if you're still thinking if you should buy this, I tell you this is really worth it. 

I suggest taking down notes during the lessons and the side quests.

+ [Gameplay] Teaching method and tests thru turn based fights worked for me (subjective)
+ Decent J-POP Music study material (subjective)
+ Pretty good art
+ The story can be better, liked it nonetheless
+ The mechanic of you micromanaging between the RPG elements of the game to distract you while trying to recognize the Katakana characters is quite interesting. 

The other guy who disliked this game for that reason maybe didn't like this kind of distraction but it worked for me especially for someone who has a terrible memory (yes I just attacked a katakana character with a 'se' syllable and after worrying about my character's health status, I forgot that katakana character right away and have to think again lol). If anything, I think those "distractions" served as a way to keep the learning process entertaining and helps you recall things upon getting distracted. Probably subjective but that's my take on it.

I don't think I have anything to dislike about this game. Just grab it if you're still thinking twice after reading this review!

author: {'steamid': '76561197975734585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1493920142}
review:
Quasi die Fortsetzung von Hiragana-Wars.
Liebevoller und umfangreicher gestaltet als der Vorgänger, aber die Dialoge interessieren mich nach wie vor herzlich wenig.
(Bei jedem Dialog wird die Enter-Taste vergewaltigt)
Kernpunkt ist natürlich das Vermöbeln von Katakana-Silben, wodurch sich durch ständiges Wiederholen ein Lerneffekt einstellt. Ich finde das Konzept (weiterhin) spitze. Vor zwei Wochen konnte ich keine einzige japanische Silbe deuten und nun lassen sich Texte ( ohne Kanji ) entschlüsseln. 

Hoffe das Entwicklerteam ist motiviert genug für einen dritten Teil mit den ersten Kanjis (:

author: {'steamid': '76561197993767973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1167, 'last_played': 1491623876}
review:
This is a really useful tool to learn and memorise Katakana. It makes many improvents over the first Hiragana game, the combat system is easier to use, and the frequent reverse levels where you need to choose the symbol are a great opportunity for revision.

It is a little overdesigned however, I would have been happier not to have the voiceovers and relationship quests A la GTAIV, but it doesn't detract from the game in a massive way.

Easily reccomend to anyone who will benefit from context memorise katakana

author: {'steamid': '76561198102531202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1493032296}
review:
Okay, I'm not going to sugar coat it but I will try my best to be polite about it, the voice-over is absolutely... not good and most of the times(in my case) the voiceover doesn't match the text thats shown on screen. I'm enjoying the game overall, so I would recommend it, but would like to have the option to disable the voice-over but won't disable the tutorials on how to say the characters/words/sentences.

Edit: Now that I played the game for a couple of hours I have to say I really enjoy this game(the game mechanics, the story and I enjoy the campiness of this game overall) but the voices please make them stop make them go away. Please give me the option in the settings to make them a bunch of mutes who speak through use of speech bubbles. I would rather give them funny voices in my head and entertain myself by being stupid but hey thats just me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035467477', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1493877122}
review:
Tl;dr basic RPG that helps you learn Katakana pretty quickly. If you're interested in learning Katakana, it's great. If you're not, it's not great.

If you played Hiragana Battle, Katakana war is a really big step forward in terms of game polish. Gameplay still happens on a traditional 16-bit style RPG, but the transitions are very slick, the menus look much better, there's (questionable) voiceover work. It's still, at it's core, a very basic RPG, but the level of modernization between Hiragana Battle and Katakana War is really impressive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018558017', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1490386798}
review:
Learn Japanes To Survive! Hiragana Battle was a game I purchased on a whim, since I had about 8 bucks in my wallet and I decided, "Why not?"
The game itself, while simple, didn't distract from the learning, and the gameplay was challenging from the enemy stats, and it kept me engaged so I continued with the learning, which was done really well!
So, after hearing about Katakana War, I anticipated the release, since I just finished the original. Once it was released and I had the money to spare, I bought the bundle and got to work.
After 3 hours, I quit the game and will probably never go back.
Why? Simple. Katakana War has too much content that distracts from the main focus. Learning with JRPG gameplay.
The gameplay has recieved some improvements, like Boss battles and being able to see the turn order, and the boost of presentation is nicely improved, with great character portraits and some voice acting.
The main problem? There's too many characters. Hiragana Battle had 4 characters, and, while I don't remember their names, I remember their personalities and looks, and they did almost nothing to distract from the learning.
Katakana War, on the other hand, has atleast 10+ characters, all with distinct personalities, and they just keep coming!
Plus, there's socalizing events, which, while welcome in games like Persona, are not needed and it distracts you from the most important part, the part of the title. LEARNING JAPANESE.
So, overall, play Hiragana Battle, and after playing that, study Katakana in a normal way, without playing this, as the little additions distract too much from the main focus of the game.
I give this game a 4/10. It has potential, but the fact the mechanics work AGAINST each other, just ruins it from becoming worthy of a purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136732748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1065, 'last_played': 1490501034}
review: First of all, you don't have to play the first game to play Katakana War, so don't let that hold you back!  Katakana War has some great improvements over Hiragana Battle, with a more enjoyable storyline, more intriguing characters, and a bit more content.  Even with these improvements, however, the storyline and characters remain passable, but nothing you will remember after you finish the game.  However, like the first game, this is probably going to be the most fun way to learn these -kana so, get ready for War!

author: {'steamid': '76561197961918996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1610, 'last_played': 1628215516}
review:
An issue just recently occured to me which drastically changed my oppinion of the game.

The concept is fantastic. You play the game and learn Katakana along the way. Even though the game itself has its flaws, the feeling of actually doing something useful motivates you enough to play on. While 'grinding' is usually a pretty boring element of RPGs, it comes along with training Katakana characters in this one. So you train not just your char but in the meantime yourself as well!
Despite the story being a bit far-fetched and the charakters being pretty shallow, I would still recommend this game. Not for its qualities as an RPG but for the omnipresent side-effect of learning something which might come in handy in the real world. 

There are, however, two things which could be improved to increase the games educational value: 
- There is no option to train specific sets of characters, which results in the player knowing the ones from the beginning of the game much better than the ones from the end (still mixing up Wa- and Ya- series).
- Also the randomizer seems not to work correctly. You often get to fight the same combinations of characters, which leads to you memorizing patterns instead of characters.

All in all a very good price-performance ratio makes this game very attractive to anyone wanting to learn Japanese.

Why do I still not recommend the game? The big flaw is the bad programming. Appearantly the game's .exe triggers alarms of anti-virus softwares. This can lead to the .exe being deleted rendering the game non-functional.

author: {'steamid': '76561198303088956', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 752, 'last_played': 1490327128}
review:
This is another excellent installment in this series and has greatly helped my Japanese study.  For anyone that hasn't already mastered Katakana, I highly recommend this game.  Just like the previous game, it is very similar to the old 80's and 90's JRPG's like Final Fantasy.  This installment also has a far larger Japanese vocabulary written in both Hiragana and Katakana.
It is simple, fun, and effective.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085359654', 'num_games_owned': 129, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1659, 'last_played': 1610598675}
review: I remember beginning to learn Katakana as I was growing up in Japan during my younger years and this game helped me incredibly to recall and continue from then. Katakana War has done a tremendous job in helping me cement and retain Katakana and all the bonus vocab within it as well, and if I sound like I enjoy this game too much, it's because I do, I honest to goodness do. I decided one day to look on steam for a game to help me continue my japanese language education, found this, and I consider myself beyond happy with the luck I had to find this game indeed. I love it, I really reeeaaallly do, and even though I havn't experienced Hiragana Battle yet, I'm definitely looking forward to playing that one next, and I CANNOT wait for Kanji Combat! Thanks for all the love and care put into this game! Thankyou so much! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197999396993', 'num_games_owned': 486, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1028, 'last_played': 1488311603}

author: {'steamid': '76561198053063077', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4411, 'last_played': 1500967586}
review:
Many imporvements made for the second game of this series:

- Menus improved
- Improved boss fight
- Improved graphics
- Interesting level design
- Bigger cast of characters
- RPG elements

and more!

+ I really liked the enhanced RPG elements with the wide variety of characters. The problem with an educational game is getting people motivated enough to start the game up and play it, to want to learn after they bought the game and finish it. I think expanding upon the RPG relationship system that was put into play this game would be a great idea for the next game. Maybe relationships or something other. Nothing too complicated, I do enjoy the simplicity of the affinity system.


- I only had a few problems with this game. The primary problem was the voiceacting. I like many people cant tolerate english dubs, usually this isnt an issue though because theres always an option to control the audio level of the voice acting for cutscenes in most games. However that option was missing from this game. Just to note I think voice acting is worth it so long as people like myself has the option to control the audio.

- Slight performance issues in Osaka and very bad performance issues when I reached max affinity with each character. 

This game is a 9/10, near perfect, enjoyed playing it a lot. VERY excited for the next game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071248331', 'num_games_owned': 109, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1486676942}
review:
Now I can survive 2 differents apocalypses. Zombies and Obake (as hiragana or katakana symbols). Not only I can break bones with rocks and sticks, but also with words.

Alright, jokes asides, I will start this review and try to stay low on spoilers the most as possible. The story is situated 10 years after the previous game (Hiragana Battle), but this time the enemies are Katakana warriors. Originally, their name is Obake, which is a shape shifting spirit. So, of course, you must stop them invading Japan.

This game is pretty good and is more complete than the previous one.

- More quests. 20 quests, which reward you like in Hiragana Battle by giving you an item, cash or a weapon, but also by teaching you a few japanese words in katakana or hiragana.

- More characters to control. 8 in total, but you can only bring up to 4 with you (your main character obligatory and 3 others)

- There are more musics and they are better than in the last game  (especially the boss one)

- The main character is you. You can choose to be either a boy or a girl and also your "class", that I will call a title, which depends of what you answer when you make a new game

- The enemies appear on the map, unlike the previous game where you could meet some every 5 feet. Touching them engage the fight.

- There a new feature which is Affection. Each characters (except you) has an affection bar that goes up when you fight and after some certain amounts, you can talk to the characters to trigger an affection event, which give them some bonus stats. When they reach their maximum affection level with you.... well I won't spoil that part

- Differently from Hiragana Battle, you can only obtain spells during certain key moments in the game instead of leveling up.


Now I will quickly go with some stuff I didn't like much, but those are really minor.

- The spell animations are all the same. By example, a minor thunder spell will have the same animation than a major thunder spell or a thunder spell hitting all enemies.

- Its not really easy to be pretty immersive in the game when everyone keep the same emotion. What I mean is that they only have one facial expression during cutscenes. By example, some of the characters have a smiling or laughing facial expression, even when there a big enemy or when they are angry. I will add a screenshot so you can more easily understand.


http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=857115516

They don't really look worried that there lots of monsters invading the town. Everyone keep the same expression in ALL cutscenes of the game.



- During the final affection event of a character, is it me or after they end talking, the cutscene freezes but still continue in the background? After that, it goes back to normal. Not much of a big deal, but just a bit weird.

- Ok, ok. This one is more of an observation than a minor thing I didn't like. At the end of the game, when the story says what happened to the characters after all the events, I found a typo at Mischa's part. Yea, the word "classes" had an extra "S", which changed it to "classses".

If I can conclude this, well I had a lot of fun playing this game and I even got some good laughs during some cutscenes. It also fulfilled its goal very well since I improved my katakana alphabet knowledge a lot (I barely needed my notebook to find which one is which).


[Spoiler]: A third game is coming and it will be about Kanji (oh no...)

author: {'steamid': '76561198019613750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1488716231}
review:
Useful tool for learning katakana.

I would just recommend having google handy to look up a written example of each character that is not stylized to look like brush strokes, the guides on how to write the characters become a bit confusing trying to figure out which characters have a tail on them, and which characters just have the tail because the brush stroke makes it look like it has a tail.

Example being the letter U. ウ
http://i.imgur.com/u3yAgkD.png

The U is just two straight lines at the top and the left, but the image made me believe there might be a curve to the line on the left.


Second example being the letter O. オ
http://i.imgur.com/iGide0m.png

The O has a tail on the vertical line but I confused it at the start for not just being part of the brush stroke. 

Hopefully in the future they can update the lessons to have a few simpler characters visually without the brush strokes added onto the lessons. Like adding it in the dialog at the bottom of the screen for easy reference.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061928422', 'num_games_owned': 810, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 670, 'last_played': 1489781754}

review:
Learn Japanese to survive: Katakana war. Is a very great way to learn your Katakana alphabet, Very clear instructions on pronounciation and how to draw these characters. Youre constantly repeating them when you are defeating your enemies and just a solid way to learn and remember the Katakana characters, for anyone who wants to learn Katakana and like to play games. 

I have played Learn Japanese to survive: Hiragana Battle, aswell, it's a very good game for learning Japanese and as Hiragana is the most common used alphabet in Japanese, you won't be needing it for this game as it is only focused on Katakana, but i do dearly recommend both games if you want to learn Japanese.

On a sidenote, does anyone else have a problem with the WASD movement keys? i cannot get them to work, i changed them to the WASD movement layout in the menu and clicked finish, but it doesn't work. Help would be appreaciated.

Great game 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198197701861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1486082870}
review:
This game is a unique Japanese learning game and is good for beginners. I had never considered learning Japanese until playing through the previous title, Hirigana Battle, which made a seemingly daunting experience into a fun and challenging one. It also gave me the confidence to learn the katakana and begin learning the grammar, kanji etc.

Since the last game, attack turns play out for each character individually and not as a group. This way, there is less punishment for guessing an incorrect answer. Also there's more emphasis storylines, character art etc but imo the game just has too many characters with too much dialouge. 

However I did start this game having already memorized the Katakana and so it didn't do much for me anyway. Still, I recommend this for beginners.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974795849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1487132645}
